rdf:Description.dc:title: Puget Sound Salish basketmaker, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Baskets; Basket making--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Coast Salish Indians--Arts & Crafts; Coast Salish Indians--Women; Women--Arts & Crafts
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Coast Salish peoples are a diverse group of Indigenous people of the Pacific Northwest who speak related languages and have some common cultural traditions. The Coast Salish grouping includes many different tribal groups, all with their own names for themselves and most with their own languages. Coast Salish peoples have lived in the Pacific Northwest since time immemorial and their traditional lands surround the Salish Sea, including part of the Olympic Peninsula, the coast of Puget Sound, the eastern side of Vancouver Island, and the southern coast of British Columbia.
The Coast Salish peoples of the Puget Sound region were famous for their coiled and twined baskets. Some of the baskets were so tightly made that they could hold water. In this photo taken around 1900, a Coast Salish basketmaker holds a split cedar root in her mouth, ready to work it into her basket.
Caption information source: "Coast Salish people & languages," Burke Museum, retrieved from https://www.burkemuseum.org/collections-and-research/culture/contemporary-culture/coast-salish-art/coast-salish-people.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Wilse Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Makah boy rowing a canoe at Neah Bay, 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Canoes--Makah Indians; Canoes--Washington (State)--Neah Bay; Boys--Washington (State)--Neah Bay; Makah Indians--Children
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
In this photo, a small Makah boy holds the oars of a large cedar canoe at Neah Bay. Makah children learned how to handle canoes at a young age. The Makah used their large canoes for long-distance travel, fishing, and for hunting whales.
Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com Caption on image: Copyrighted 1900
rdf:Description.dc:source: Wilse Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two Makah basketmakers at Neah Bay, 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Aged persons--Washington (State)--Neah Bay; Baskets.; Basket making--Washington (State)--Neah Bay; Makah Indians--Women--Arts & crafts; Makah Indians--Women--Clothing & dress; Makah Indians--Structures; Women--Washington (State)--Neah Bay
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
These women are weaving the delicate wrapped twined baskets for which the Makah are well known. The baskets are made from cedar bark warps and grass wefts, some of which are dyed various colors. Most of the small "trinket baskets" as they were called had lids and were decorated with geometric and animal or bird designs.
Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com

rdf:Description.dc:title: Makah sailing canoe, 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Canoes--Makah Indians; Canoes--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Makah Indians--Transportation
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
The Makah people built large ocean-going canoes which they used for whale hunting and for voyages around Puget Sound. By 1900, when this photo was taken, Makah canoes shared the waters with many large steamships and sailing craft. This photo shows a Makah sailing canoe in the foreground and a large three-masted sailing ship behind.
Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com Caption on image: Copyrighted 1900

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Makah Indians--Transportation; Makah Indians--Subsistence activities; Canoes--Makah Indians; Canoes--Washington (State)--Neah Bay
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
The Makah used their large canoes for long-distance travel, fishing, and for hunting whales. In this photo, taken at Neah Bay, Makah men, women, and children pull their canoe up on the beach on rollers. This canoe also has a cloth sail which is furled in the bow of the canoe. Before European contact, the Makah used cedar bark sails on their canoes.
Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com

rdf:Description.dc:title: Whaling canoe at Neah Bay, 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Canoes--Makah Indians; Canoes--Washington (State)--Neah Bay; Makah Indians--Subsistence activities; Waterfronts--Washington (State)--Neah Bay; Whaling
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
The Makah people of Washington's Olympic Peninsula hunted whales and other sea mammals from large seagoing canoes. The hunters harpooned the animals and kept them from sinking by attaching floats made from sealskin filled with air. This photo taken in 1900 shows a row of Makah canoes, probably at Neah Bay. The canoe in the foreground is filled with sealskin floats.
Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com Captions on image: The whaling canoe ; Copyrighted 1900.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Woman with hop basket, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Baskets; Harvesting--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Hops--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Employment; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Clothing & dress
rdf:Description.dc:description:
From the late 1860s to the early 1890s, hop farming was an important activity in the valleys of the Puget Sound region, including Puyallup, White River, and Snoqualmie. Indigenous workers came from through the Pacific Northwest, Canada, and Alaska (but especially from regional tribes like the Puyallup, Snoqualmie, Muckleshoot, Duwamish, Sammamish, Lummi, and Nisqually) as a seasonal labor force to harvest these crops in last summer and early autumn.
These Indigenous workers gathered the cone-like fruit into handmade baskets, as shown in the photograph. Indigenous people used split cedar or spruce root to make this type of open-weave storage basket, traditionally used to store dried foods and household goods in the longhouses.
Caption information source: "Indigenous Hop Pickers in Western Washington" by Hans Zeiger, HistoryLink.org Essay 21295.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Wilse Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nellie Stimson’s basket collection, Seattle, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Stimson family--Homes & haunts; Baskets; Indians of North America--Arts & crafts; Interiors--Washington (State)--Seattle; Light fixtures.; Mantels--Washington (State)--Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:description:
At the turn of 19th to 20th centuries, Indigenous artists in the Pacific Northwest were making baskets and carvings specifically for the tourist trade and were experimenting with form and design. In Nellie (Mrs. Fred) Stimson’s Seattle home, baskets from the Pacific Northwest as well as from the Great Basin and Southwest were displayed in abundance.
Caption information source: "Northwest Coast Basketry," by Silvia Koros for the Burke Museum, retrieved from https://www.burkemuseum.org/static/baskets/Teachersguideforbasketry.htm.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Wilse Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Portrait of Yaht-le-min's wife, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: General Taylor, Mrs.; Coast Salish Indians--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Aged persons; Coast Salish Indians--Clothing & dress; Coast Salish Indians--Women; Jewelry; Women--Washington (State)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
This is a portrait of the wife of Yaht-le-min (called General Taylor by the settlers), a sub-chief of the S'Klallam. Her name is not known. She had her portrait taken with a traditional clam basket in front of a handmade cattail mat. She wears a crucifix pendant, a symbol of the Christian faith introduced by missionaries in the mid-1800s.
Caption information source: "Land and People and Lifestyle," by Jerry Gorsline for the Port Gamble S'Klallam Tribe, retrieved from https://www.pgst.nsn.us/tribal-enterprises/noo-kayet-development/35-top-level/land-and-people-and-lifestyle
rdf:Description.dc:source: Wilse Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
The Makah people of Washington's Olympic Peninsula hunted whales and other sea mammals from large seagoing canoes. The hunters harpooned the animals and kept them from sinking by attaching floats made from sealskin filled with air. These carved cedar dugouts traveled miles out into the open ocean for whale hunting as well as for fishing and trading trips. This image shows a group of hunters landing their canoe at Neah Bay.
Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com Caption on image: Copyrighted 1900 Caption on image: "Return of the whale hunters" ; "Copyrighted 1900."

rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
The Makah people of Washington's Olympic Peninsula hunted whales and other sea mammals from large seagoing canoes. These carved cedar dugouts traveled miles out into the open ocean for whale hunting as well as for fishing and trading trips. This image shows a Makah whale hunter next to a canoe. The float inside the canoe is made from inflated sealskin and was attached to the harpoon line when it was thrust at the whale.
Caption on image: "The old whale hunter" Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com

rdf:Description.dc:title: Encampment of Indigenous people on Ballast Island at the Seattle waterfront, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Camping--Washington (State)--Seattle; Dwellings--Washington (State)--Seattle; Indian encampments--Washington (State)--Seattle; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Seattle; Indians of North America--Structures; Railroad cars--Washington (State)--Seattle; Railroad tracks--Washington (State)--Seattle; Tents--Washington (State)--Seattle; Waterfronts--Washington (State)--Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:description:
In 1865 the Board of Trustees of Seattle passed Ordinance No. 5 banning Indigenous people from living in the city unless they worked for a non-Indigenous resident and lived on their employer’s property. Despite this attempt to enforce separation between Indigenous people and the settlers, Seattle depended on Indigenous people. Settlers relied on Native people for domestic work and for trade of fish, shellfish, and baskets. Indigenous people from across the Pacific Northwest also harvested hops in agricultural areas to the south and east of Seattle.
Because they were excluded from the rest of the city, many Indigenous people stayed on Ballast Island, either when passing through, temporarily stopping, or living on the island year-round. Ballast Island was in the harbor at the foot of Washington Street and was created when sailing ships dumped their ballast in Elliott Bay in order to take on cargo. The only place close to Seattle’s business district where Indigenous people were allowed to live, Ballast Island lacked a source of fresh water or permanent structures. As the waterfront grew in the 1890s, Ballast Island was gradually covered and by the time the seawall was built in 1916, the island was almost completely gone and its Indigenous residents had again been displaced.
This image shows part of the encampment on Ballast Island around 1900. The coastal Native peoples adopted canvas tents in place of their native cattail mat shelters for traveling.
Caption information source: "Exile to Ballast Island," Duwamish Tribe, retrieved from https://www.duwamishtribe.org/exile-to-ballast-island Caption information source: "Seattle Board of Trustees passes ordinance, calling for removal of Indians from the town, on February 7, 1865," by Jennifer Ott, HistoryLink essay #10979, retrieved from https://www.historylink.org/file/10979
rdf:Description.dc:source: Wilse Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indigenous family working in a hop field in western Washington, circa 1900.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultural laborers--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Agricultural laborers--Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Baskets; Harvesting--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Hops--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region--Employment; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region--Children; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region--Clothing & dress
rdf:Description.dc:description:
From the late 1860s to the early 1890s, hop farming was an important activity in the valleys of the Puget Sound region, including Puyallup, White River, and Snoqualmie. Indigenous workers came from throughout the Pacific Northwest, Canada, and Alaska (but especially from regional tribes like the Puyallup, Snoqualmie, Muckleshoot, Duwamish, Sammamish, Lummi, and Nisqually) as a seasonal labor force to harvest these crops in late summer and early autumn. Often, whole families would work together and on occasion entire villages were emptied as people left for the hops harvest. Workers would use downtime to socialize with each other, weave baskets to sell, or fish for salmon.
These Indigenous workers gathered the cone-like fruit into handmade baskets, as shown in this photograph. Indigenous people used split cedar or spruce root to make this type of open-weave storage basket, traditionally used to store dried foods and household goods in the longhouses.
Caption information source: "Indigenous Hop Pickers in Western Washington" by Hans Zeiger, HistoryLink.org Essay 21295.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Wilse Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Young Indigenous woman named Tasha seated by a tent, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tasha (Indian woman); Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Seattle--Women; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Seattle--Clothing & dress; Women--Washington (State)--Seattle--Clothing & dress; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:description:
From the late 1860s to the early 1890s, hop farming was an important activity in the valleys of the Puget Sound region, including Puyallup, White River, and Snoqualmie. Indigenous workers came from throughout the Pacific Northwest, Canada, and Alaska (but especially from regional tribes like the Puyallup, Snoqualmie, Muckleshoot, Duwamish, Sammamish, Lummi, and Nisqually) as a seasonal labor force to harvest these crops in late summer and early autumn.
This portrait of a young woman identified as Tasha was taken inside a canvas tent, probably in a camp along the Seattle waterfront. She was most likely on her way to pick hops on farms to the south and east of the city. Hop picking was an important source of cash income for Indigenous people living in the Pacific Northwest during this time period.
Caption on image: "Tasha"
Caption information source: "Indigenous Hop Pickers in Western Washington" by Hans Zeiger, HistoryLink.org Essay 21295.

rdf:Description.dc:title: White woman buying baskets from an Indigenous woman, Seattle, circa 1911
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Baskets; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Seattle--Women; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Seattle--Commerce; Peddlers--Indians of North America; Peddlers--Washington (State)--Seattle; Women--Washington (State)--Seattle--Commerce
rdf:Description.dc:description:
At the turn of 19th to 20th centuries, Indigenous artists in the Pacific Northwest were making baskets and carvings specifically for the tourist trade and were experimenting with form and design. Making baskets for sale became an import income source for many Indigenous families. In this photo, taken around 1911 outside a downtown Seattle store, a woman bends to ask a basket seller about her wares. The mats and baskets are Nuu-chah-nulth (formerly called Nootka) in style.
Caption information source: "Northwest Coast Basketry," by Silvia Koros for the Burke Museum, retrieved from https://www.burkemuseum.org/static/baskets/Teachersguideforbasketry.htm.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quinault canoe and sightseers, Moclips, Washington, 1914
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Quinault Indians; Beaches--Washington (State)--Moclips; Canoes--Quinault Indians; Canoes--Washington (State)--Moclips; Sightseers--Washington (State)--Moclips
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Quinault are a Coast Salish people whose historic territory was the southwestern Olympic Peninsula. The current Quinault Indian Nation (QIN) has a reservation covering part of their historic lands. In addition to Quinault people, the QIN includes people from several neighboring tribes: Queets, Quileutes, Hohs, Chehalis, Chinook, and Cowlitz. Fishing, especially for salmon, is an important part of Quinault culture. Salmon spawn on the Quinault and Ozette rivers. After the fish laid and fertilized their eggs, Quinault fishers use a wide array of nets or traps to catch them. Historically, the Quinault also hunted whales, seals, and sea lions.
In this image taken near Moclips, a group of tourists watches a Quinault canoe paddle out from the shore. Starting in the early 20th century, oceanside resorts were established on the Pacific coast south of the Quinault reservation, where city residents could enjoy the healthy sea air and salt water.
Caption information source: "Quinault," by Justine E. James and Leilani A. Chubby, in "Native Peoples of the Olympic Peninsula: Who We Are," by the Olympic Peninsula Intertribal Cultural Advisory Committee, University of Oklahoma Press, 2002, p. 99-106.
rdf:Description.dc:source: PEMCO Webster & Stevens Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hwehlchtid's house at Shilshole with canoe anchored offshore, circa 1905
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Salmon Bay Charlie (Duwamish Indian)--Homes & haunts; Duwamish Indians--Structures; Dwellings--Washington (State)--Seattle; Waterfronts--Washington (State)--Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:description:
In 1855, representatives of the Indigenous peoples of the area now known as Seattle, including the Duwamish and Suquamish, signed the Treaty of Point Elliott. As part of this treaty, many Indigenous people agreed to move in their tribal groups to reservations outside of the Seattle area, but some remained. In 1865 the Board of Trustees of Seattle passed Ordinance No. 5 banning Indigenous people from living in the city unless they worked for a non-Indigenous resident and lived on their employer’s property.
Hwehlchtid (called Salmon Bay Charlie by the settlers) of the Shilshole people lived on the southern shore of Salmon Bay, near present-day Ballard, which was then outside of Seattle. Hwehlchtid and his wife Chilohleet'sa (Madeline) remained in their traditional homeland long after others of their tribe had moved away. This photo, taken around 1905, shows their home at Shilshole with a canoe docked outside. Although the wood planks of the house were not hand-hewn as in older dwellings, the traditional smoke hole with its adjustable cover is visible.
Caption source information: "City of the Changers: Indigenous People and the Transformation of Seattle’s Watersheds," by Coll Thrush, Pacific Historical Review, (2006) Vol. 75, No. 1, pages 89–117, Accessed at http://web.mit.edu/people/spirn/Public/Granite%20Garden%20Research/Urban%20Environmental%20History/Thrush%202006%20Indigenous%20People%20Seattle.pdf
rdf:Description.dc:source: PEMCO Webster & Stevens Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Fishing camp at Eagle Harbor on Bainbridge Island, circa 1905
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--British Columbia--Subsistence activities; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Bainbridge Island--Structures; Dwellings--Washington (State)--Bainbridge Island; Fish drying--Washington (State)--Bainbridge Island; Salmon--Drying
rdf:Description.dc:description: Bainbridge Island had been inhabited by the Suquamish people before the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott. In the early 20th century, a group of Indigenous people from British Columbia set up a camp on Eagle Harbor, near what is now Waterfront Park in Winslow. They harvested clams and fish from Eagle Harbor and other nearby waters to sell to Seattle residents and also dried salmon to preserve it for later use. In this photo, taken at the camp, men and children stand near their plank houses and salmon drying racks. Salmon fishing was an important part of culture and subsistence for many Indigenous people groups surrounding the Salish Sea.
rdf:Description.dc:source: PEMCO Webster & Stevens Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: William Shelton carving a story pole, circa 1920
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Shelton, William (Snohomish Indian); Snohomish Indians--Arts & crafts; Totem poles; Wood carving--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Wood carvings
rdf:Description.dc:description:
William Shelton (1868-1938), named Wha-ceh-dub or Whah-kay-dub in his native language of Lushootseed, was a cultural leader of the Snohomish and expert woodworker. During his lifetime, Indigenous people were confined to live on reservations and their children were taken to boarding schools. These schools prohibited Indigenous customs or languages in an attempt to "civilize" Indigenous children and eradicate their culture. At the time, many people both white and Indigenous believed that Indigenous people and their cultural identities would eventually vanish completely.
William Shelton wanted to preserve his peoples’ stories and cultural values through art. Though totem poles were not traditionally made by the Indigenous peoples of Washington, he decided to adapt the form. He gathered stories from elders of multiple tribes in western Washington and began carving a 60-foot pole with figures that represented the stories. The pole also included figures called skla’letut which represent guardian spirits or supernatural powers and figures that Shelton remembered from his childhood on the Tulalip Reservation. He called the result a "story pole." His first story pole was carved in 1912 and installed in 1913 in front of the Tulalip Indian School. Over the rest of his life Shelton carved at least 16 additional large story poles for public display.
This image shows Shelton carving a story pole commissioned by the City of Everett. This pole was installed in 1923 and includes figures of an octopus, a man, and a frog.
Caption information source: "The carved legacy of Snohomish cultural leader William Shelton," by Christy Christodoulides, Burke Museum, retrieved from: https://www.burkemuseum.org/news/carved-legacy-snohomish-cultural-leader-william-shelton Caption information source: "Shelton, William (1868-1938)," by Margaret Riddle, HistoryLink essay #8928, retrieved from: https://www.historylink.org/File/8928
rdf:Description.dc:source: PEMCO Webster & Stevens Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two Yakama couples in traditional dress, Seattle, January 29, 1921
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Williams, Caesar (Yakama Indian); Williams, Kate (Yakama Indian); Watson, Homer, Mrs. (Yakama Indian); Watson, Homer (Yakama Indian); Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress; Yakama Indians--Political activity; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Spouses--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Tribal chiefs--United States
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Yakama (formerly spelled Yakima) people have lived in the Columbia River basin since time immemorial. During the winter, they lived in permanent villages built on the valley floor, where the climate was most temperate. Starting in spring, they traveled along the rivers and into the hills to gather food. Some gathered roots and berries, and others fished in rivers, especially the Columbia and the Yakima. In 1855, a confederation of 14 tribal groups signed the Yakama Nation Treaty with the United States and ceded most of their traditional lands, but reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. These groups were: Kah-miltpah, Palouse, Klickitat, See-ap-Cat, Klinquit, Sk-in-pah, Li-ay-was, Oche-Chotes, Wenatchapam, Pesquose, Yakama, Shyiks, Know-was-say-ee, and Wish-ham. All 14 groups are now part of the Confederated Tribes and Bands of the Yakama Nation and live on a reservation in central Washington.
On January 29, 1921, seven members of the Yakama nation stopped in Seattle on their way back from Olympia, where they appeared before the Washington State Senate. The 1855 treaty, which guaranteed the right to fish the Yakima River, was threatened by restrictions at the new Prosser Dam in Benton County. This photo shows four members of the delegation, left to right: Chief Lo-páh-hin (Caesar Williams), Yes-to-lah-lemy (Mrs. Kate Williams), Mrs. Homer Watson, and Chief Homer Watson. They wear ceremonial clothing. The beadwork and woven bag are typical of Yakama handicrafts. Chief Lo-páh-hin was a chief from Oregon who joined the delegation; Chief Watson was second in authority among all Yakama groups.
Caption information source: Yakama Nation, retrieved from https://www.yakama.com/about/.
rdf:Description.dc:source: PEMCO Webster & Stevens Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Yakama (formerly spelled Yakima) people have lived in the Columbia River basin since time immemorial. Historically, they lived in permanent winter villages built on the valley floor where the climate was most temperate. Starting in spring, they traveled along the rivers and into the hills to gather food. Some gathered roots and berries, and others fished in rivers, especially the Columbia and the Yakima. In 1855, a confederation of 14 tribal groups signed the Yakama Nation Treaty with the United States and ceded most of their traditional lands, but reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. These groups were: Kah-miltpah, Palouse, Klickitat, See-ap-Cat, Klinquit, Sk-in-pah, Li-ay-was, Oche-Chotes, Wenatchapam, Pesquose, Yakama, Shyiks, Know-was-say-ee, and Wish-ham. All 14 groups are now part of the Confederated Tribes and Bands of the Yakama Nation and live on a reservation in central Washington.
On January 29, 1921, seven members of the Yakama nation stopped in Seattle on their way back from Olympia where they appeared before the Washington State Senate. The 1855 treaty, which guaranteed the right to fish the Yakima River, was threatened by restrictions at the new Prosser Dam in Benton County. This photo shows four members of the delegation in everyday dress, left to right: Chief Lo-páh-hin (Caesar Williams), Yes-to-lah-lemy (Mrs. Kate Williams), Chief Homer Watson, and Mrs. Homer Watson. They are standing outside Seattle's New Richmond Hotel. The hotel was located on the corner of 4th Avenue South and Main Street. Chief Lo-páh-hin was a chief from Oregon who joined the delegation; Chief Watson was second in authority among all Yakama groups.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Group of Suquamish people waiting at Colman Dock, Seattle, circa 1911
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Doctor Peter (Suquamish Indian); Youkton, Charlie (Suquamish Indian); Wahelchu, Jacob, Mrs. (Suquamish Indian); Wahelchu, Jacob (Suquamish Indian); Adams, Mary (Suquamish Indian); Colman Dock (Seattle, Wash.); Suquamish Indians; Arrivals & departures--Suquamish Indians; Arrivals & departures--Washington (State)--Seattle; Tribal chiefs--United States
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Suquamish tribe lived on Bainbridge Island and fished in the waters of Puget Sound long before Seattle was founded. The Suquamish carved dugout canoes and used them to travel to fishing and hunting grounds across Puget Sound. Fishing, especially for salmon, was of central importance to the Suquamish for both subsistence and culture. Suquamish fishers used subtle environmental clues including tides, numbers of birds and seals, and water levels in streams to establish the best places and times to fish. The 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott reduced Suquamish land to some 7,800 acres at Port Madison, just north of the island on the Kitsap Peninsula. Members of the tribe frequently traveled by steamer from the Port Madison Reservation to Seattle to trade for supplies or transact other business. Today, most Suquamish people live on or around the Port Madison reservation and continue to practice their cultural traditions.
In this photo, a group of Suquamish people waits at Seattle's Colman Dock for the steamer to Bainbridge Island after trying to collect land payments owed by the government. Tribal members have identified the six visible members of the group as, left to right: Doctor Peter, Charlie Youkton, Mrs. Chief Jacob, Chief Jacob Wahelchu, [unknown], and Mary Adams.
Original copy negative.
Caption information source: "History & Culture," Suquamish Tribe, retrieved from https://suquamish.nsn.us/home/about-us/history-culture/
rdf:Description.dc:source: PEMCO Webster & Stevens Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indigenous family selling baskets in downtown Seattle, circa 1912
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Frederick & Nelson; Peddlers; Baskets; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Seattle--Commerce
rdf:Description.dc:description:
At the turn of 19th to 20th centuries, Indigenous artists in the Pacific Northwest were making baskets and carvings specifically for the tourist trade and were experimenting with form and design. Making baskets for sale became an important income source for many Indigenous families. In this photo, two women and a boy sit by their baskets on Second Avenue, outside the Frederick & Nelson department store. The twined baskets in the image are of the style made by the Makah people of Neah Bay and the Nuu-cha-nulth (formerly called Nootka) people of Vancouver Island.
Caption information source: "Northwest Coast Basketry," by Silvia Koros for the Burke Museum, retrieved from https://www.burkemuseum.org/static/baskets/Teachersguideforbasketry.htm.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Children in front of girls’ dormitory building, Tulalip Indian School, circa 1912
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Brady, Ferd (Ferdinand)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tulalip Indian School (Wash.); Schools--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Students--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; School children--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Education; Dormitories--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Uniforms
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word “dxwlilap,” meaning “small-mouth bay.”
Catholic missionaries opened a boarding school on the Tulalip reservation in 1857. After a few years, the school began receiving funding from the federal government and in 1902 the government fully took over the school. That year, the original school buildings burned down, and a new school reopened in 1905. The school had a capacity of 200 students, who were as young as six. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip Indian School. The Tulalip school was one of many boarding schools for Indigenous children across the US. These schools were an attempt to “civilize” Indigenous peoples by forcing their children to assimilate to white-dominated Western society. One of the primary ways the schools undertook this goal was forcing students to speak English exclusively. Severe punishment, including physical punishment, was imposed when students spoke their native languages or otherwise resisted school authorities.
This image shows the youngest students lined up in front of the girls’ dormitory. The upper floor contained the bedrooms (including a sick room), the middle floor had a music room in the left wing, a reading room in the right, and a dining room in the center. Showers and a play room were in the basement.
Caption on image: "Brady photo."
Caption information source: History, Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. Caption information source: Assimilation Through Education: Indian Boarding Schools in the Pacific Northwest, by Carolyn Marr, retrieved from https://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/marr.html.
rdf:Description.dc:type: silver gelatin print; photograph; image StillImage
rdf:Description.dc:source: Brady Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."
Catholic missionaries opened a boarding school on the Tulalip reservation in 1857. After a few years, the school began receiving funding from the federal government and in 1902 the government fully took over the school. That year, the original school buildings burned down, and a new school reopened in 1905. The school had a capacity of 200 students, who were as young as six. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip Indian School. The Tulalip school was one of many boarding schools for Indigenous children across the US. These schools were an attempt to "civilize" Indigenous peoples by forcing their children to assimilate to white-dominated Western society. One of the primary ways the schools undertook this goal was forcing students to speak English exclusively. Severe punishment, including physical punishment, was imposed when students spoke their native languages or otherwise resisted school authorities.
This image shows the students eating dinner. Even mealtimes had a strict military atmosphere; the students marched into the dining room and stood at their places until a signal was given to sit down. Boys and girls ate their meals at separate tables in the dining room. Students prepared and served the meals and cleaned up afterwards.
Caption information source: "History," Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word “dxwlilap,” meaning “small-mouth bay.”
This image was taken on the Tulalip Indian Reservation on the 4th of July. It shows a tug of war between two canoes as part of the celebrations. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip reservation and boarding school.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two racing canoes, Tulalip Bay, circa 1912
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Brady, Ferd (Ferdinand)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tulalip Indian School (Wash.); Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation--Education; Schools--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Canoes--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Canoes--Indians of North America--Washington (State); Racing--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Social life; Holidays--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."
At the Tulalip Indian Reservation, canoe races often took place on the 4th of July. Eleven-person teams competed in many different races with different types of canoes. Women also participated on their own teams, usually with a male bow man and captain. This image shows a race between long canoes. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip reservation and boarding school.
Caption information source: "History," Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History.

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Brady, Ferd (Ferdinand)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tulalip Indian School (Wash.); Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation--Education; Schools--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Canoes--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Canoes--Indians of North America--Washington (State); Racing--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Social life; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Children; Boys--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."
At the Tulalip Indian Reservation, canoe races often took place on the 4th of July. Here, teams of two boys compete in small dugouts. The canoes shown are the traditional Coast Salish notched-prow style, except for the second from the left, which has the prow of a West Coast style. The former became extremely rare by the middle of the century, as the latter became more numerous. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip reservation and boarding school.
Caption on image: "Little canoe race, Tulalip Indian Boys."
Caption information source: "History," Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. Caption information source: "Northwest Coast Canoes," Simon Fraser University, retrieved from https://www.sfu.ca/brc/art_architecture/canoes.html.

The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."
Fourth of July festivities at the Tulalip Indian Reservation often included a parade of canoes, pulled past the spectators by the Indian School's small motor launch. Shown in this photo are several canoes of different sizes with Camano Head in the background. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip reservation and boarding school.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tulalip Indian School building, circa 1912
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Brady, Ferd (Ferdinand)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tulalip Indian School (Wash.); Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation--Education; Schools--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."
Catholic missionaries opened a boarding school on the Tulalip reservation in 1857. After a few years, the school began receiving funding from the federal government and in 1902 the government fully took over the school. That year, the original school buildings burned down, and a new school reopened in 1905. The school had a capacity of 200 students, who were as young as six. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip Indian School. The Tulalip school was one of many boarding schools for Indigenous children across the US. These schools were an attempt to "civilize" Indigenous peoples by forcing their children to assimilate to white-dominated Western society. One of the primary ways the schools undertook this goal was forcing students to speak English exclusively. Severe punishment, including physical punishment, was imposed when students spoke their native languages or otherwise resisted school authorities.
Buildings on the school grounds included the boys’ dormitory, the girls’ dormitory, a machine shop, the hospital, and other structures for the maintenance of the campus. Pupils spent half days in classes in this school building; here they learned spelling, reading, arithmetic, history, geography, and hygiene. The other half of their days were spent doing work to maintain the school and its grounds.
Caption on image: "School building - T.I.S."
Caption information source: "History," Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. Caption information source: "Assimilation Through Education: Indian Boarding Schools in the Pacific Northwest," by Carolyn Marr, retrieved from https://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/marr.html.

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Brady, Ferd (Ferdinand)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Curley, Fred (Lummi Indian); Jones, George (Tulalip Indian); Sam, Alfred (Snohomish); Joe, Joseph; Shelton, Aloysius (Tulalip Indian); Cladoosby, Ernest (Swinomish Indian); George, Leo (Tulalip Indian); Tulalip Indian School (Wash.); Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation--Education; Schools--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Students--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Social life; Bands; Musical instruments
rdf:Description.dc:description:
"The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word “dxwlilap,” meaning “small-mouth bay.”
Catholic missionaries opened a boarding school on the Tulalip reservation in 1857. After a few years, the school began receiving funding from the federal government and in 1902 the government fully took over the school. That year, the original school buildings burned down, and a new school reopened in 1905. The school had a capacity of 200 students, who were as young as six. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip Indian School. The Tulalip school was one of many boarding schools for Indigenous children across the US. These schools were an attempt to “civilize” Indigenous peoples by forcing their children to assimilate to white-dominated Western society. One of the primary ways the schools undertook this goal was forcing students to speak English exclusively. Severe punishment, including physical punishment, was imposed when students spoke their native languages or otherwise resisted school authorities.
Student bands at the Tulalip school date back to 1860, when the school was operated by Catholic missionaries. That year, the school had 15 students and its all-boys band played in nearby towns to raise money for the school. In 1912, members of the band included, front row, left to right: Fred Curley (Lummi); George Jones (Tulalip); and Alfred Sam (Snohomish) at far right. Top row, left to right are: Joseph Joe; Aloysius Shelton (Tulalip); unknown; Ernest Cladoosby (Swinomish); and Leo George (Tulalip) at far right. The band played in the town of Marysville and traveled to other reservations to perform for special occasions.
Caption information source: “History,” Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. Caption information source: “Assimilation Through Education: Indian Boarding Schools in the Pacific Northwest,” by Carolyn Marr, retrieved from https://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/marr.html."

rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word “dxwlilap,” meaning “small-mouth bay.”
Catholic missionaries opened a boarding school on the Tulalip reservation in 1857. After a few years, the school began receiving funding from the federal government and in 1902 the government fully took over the school. That year, the original school buildings burned down, and a new school reopened in 1905. The school had a capacity of 200 students, who were as young as six. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip Indian School. The Tulalip school was one of many boarding schools for Indigenous children across the US. These schools were an attempt to “civilize” Indigenous peoples by forcing their children to assimilate to white-dominated Western society. One of the primary ways the schools undertook this goal was forcing students to speak English exclusively. Severe punishment, including physical punishment, was imposed when students spoke their native languages or otherwise resisted school authorities.
Students split their days between classroom lessons and working to maintain the school. Among other assignments, boys were assigned to tend the school garden during their daily work period. They grew all of the vegetables eaten in the school dining room. The young fruit trees in the background grew to become part of the large orchard that produced fruit for the school. Here, several young boys pose for the camera, along with the school’s farmer and his wife and child.
Caption information source: “History,” Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. rdf:Description.dc:title: Game of Slahal, Treaty Day celebration, Tulalip, 1912
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Brady, Ferd (Ferdinand)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tulalip Indian School (Wash.); Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation--Education; Schools--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Students--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; School children--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Social life; Gambling--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Crowds--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."
Catholic missionaries opened a boarding school on the Tulalip reservation in 1857. After a few years, the school began receiving funding from the federal government and in 1902 the government fully took over the school. That year, the original school buildings burned down, and a new school reopened in 1905. The school had a capacity of 200 students, who were as young as six. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip Indian School. The Tulalip school was one of many boarding schools for Indigenous children across the US. These schools were an attempt to "civilize" Indigenous peoples by forcing their children to assimilate to white-dominated Western society. One of the primary ways the schools undertook this goal was forcing students to speak English exclusively. Severe punishment, including physical punishment, was imposed when students spoke their native languages or otherwise resisted school authorities.
Under most circumstances, traditional games such as slahal, the bone game, were discouraged by the "Indian agents" who administered the reservations. On this occasion, the anniversary of the signing of the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, the bone game is a center attraction. Teams have lined up facing each other while a crowd watches. The school boys, in their corduroy uniforms and hats, kneel in the foreground, and some of the girls look down from a balcony of the Girls' Building. Slahal is a gambling game played by many Indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest. It involves hiding animal bones in one team's hands while the other guesses which hand holds the bones.
Caption on image: "Indian Gambling Game - Treaty Day Celebration at Tulalip Jan. 22, 1912"
Caption information source: "History," Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. Caption information source: "Assimilation Through Education: Indian Boarding Schools in the Pacific Northwest," by Carolyn Marr, retrieved from https://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/marr.html.

rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."
Catholic missionaries opened a boarding school on the Tulalip reservation in 1857. After a few years, the school began receiving funding from the federal government and in 1902 the government fully took over the school. That year, the original school buildings burned down, and a new school reopened in 1905. The school had a capacity of 200 students, who were as young as six. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip Indian School. The Tulalip school was one of many boarding schools for Indigenous children across the US. These schools were an attempt to "civilize" Indigenous peoples by forcing their children to assimilate to white-dominated Western society. One of the primary ways the schools undertook this goal was forcing students to speak English exclusively. Severe punishment, including physical punishment, was imposed when students spoke their native languages or otherwise resisted school authorities.
Illness was a constant fear among boarding school students and staff. The influenza epidemic of 1918 hit hard at Tulalip, and there was a very real threat of tuberculosis for many years. The hospital building had two wards, one for boys and one for girls. The dormitories each had a sick room for minor ailments. The staff in this photo include student nurses in training: Josie Cayou (Swinomish); Theresa Young (Tulalip); Myrtle Loughrey (Suquamish); Clara Jones (Swinomish); Emily Limon (Upper Skagit); and Annie Nason (Muckleshoot, in center). Nurse O’Dell and Dr. Buchanan stand at the rear.
Caption information source: "History," Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. Caption information source: "Assimilation Through Education: Indian Boarding Schools in the Pacific Northwest," by Carolyn Marr, retrieved from https://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/marr.html.

In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Brady, Ferd (Ferdinand)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Shelton, William (Snohomish Indian); Bob, Clement; Shelton, Robert (Snohomish Indian); Loughrey, Roy (Suquamish Indian); Joe, Joseph; Day, Augustus; Tulalip Indian School (Wash.); Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation--Education; Schools--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Students--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Children--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation--Sports; Baseball players--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Sports--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."
Catholic missionaries opened a boarding school on the Tulalip reservation in 1857. After a few years, the school began receiving funding from the federal government and in 1902 the government fully took over the school. That year, the original school buildings burned down, and a new school reopened in 1905. The school had a capacity of 200 students, who were as young as six. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip Indian School. The Tulalip school was one of many boarding schools for Indigenous children across the US. These schools were an attempt to "civilize" Indigenous peoples by forcing their children to assimilate to white-dominated Western society. One of the primary ways the schools undertook this goal was forcing students to speak English exclusively. Severe punishment, including physical punishment, was imposed when students spoke their native languages or otherwise resisted school authorities.
Baseball, which somewhat resembles the Indigenous game of stick ball, was the most popular sport among students. In earlier years, players fashioned their own handmade bats and sometimes played barehanded. On the team pictured here are Clemont Bob, second from left in back row; Robert Shelton, third from right; Roy Loughrey, second from right; Joseph Joe, far right; and Augustus Day, seated on right. In the back row, holding a pennant, is William Shelton, an employee of the school and Robert’s father. William Shelton (1868-1938), named Wha-ceh-dub or Whah-kay-dub in his native language of Lushootseed, was a cultural leader of the Snohomish and expert woodworker and carver of story poles.
Caption information source: "History," Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. Caption information source: "Assimilation Through Education: Indian Boarding Schools in the Pacific Northwest," by Carolyn Marr, retrieved from https://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/marr.html.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tulalip men working on a log boom, circa 1912
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Brady, Ferd (Ferdinand)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Lumber industry--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation--Employment; Logs
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."
Loggers cleared most of the reservation land in the first part of the 20th century. The cut logs were hauled to the bay and floated in log booms to sawmills located throughout the area. The Tulalip Indian School also encouraged its students to become farmers, which required the clearing of forests on the reservation. Indigenous men, like the three seen here, found employment in all aspects of the lumber industry.
The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip reservation and boarding school.
Caption on image: "Tulalip Indians working on a log boom."
Caption information source: "History," Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. Caption information source: "Assimilation Through Education: Indian Boarding Schools in the Pacific Northwest," by Carolyn Marr, retrieved from https://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/marr.html.

rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."
Catholic missionaries opened a boarding school on the Tulalip reservation in 1857. After a few years, the school began receiving funding from the federal government and in 1902 the government fully took over the school. That year, the original school buildings burned down, and a new school reopened in 1905. The school had a capacity of 200 students, who were as young as six. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip Indian School. The Tulalip school was one of many boarding schools for Indigenous children across the US. These schools were an attempt to "civilize" Indigenous peoples by forcing their children to assimilate to white-dominated Western society. One of the primary ways the schools undertook this goal was forcing students to speak English exclusively. Severe punishment, including physical punishment, was imposed when students spoke their native languages or otherwise resisted school authorities.
Every student at the boarding school spent at least half of his or her day working in some part of the operation. Boys rotated about every six weeks between jobs as carpenters, engineers, farmers or dairymen; girls were assigned to sewing, darning, laundry and kitchen work. As part of their regular work assignment, some of the young men chopped, split, and stacked hundreds of cords of wood to feed the steam boilers which supplied heat and power to the school buildings. Shown in this photo are Sebastian Williams (second from left), Woody Loughrey (fifth from left) and Clarence Shelton (third from right).
Caption on image: "Engineer boys T.I.S."
Caption information source: "History," Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. Caption information source: "Assimilation Through Education: Indian Boarding Schools in the Pacific Northwest," by Carolyn Marr, retrieved from https://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/marr.html.

rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."
Catholic missionaries opened a boarding school on the Tulalip reservation in 1857. After a few years, the school began receiving funding from the federal government and in 1902 the government fully took over the school. That year, the original school buildings burned down, and a new school reopened in 1905. The school had a capacity of 200 students, who were as young as six. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip Indian School. The Tulalip school was one of many boarding schools for Indigenous children across the US. These schools were an attempt to "civilize" Indigenous peoples by forcing their children to assimilate to white-dominated Western society. One of the primary ways the schools undertook this goal was forcing students to speak English exclusively. Severe punishment, including physical punishment, was imposed when students spoke their native languages or otherwise resisted school authorities.
As part of their efforts to assimilate the students, school authorities limited contact between students and their families, but parents were allowed to visit briefly the school on weekends, and that may have been the occasion for this photo. Lucy and Bill Dunbar are shown with their children Josephine and Billy, Jr., who both attended the school.
Caption information source: "History," Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."

After a few years, the school began receiving funding from the federal government and in 1902 the government fully took over the school. These schools were an attempt to "civilize" Indigenous peoples by forcing their children to assimilate to white-dominated Western society. One of the primary ways the schools undertook this goal was forcing students to speak English exclusively. Severe punishment, including physical punishment, was imposed when students spoke their native languages or otherwise resisted school authorities.
The school’s administration strongly encouraged athletic teams, such as this 1912 girls basketball squad. Basketball games took place in a wooden pavilion and other ball games at a ball field at the top of the hill above the school. Players identified in this photo are: Catherine Edwards (Swinomish, far left); Clara Siddle (Muckleshoot, center holding ball); Annie Nelson (Muckleshoot); Maggie Daniels; and Agatha Henry (Suquamish). The coach is Mr. Rosenberg, Assistant Engineer for the school, who came from Alaska.
Caption on image: "First basket ball team 1912"

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tulalip Indian School grounds, circa 1912
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Brady, Ferd (Ferdinand)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tulalip Indian School (Wash.); Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation--Education; Schools--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Waterfronts--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Piers & wharves--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."
Catholic missionaries opened a boarding school on the Tulalip reservation in 1857. After a few years, the school began receiving funding from the federal government and in 1902 the government fully took over the school. That year, the original school buildings burned down, and a new school reopened in 1905. The school had a capacity of 200 students, who were as young as six. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip Indian School. The Tulalip school was one of many boarding schools for Indigenous children across the US. These schools were an attempt to "civilize" Indigenous peoples by forcing their children to assimilate to white-dominated Western society. One of the primary ways the schools undertook this goal was forcing students to speak English exclusively. Severe punishment, including physical punishment, was imposed when students spoke their native languages or otherwise resisted school authorities.
The Tulalip Indian School was situated on reservation land along the shores of Tulalip Bay. During the early years of the school nearly all transportation was by water. A steamer arrived at the dock on a regular schedule carrying mail and visitors. After a fire in 1902 destroyed the older St. Anne’s Catholic Mission School, which had been at this site since 1861, the federal government funded construction of the buildings shown in this photograph. The new school opened in 1905. The Tulalip Indian School closed in 1932.
Caption information source: "History," Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. Caption information source: "Assimilation Through Education: Indian Boarding Schools in the Pacific Northwest," by Carolyn Marr, retrieved from https://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/marr.html.
