rdf:Description.dc:title: Sawmill, Tulalip Indian School, circa 1912
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Brady, Ferd (Ferdinand)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tulalip Indian School (Wash.); Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation--Education; Schools--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Mills--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Lumber industry--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word "dxwlilap," meaning "small-mouth bay."
Catholic missionaries opened a boarding school on the Tulalip reservation in 1857. After a few years, the school began receiving funding from the federal government and in 1902 the government fully took over the school. That year, the original school buildings burned down, and a new school reopened in 1905. The school had a capacity of 200 students, who were as young as six. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip Indian School. The Tulalip school was one of many boarding schools for Indigenous children across the US. These schools were an attempt to "civilize" Indigenous peoples by forcing their children to assimilate to white-dominated Western society. One of the primary ways the schools undertook this goal was forcing students to speak English exclusively. Severe punishment, including physical punishment, was imposed when students spoke their native languages or otherwise resisted school authorities.
A sawmill located next to Tulalip Creek served the entire community. When wood or lumber were needed, logs were hauled in log booms across the bay to the mill. The creek was later dammed to supply electricity, and a powerhouse was built at the mill site. William Shelton (Snohomish), an employee of the school, served as the sawyer at this time. Shelton (1868-1938), named Wha-ceh-dub or Whah-kay-dub in his native language of Lushootseed, was a cultural leader of the Snohomish and expert woodworker and carver of story poles.
Caption on image: "Sawmill T.I.S."
Caption information source: "History," Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. Caption information source: "Assimilation Through Education: Indian Boarding Schools in the Pacific Northwest," by Carolyn Marr, retrieved from https://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/marr.html.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Boys with buckets, Tulalip Indian School, circa 1912
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Brady, Ferd (Ferdinand)

rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tulalip Tribes are a confederation of several Coast Salish peoples including the Snohomish, Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Skagit, Suiattle, Samish, Stillaguamish, and other allied tribes and bands. In the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott, these groups ceded most of their land to the United States and reserved the Tulalip Indian Reservation for their permanent homeland. They also reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The name Tulalip comes from the Coast Salish word “dxwlilap,” meaning “small-mouth bay.”
Catholic missionaries opened a boarding school on the Tulalip reservation in 1857. After a few years, the school began receiving funding from the federal government and in 1902 the government fully took over the school. That year, the original school buildings burned down, and a new school reopened in 1905. The school had a capacity of 200 students, who were as young as six. The photographer Ferdinand Brady had a government contract in the 1910s to photograph the people and activities around the Tulalip Indian School. The Tulalip school was one of many boarding schools for Indigenous children across the US. These schools were an attempt to “civilize” Indigenous peoples by forcing their children to assimilate to white-dominated Western society. One of the primary ways the schools undertook this goal was forcing students to speak English exclusively. Severe punishment, including physical punishment, was imposed when students spoke their native languages or otherwise resisted school authorities.
A member of the Tulalip Tribes contacted by the Museum of History and Industry identified the group in this photo as the milking brigade. Each day, the boys milked 40 to 50 cows in the dairy up the hill from the school. A published history of the Suquamish tribe, ""The Eyes of Chief Seattle,"" identifies the group as ""houseboys"", implying that they cleaned and did other domestic work.
Caption information source: “History,” Tulalip Tribes, retrieved from https://www.tulaliptribes-nsn.gov/WhoWeAre/History. rdf:Description.dc:title: Young Doctor and his wife Lizzie, Neah Bay, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCurdy, James G.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Young Doctor (Makah Indian woodcarver); Lizzie (wife of Young Doctor, Makah Indian woodcarver); Artists; Makah Indians--Arts & crafts; Makah Indians--Clothing & dress; Spouses--Washington (State)--Neah Bay; Wood carving--Washington (State)--Neah Bay; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Neah Bay
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
Young Doctor (circa 1851-1934) was a well-known Makah carver and musician whose life spanned a period of intense cultural change. Shown in this photograph with his wife Lizzie, Young Doctor holds an adze and a partially carved staff. Carvings of model canoes, a human figure, and a whale with floats attached are arranged on the steps of the building.
The photographer, James McCurdy, was born in Port Townsend in 1872. He spent many years of his childhood in Neah Bay on the Makah reservation and returned to Port Townsend in 1894. In his memoir "Indian Days at Neah Bay", McCurdy stated that none could match the precise skill of Young Doctor, who had learned his craft from his father and was aided by spirit helpers.
Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com Caption information source: Charles T. Hommel, A Guide to Historical Photograph Collections in Seattle, p. 33
rdf:Description.dc:source: McCurdy Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Atlieu, Nuu-cha-nulth carver, Neah Bay, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCurdy, James G.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Atlieu; Artists; Wood carving--Washington (State)--Neah Bay; Nuu-chah-nulth Indians--Arts & crafts; Masks
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Nuu-chah-nulth are a group of 14 First Nations peoples living on the west side of Vancouver Island: Ditidaht, Huu-ay-aht, Hupacasath, Tse-shaht, Uchucklesaht, Ahousaht, Hesquiaht, Tla-o-qui-aht, Toquaht, Ucluelet, Ehattesaht, Kyuqout/Checlesaht, Mowachat/Muchalaht, and Nuchatlaht. They share cultural traditions and language but remain distinct nations, each with a hereditary chief. The Nuu-chah-nulth peoples were previously called the Nootka after European colonizers misunderstood their name and assumed them all to be one tribe, but they collectively chose this new name for themselves in 1978. Fishing and whaling were important parts of Nuu-chah-nulth culture, and they continue to protect their hunting and fishing rights on traditional territory. The Nuu-chah-nulth also have a tradition of skilled woodworking; they build totem poles, multifamily homes, and large oceangoing canoes. Over the 19th century, the increasing presence of settlers displaced the Nuu-chah-nulth from their historic land and they were forced onto reserves created by the Canadian government. As of 2022, the Nuu-chah-nulth Tribal Council represents about 10,000 enrolled members across 14 First Nations on Vancouver Island.
The renowned carver Atlieu (Charlie Williams) came from a Tla-o-qui-aht village on Vancouver Island but lived part of the time with the Makah in Neah Bay, Washington. He received several medals from the Canadian government in recognition of his woodcarving and metalwork, one of which he wears in this photograph. The ceremonial mask he is painting is a good example of Nuu-chah-nulth-style carving. The yew-wood club at the far left shows Atlieu’s distinctive style, with its intertwining animal figures.
The photographer, James McCurdy, was born in Port Townsend in 1872. He spent many years of his childhood in Neah Bay on the Makah reservation and returned to Port Townsend in 1894.
Caption information source: ""Nuu-chah-nulth (Nootka),"" by EY Arima, The Canadian Encyclopedia, retrieved from https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/nootka-nuu-chah-nulth Caption information source: Charles T. Hommel, A Guide to Historical Photograph Collections in Seattle, p. 33"
rdf:Description.dc:source: McCurdy Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Interior of a longhouse, Neah Bay, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCurdy, James G.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Makah Indians--Structures; Makah Indians--Subsistence activities; Houses--Washington (State)--Neah Bay; Interiors--Washington (State)--Neah Bay; Longhouses
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
This photograph is a rare view of the inside of a traditional Makah longhouse around 1900. The smoke holes in the roof are open to let in light, fish are drying on racks near the ceiling, and rolled-up sails are suspended from ropes. Sealskins full of oil, various pots, baskets, a washboard, and cattail mats can also be seen. Traditional Makah longhouses were constructed of split cedar planks placed horizontally and lashed to upright poles with lengths of twisted cedar rope. Sleeping platforms lined the walls and each family had its own cooking place on the earthen floor.
The photographer, James McCurdy, was born in Port Townsend in 1872. He spent many years of his childhood in Neah Bay on the Makah reservation and returned to Port Townsend in 1894.
Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com Caption information source: Charles T. Hommel, A Guide to Historical Photograph Collections in Seattle, p. 33

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quedessa, Makah woman, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCurdy, James G.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Quedessa; Makah Indians--Women; Makah Indians--Clothing & dress; Aged persons--Washington (State)--Olympic Peninsula; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Olympic Peninsula
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
Quedessa was a Makah woman who did household work for the family of the James McCurdy, the photographer of this picture, in Neah Bay in the 1870s. She was married to Lighthouse Jack (also called Frank Parker), a Makah canoe maker and whaler, and she taught young James McCurdy about Makah basketry and Native foods and medicines.
James McCurdy, was born in Port Townsend in 1872. He spent many years of his childhood in Neah Bay on the Makah reservation and returned to Port Townsend in 1894.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Makah woman making baskets at Neah Bay, circa 1905
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCurdy, James G.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Makah Indians--Women; Makah Indians--Arts & crafts; Women--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Baskets; Basket making--Washington (State)--Port Townsend
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
Makah women have a tradition of basketry back to time immemorial. They use grasses, tree bark, or roots to make a variety of baskets and mats for various uses. Some Makah baskets are so tightly woven that they are watertight. Today, the tradition is carried on by both women and men. This photo, taken sometime between about 1900 and 1910, shows a Makah basketmaker on the beach, probably at Port Townsend. She is using cedar bark strips to make a dry storage container.
The photographer, James McCurdy, was born in Port Townsend in 1872. He spent many years of his childhood in Neah Bay on the Makah reservation and returned to Port Townsend in 1894.
Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com Caption information source: "Northwest Coast Basketry," by Silvia Koros for the Burke Museum, retrieved from https://www.burkemuseum.org/static/baskets/Teachersguideforbasketry.htm. Caption information source: Charles T. Hommel, A Guide to Historical Photograph Collections in Seattle, p. 33
rdf:Description.dc:source: McCurdy Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Group seated on the beach with trade items, Port Townsend, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCurdy, James G.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Women; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Children; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Clothing & dress; Women--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Structures--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Port Townsend
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The people in this photograph are not identified, but the items they brought with them in their large sea-going canoes are visible-- bundles of dried cattails for weaving mats and a large, decorated Chinese trunk. The woman in the center appears to be holding a mirror.
The buildings in the distant background indicate the location is probably Port Townsend, Washington. At this time, many Indigenous people traveled to Port Townsend to conduct trade on the beach. Most of the subjects of this image have their backs to the camera. At least one surviving account from Port Townsend indicates that white photographers often photographed Indigenous people, and that some of the Indigenous subjects resented being photographed, asked for compensation, or attempted to avoid being photographed.
The photographer, James McCurdy, was born in Port Townsend in 1872. He spent many years of his childhood in Neah Bay on the Makah reservation and returned to Port Townsend in 1894.
Caption information source: Charles T. Hommel, A Guide to Historical Photograph Collections in Seattle, p. 33 Caption information source: "The Indian and His Point of View," by Katherine McCurdy, The Westerner, Vol. IV, No. 5, April 1906.
rdf:Description.dc:source: McCurdy Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Makah woman drying fish on a rack, Neah Bay, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCurdy, James G.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Makah Indians--Women; Makah Indians--Subsistence activities; Makah Indians--Clothing & dress; Women--Washington (State)--Neah Bay; Fish drying--Washington (State)--Neah Bay; Salmon--Drying; Halibut--Drying
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
Halibut and salmon, the staples of the diet of Indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest, were either dried or smoked for winter use. In this photograph taken at Neah Bay, a Makah woman dries thinly-sliced fish in the sun. The scarecrows on the ends of the racks were intended to frighten away hungry birds.
The photographer, James McCurdy, was born in Port Townsend in 1872. He spent many years of his childhood in Neah Bay on the Makah reservation and returned to Port Townsend in 1894.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two Makah basketmakers, Neah Bay, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCurdy, James G.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Makah Indians--Women; Makah Indians--Arts & crafts; Makah Indians--Clothing & dress; Women--Washington (State)--Neah Bay; Basket making--Washington (State)--Neah Bay
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
These Makah women of Neah Bay demonstrate the distinctive lidded baskets, sometimes called "trinket baskets," for which the Makah are well-known. The bundled grass, which can be woven over a foundation of cedar bark, can be dyed various colors or left its natural cream color. These baskets combine geometric with naturalistic designs, and some are so tightly woven they are watertight. The Makah traded among Native groups as well as to non-Native collectors.
The photographer, James McCurdy, was born in Port Townsend in 1872. He spent many years of his childhood in Neah Bay on the Makah reservation and returned to Port Townsend in 1894.
Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com Caption information source: "Northwest Coast Basketry," by Silvia Koros for the Burke Museum, retrieved from https://www.burkemuseum.org/static/baskets/Teachersguideforbasketry.htm. rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCurdy, James G.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Makah Indians--Women; Makah Indians--Children; Makah Indians--Clothing & dress; Women--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Children---Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Mothers & children--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Families---Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Dogs--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Blankets; Pets
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing and carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
Seated on the beach in front of a tent, probably at Port Townsend, a Makah woman and child hold a puppy for a portrait. Another woman seated next to the pair shields her face from the photographer. At least one surviving account from Port Townsend indicates that white photographers often photographed Indigenous people, and that some of the Indigenous subjects resented being photographed, asked for compensation, or attempted to avoid being photographed.
The photographer, James McCurdy, was born in Port Townsend in 1872. He spent many years of his childhood in Neah Bay on the Makah reservation and returned to Port Townsend in 1894.
Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com Caption information source: "The Indian and His Point of View," by Katherine McCurdy, The Westerner, Vol. IV, No. 5, April 1906. Caption information source: Charles T. Hommel, A Guide to Historical Photograph Collections in Seattle, p. 33
rdf:Description.dc:source: McCurdy Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Women shopping for baskets on the beach, Port Townsend, circa 1895
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCurdy, James G.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Commerce; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Women; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Clothing & dress; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Women---Washington (State)--Port Townsend
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
This photo, taken on the beach at Port Townsend, shows three white women examining baskets made by Indigenous people, whose canoes are landed nearby. One of the baskets is of finely-woven spruce root, the other is a coiled container of a style made in the interior of British Columbia. Baskets were traded among Native groups as well as to non-Native collectors.
The photographer, James McCurdy, was born in Port Townsend in 1872. He spent many years of his childhood in Neah Bay on the Makah reservation and returned to Port Townsend in 1894.
Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com Caption information source: "Northwest Coast Basketry," by Silvia Koros for the Burke Museum, retrieved from https://www.burkemuseum.org/static/baskets/Teachersguideforbasketry.htm. Caption information source: Charles T. Hommel, A Guide to Historical Photograph Collections in Seattle, p. 33
rdf:Description.dc:source: McCurdy Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Coast Salish canoe in Port Townsend Bay, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCurdy, James G.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Coast Salish Indians--Transportation; Canoes--Coast Salish Indians; Canoes-Washington (State)--Olympic Peninsula
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Coast Salish style canoe was designed for use in the calm waters of Puget Sound and its many small bays and inlets. Both the prow and the stern curve upwards from a rounded bottom. Salish canoes were often painted black with brightly colored figures near the prow and stern. The Coast Salish style of canoe was more lightly constructed than other canoes built by Indigenous peoples and was not suited for longer voyages or in rough waters. It was also not as useful for fishing, carrying cargo, or raiding and as a result the style was gradually replaced by the more robust West Coast style of canoe, originally built by the Nuu-Chah-Nulth of Vancouver Island.
This image shows a Coast Salish style canoe piloted by an Indigenous person in Port Townsend Bay on the Olympic Peninsula. A few other watercraft are visible in the right background, including a sailing ship and a steamship. The Klallam (also spelled S'Klallam), a Coast Salish group, lived in and around Port Townsend and the subject of this image may be a Klallam.
The photographer, James McCurdy, was born in Port Townsend in 1872. He spent many years of his childhood in Neah Bay on the Makah reservation and returned to Port Townsend in 1894.
Caption information source: Caption information source: "Northwest Coast Canoes," Simon Fraser University, retrieved from https://www.sfu.ca/brc/art_architecture/canoes.html. Caption information source: Charles T. Hommel, A Guide to Historical Photograph Collections in Seattle, p. 33
rdf:Description.dc:source: McCurdy Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: West Coast style canoe with two sails, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCurdy, James G.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Olympic Peninsula--Transportation; Canoes--Indians of North America; Canoes-Washington (State)--Olympic Peninsula; Beaches-Washington (State)--Olympic Peninsula; Sails--Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description:
By the turn of the 20th century, Indigenous seafarers adapted cloth sails, usually of the sprit-rig type seen in this image. Traditional sails of woven mats and wood slats had been used prior to the arrival of Europeans, but they were replaced by cloth once the Native peoples began trading with the settlers.
This photograph was probably taken in Port Townsend Bay or along the Strait of Juan de Fuca. It shows a West Coast style canoe equipped with a European style sail. The West Coast style of canoe was originally developed by the Nuu-Chah-Nulth peoples of Vancouver Island. It had a flatter bottom than other canoe styles and a vertical stern, making it more stable in rougher waters and able to carry more cargo. As a result, West Coast style canoes became the most common style in the Pacific Northwest during the late 19th century.
The photographer, James McCurdy, was born in Port Townsend in 1872. He spent many years of his childhood in Neah Bay on the Makah reservation and returned to Port Townsend in 1894.
Caption information source: "Northwest Coast Canoes," Simon Fraser University, retrieved from https://www.sfu.ca/brc/art_architecture/canoes.html. Caption information source: Charles T. Hommel, A Guide to Historical Photograph Collections in Seattle, p. 33
rdf:Description.dc:source: McCurdy Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indigenous women picking hops, Snoqualmie Hop Ranch, circa 1895
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Soule, John P.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Snoqualmie Hop Ranch (Wash.) ; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Employment; Hops--Washington (State)--Snoqualmie; Harvesting--Washington (State)--Snoqualmie; Agricultural laborers--Washington (State)--Snoqualmie; Agricultural laborers--Indians of North America--Washington (State); Women--Washington (State)--Employment; Brewing industry--Washington (State)--Snoqualmie; Baskets.
rdf:Description.dc:description:
From the late 1860s to the early 1890s, hop farming was an important activity in the valleys of the Puget Sound region, including Puyallup, White River, and Snoqualmie. Indigenous workers came from throughout the Pacific Northwest, Canada, and Alaska (but especially from regional tribes like the Puyallup, Snoqualmie, Muckleshoot, Duwamish, Sammamish, Lummi, and Nisqually) as a seasonal labor force to harvest these crops in late summer and early autumn. This seasonal work gave them a chance to earn the money they needed to buy things in a cash economy.
In this 1890s photo, taken at Snoqualmie Hop Ranch in western Washington state, two Indigenous women stand in a hop field holding traditional cedar bark baskets. Other baskets filled with the pale hop blossoms sit on the ground in the background (right).
Caption on image: "Indian hop pickers at Snoqualmie Hop Ranch"
Caption information source: "Indigenous Hop Pickers in Western Washington" by Hans Zeiger, HistoryLink.org Essay 21295.
rdf:Description.dc:type: Safety film negatives; image; photograph StillImage

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pat Kanim, Snoqualmie Chief, circa 1855
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Moore, George N.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Kanim, Pat (Snoqualmie Indian); Tribal chiefs--United States; Snoqualmie Indians--Clothing & dress
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Snoqualmie people are a Coast Salish group who have lived in the Snoqualmie River Valley since time immemorial. They made dugout canoes which they used to navigate the river and reach Puget Sound. Traditionally the Snoqualmie burned off the bottom lands of the Snoqualmie Valley to create open areas that ensured an abundance of edible plants for foraging as well as supplied space for game animals to feed. In the early 19th century, the Snoqualmie were among the most powerful tribes around Puget Sound. They exerted economic influence over neighboring groups from Whidbey Island to Snoqualmie Pass. The Snoqualmie signed the Treaty of Point Elliott in 1855, ceding their land to the United States. They were temporarily assigned to live on the Tulalip reservation and were promised a reservation of their own. However, the US government reneged on its promise and no land was allocated for the Snoqualmie, most of whom moved back to their historic lands or stayed on the Tulalip reservation. The Snoqualmie finally received a reservation on their historic land in 1999.
This image is a portrait of Patkanim (or Pat Kanim), the chief of the Snoqualmie and Snohomish in the mid 19th century. In the 1840s, he wanted to force out the early white settlers. However, after visiting San Francisco in 1850, Patkanim decided that any fight against the settlers would be hopeless. He signed the Treaty of Point Elliott in 1855 and aided the settlers against other Indigenous groups in the war of 1855-1856. Patkanim died in 1858 on the Tulalip Reservation.
Photographer George N. Moore copied this portrait in the 1880s from an earlier photograph of Patkanim.
Caption information source: "Historic Overview: Carnation, Washington," by Christine Palmer, King County Cultural Resources Division, retrieved from: https://web.archive.org/web/20050519084000/http://www.ci.carnation.wa.us/library/carnation-historical-context.pdf Caption information source: "Chief Patkanim," by Edmond Meany, Washington Historical Quarterly, Vol XV, No. 2, July 1924, retrieved from: https://journals.lib.washington.edu/index.php/WHQ/issue/view/493.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Historical Society Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Industrial Boarding School buildings on the Puyallup Reservation, circa 1885
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hadley, U.P. (Urban Pope)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Industrial Boarding School (Puyallup Indian Reservation, Wash.); Schools--Washington (State)--Puyallup Indian Reservation; Students--Washington (State)--Puyallup Indian Reservation; School children--Washington (State)--Puyallup Indian Reservation; Indians of North America--Washington Territory--Education
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Puyallup people are a Coast Salish group whose historic lands are along the Puyallup River Valley. They call themselves "Spuyalepabs" in their native language of Lushootseed, meaning "people from the bend at the bottom of the river." Before settlers arrived, the Puyallup lived in villages that spread from the Cascade foothills to the shores of Puget Sound. In 1854, Puyallup leaders signed the Medicine Creek Treaty under duress. The Puyallup ceded most of their land to the US in this treaty, but due to US government treaty violations in the size and location of reservations, the Puyallup peoples joined what is now called the Puget Sound War in 1855-1856. After the war ended, the treaty was renegotiated and the Puyallup reservation was enlarged. Since then, the Puyallup have fought for tribal rights, including in the fish wars of the 1960s and 70s and the Puyallup Land Claims Settlement in 1990.
Starting in the middle of the 19th century, church groups and the United States government set up boarding schools for Indigenous children. Here, children from many tribes were taught to speak English and were educated with a focus on agriculture and manual skills. They were separated from their elders, discouraged from learning their tribal traditions, and punished for speaking languages other than English. This photo shows the buildings and students of the Puyallup Indian School on the Puyallup Reservation, sometime between 1880 and 1889. The Puyallup Indian School opened in 1860 but expanded in the 1880s and 1890s, when a number of new buildings were added, and the school grew from 125 to more than 350 pupils. Later called the Industrial Boarding School and the Cushman School, it remained open until 1920. By that time, most Indigenous children attended local public schools.
Caption on image: "Indian scholars at the Industrial Boarding School, Puyallup Reservation, W.T." ; "Views of Tacoma, Etc." Part of Hadley series "Views of Tacoma, Etc." Caption information source: "Puyallup Tribe: The Story of Our People," Puyallup Tribe of Indians, retrieved from http://puyallup-tribe.com/ourtribe/. Caption information source: "Assimilation Through Education: Indian Boarding Schools in the Pacific Northwest," by Carolyn Marr, retrieved from https://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/marr.html.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Historical Society Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pilchuck Julia, Snohomish, 1915
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Douglas, William
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pilchuck Julia (Snohomish Indian); Snohomish Indians--Women; Women--Washington (State)--Snohomish; Aged persons--Washington (State)--Snohomish
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Snohomish (written Sduhubš in their language) are a Coast Salish people who have lived along the Snohomish River since time immemorial. Their largest village was Hibulb, near the mouth of the river in what is now Everett. Like their other Coast Salish neighbors, the Snohomish used dugout canoes to travel along rivers and around Puget Sound. Salmon fishing was important to the Snohomish, both for sustenance and for cultural reasons. In 1855, Snohomish leaders signed the Treaty of Point Elliott. They ceded land to the United States but reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. The Snohomish were temporarily assigned to live on the Tulalip reservation and were promised their own reservation. However, the US government later reneged on this promise and most Snohomish people remained on the Tulalip reservation. As of 2023, the Snohomish are not a federally-recognized tribe.
Pilchuck Julia, of the Snohomish people, was born around 1840 and witnessed the signing of the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott. After the treaty, she and her husband Pilchuck Jack stayed at their home on the Pilchuck River, near the town of Snohomish, Washington. Pilchuck Julia supported the family by making baskets and by selling clams, salmon, and berries. She was also known for her accurate weather predictions. During her lifetime, Julia was a much-photographed figure. Pilchuck Julia died of smallpox in 1923 and is buried in the G.A.R. Cemetery in Snohomish. The Pilchuck Julia Boat Landing in Snohomish was named in her honor in 2017.
Caption on image: "Pilchuck Julia, [copyright] 1915 by Wm. Douglas."
Caption information source: Snohomish Tribe of Indians, About Us, retrieved from: https://snohomishtribe.org/about Caption information source: "Snohomish County – Thumbnail History," by Margaret Riddle, HistoryLink, retrieved from https://www.historylink.org/file/7877 Caption information source: "City of Snohomish officially names boat landing in honor of Pilchuck Julia," by Kim Kalliber, Tulalip News, retrieved from https://www.tulalipnews.com/wp/2019/08/28/city-of-snohomish-officially-names-boat-landing-in-honor-of-pilchuck-julia/
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Historical Society Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Wako (Coast Salish Indian); Coast Salish Indians--Structures; Coast Salish Indians--Domestic life; Healers--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quileute children and teachers, La Push, circa 1887
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Smith, David T.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Smith, A.W. (Indian agent at La Push, Wash.); Smith, A.W., Mrs. (Wife of Indian agent at La Push, Wash.); Quileute Indians--Children; School children--Washington (State)--La Push; Students--Washington (State)--La Push; Schools--Washington (State)--La Push
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Quileute are an Indigenous people whose historic lands are on the west side of the Olympic Peninsula, in the valleys of the Quillayute and Hoh Rivers. The Quileute are not related to either the Makah to the north or the Coast Salish peoples of western Washington, and the Quileute language is unrelated to any other in the world. Quileute land is directly exposed to the Pacific Ocean and receives about 9.5 feet of average yearly rainfall. To protect themselves, the Quileute made rainproof hats and clothing using the inner layer of cedar bark. The Quileute signed the Treaty of Olympia in 1856, in which they ceded their land and agreed to move to a reservation. In the treaty, the Quileute reserved rights for hunting, fishing, and gathering at all usual and accustomed places. However, because their land was so remote, reservations were not established until 1889 and 1893. Today, most Quileutes live on either the Quileute or the Hoh reservations.
In 1882, A.W. Smith established a school on Quileute land. He renamed Quileute individuals after Biblical characters and figures from US history. Seven years later Smith would become the "Indian agent" when the Quileute reservation was established. In this photo, Smith (left center) and his wife (right) pose with a group of Quileute school children next to a recently-built structure which may be the school.
Caption information source: "History", Quileute Nation, retrieved from https://quileutenation.org/history/#.
rdf:Description.dc:type: silver gelatin print; photograph; image StillImage
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Historical Society Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quileute Indians in a western Washington hop field, 1904
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Kilburn, B.W.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Quileute Indians--Employment; Quileute Indians--Women; Quileute Indians--Children; Hops--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Agricultural laborers--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Women--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Children--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Child laborers--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Brewing industry--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Quileute are an Indigenous people whose historic lands are on the west side of the Olympic Peninsula, in the valleys of the Quillayute and Hoh Rivers. The Quileute are not related to either the Makah to the north or the Coast Salish peoples of western Washington and the Quileute language is unrelated to any other in the world. Quileute land is directly exposed to the Pacific Ocean and receives about 9.5 feet of average yearly rainfall. To protect themselves, the Quileute made rainproof hats and clothing using the inner layer of cedar bark. The Quileute signed the Treaty of Olympia in 1856, in which they ceded their land and agreed to move to a reservation. In the treaty, the Quileute reserved rights for hunting, fishing, and gathering at all usual and accustomed places. However, because their land was so remote, reservations were not established until 1889 and 1893. Today, most Quileutes live on either the Quileute or the Hoh reservations.
From the late 1860s to the early 1890s, hop farming was an important activity in the valleys of the Puget Sound region, including Puyallup, White River, and Snoqualmie. Indigenous workers came from throughout the Pacific Northwest, Canada, and Alaska as a seasonal labor force to harvest crops in late summer and early autumn. Some Quileute people traveled all the way from the west coast of Washington's Olympic Peninsula to Puget Sound to pick hops. They relied on wages from seasonal labor to purchase goods in the currency-based economy of settlers. In 1889, a settler burned down the Quileute village of La Push while the inhabitants were away picking hops. The fire destroyed many of the last remaining masks, baskets, hunting equipment, and sacred items from before contact with the settlers.
This image shows a group of Quileute people posing for a photo in a hop field. Woven baskets to carry the hops can be seen in the foreground. This image is a stereograph – two nearly identical images printed together to produce a 3D effect when seen through a special viewer.
Caption on image: "Quillayute Indians in the hop fields, Puget Sound, Wash." ; "Copyright 1904, by B.W. Kilburn." No. 16055 in untitled series of views published by James M. Davis, New York City, and St. Louis, Mo.
Caption information source: "History", Quileute Nation, retrieved from https://quileutenation.org/history/#.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Historical Society Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Game of slahal on a Puget Sound beach, circa 1884
rdf:Description.dc:creator: King, C.E.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Gambling--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region--Social life
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Slahal, also called the bone game, is one of many games played by Indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest. A team member held up their hands, each of which contained a small bone, and the members of the opposite team tried to guess if a marked bone was in the right or left hand. Slahal often also involved gambling between the teams. Stakes could be high, and the games might last for hours.
In this photo, taken sometime before Washington became a state in 1889, a group of Indigenous people play the bone game near their beached canoes. The two teams sit opposite one another in the sand. Some team members hold sticks which are used for scoring and for keeping up a rhythmic beat.
Caption on image: "Indians gambling, Puget Sound, W.T." ; "Washington Territory and Oregon Views." Part of series entitled: "Washington Territory and Oregon Views"
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Historical Society Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Steilacoom John and Annie, circa 1905
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Blosser, J.A.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Steilacoom John; Annie; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Steilacoom Region; Spouses--Washington (State)--Steilacoom Region; Steilacoom Indians; Group portraits
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Steilacoom are a Coast Salish people whose historic lands are near the current town of Steilacoom, southwest of Tacoma. The Steilacoom consisted of five bands: Steilacoom, Sastuck, Spanaway, Tilhlow, and Segwallitchew. Unlike many of their neighbors the Steilacoom did not live near a glacier-fed river, but on land featuring a group of lakes and creeks. The Steilacoom were affected by settlers earlier than most other Indigenous peoples in Washington. Settlers encroached on their land starting in the 1830s, and the first incorporated town north of the Columbia River was in Steilacoom territory. In 1854, Steilacoom leaders signed the Medicine Creek Treaty and ceded their land to the United States. The US government expected Steilacoom land to be heavily populated with settlers and so did not assign the Steilacoom a reservation. Instead, the Steilacoom were assigned to live on neighboring reservations. Many refused to leave, however, and have remained on their historic lands. The Steilacoom Tribe is not federally recognized.
Steilacoom John was a leader of the Steilacoom Tribe and a son of Ce-col-quin, a signer of the 1854 Medicine Creek Treaty. In this photograph, John and his wife Goe-lit-sah (also called Anna or Annie) are seated in front of their home with a basket and other household items. This image is a stereograph – two nearly identical images printed together to produce a 3D effect when seen through a special viewer. A caption on the image describes John and Annie as "Siwash Indians." The term "Siwash" was once used as a general term for Indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest, but it is now considered derogatory.
Caption on image: "Steilacoom John and Annie. (Siwash Indians)" ; "Views of the Cascade Mountains, Puget Sound, and the Pacific Northwest." ; "Copyrighted, 1905, by J.A. Blosser, Snohomish, Wash."
Caption information source: "Steilacoom Tribe History," retrieved from http://steilacoomtribe.blogspot.com/2009/01/history.html. Caption information source: "Summary under the criteria and evidence for proposed finding Steilacoom Tribe of Indians," Bureau of Indian Affairs, retrieved from https://www.bia.gov/sites/default/files/dup/assets/as-ia/ofa/petition/011_steila_WA/011_pf.pdf
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Historical Society Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indigenous canoes docked at the Seattle waterfront, circa 1892
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Canoes--Indians of North America; Canoes--Washington (State)--Seattle; Camping--Washington (State)--Seattle; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Transportation; Dwellings--Washington (State)--Seattle; Waterfronts--Washington (State)--Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:description:
In 1865 the Board of Trustees of Seattle passed Ordinance No. 5 banning Indigenous people from living in the city unless they worked for a non-Indigenous resident and lived on their employer’s property. Despite this attempt to enforce separation between Indigenous people and the settlers, Seattle depended on Indigenous people. Settlers relied on Native people for domestic work and for trade of fish, shellfish, and baskets. Indigenous people from across the Pacific Northwest also harvested hops in agricultural areas to the south and east of Seattle.
Because they were excluded from the rest of the city, many Indigenous people stayed on Ballast Island, either when passing through, temporarily stopping, or living on the island year-round. Ballast Island was in the harbor at the foot of Washington Street and was created when sailing ships dumped their ballast in Elliott Bay in order to take on cargo. The only place close to Seattle’s business district where Indigenous people were allowed to live, Ballast Island lacked a source of fresh water or permanent structures. As the waterfront grew in the 1890s, Ballast Island was gradually covered and by the time the seawall was built in 1916, the island was almost completely gone and its Indigenous residents had again been displaced.
This image shows several canoes moored at Ballast Island, with an encampment visible on the island and the growing cityscape in the background.
Caption on image: "Indian canoes"
Caption information source: "Exile to Ballast Island," Duwamish Tribe, retrieved from https://www.duwamishtribe.org/exile-to-ballast-island Caption information source: "Seattle Board of Trustees passes ordinance, calling for removal of Indians from the town, on February 7, 1865," by Jennifer Ott, HistoryLink essay #10979, retrieved from https://www.historylink.org/file/10979
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Historical Society Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indigenous encampment at the Seattle waterfront, circa 1895
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Canoes--Indians of North America; Canoes----Washington (State)--Seattle; Camping--Washington (State)--Seattle; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Transportation; Dwellings--Washington (State)--Seattle; Waterfronts--Washington (State)--Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:description:
In 1865 the Board of Trustees of Seattle passed Ordinance No. 5 banning Indigenous people from living in the city unless they worked for a non-Indigenous resident and lived on their employer’s property. Despite this attempt to enforce separation between Indigenous people and the settlers, Seattle depended on Indigenous people. Settlers relied on Native people for domestic work and for trade of fish, shellfish, and baskets. Indigenous people from across the Pacific Northwest also harvested hops in agricultural areas to the south and east of Seattle.
Because they were excluded from the rest of the city, many Indigenous people stayed on Ballast Island, either when passing through, temporarily stopping, or living on the island year-round. Ballast Island was in the harbor at the foot of Washington Street and was created when sailing ships dumped their ballast in Elliott Bay in order to take on cargo. The only place close to Seattle’s business district where Indigenous people were allowed to live, Ballast Island lacked a source of fresh water or permanent structures. As the waterfront grew in the 1890s, Ballast Island was gradually covered and by the time the seawall was built in 1916, the island was almost completely gone and its Indigenous residents had again been displaced.
This image shows canoes beached on Ballast Island, a few of them converted into tents. Dugout shelters are also visible behind the canoes.
Caption information source: "Exile to Ballast Island," Duwamish Tribe, retrieved from https://www.duwamishtribe.org/exile-to-ballast-island Caption information source: "Seattle Board of Trustees passes ordinance, calling for removal of Indians from the town, on February 7, 1865," by Jennifer Ott, HistoryLink essay #10979, retrieved from https://www.historylink.org/file/10979

rdf:Description.dc:title: Jim Yellakanim, Nooksack chief, circa 1898
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hadley, U.P. (Urban Pope)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Yellakanim, Jim (Nooksack Indian); Tribal chiefs--United States; Photographic studios--Washington (State); Portrait photographs
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Nooksack are a Coast Salish people whose historic lands centered on the Nooksack River drainage basin, from the shore to around Mount Baker in the east. They have their own language, also named Nooksack. On the edges of Nooksack land and in offshore waters, resources were shared with neighboring peoples, to whom the Nooksack were linked by shared descent or marriage ties. The Nooksack were party to the Treaty of Point Elliott in 1855 and ceded their land in exchange for fishing, hunting, and gathering rights but the Nooksack did not receive a reservation. Many Nooksack refused to leave their homes and in the 1870s, they claimed homesteads on their historic land. The Nooksack tribe received a small reservation in 1970 and was federally recognized in 1973. Today, many of the 2,000 Nooksack tribal members live near their historic lands and continue to fish, both for income and to maintain cultural practices.
"Jim" Yellakanim Seclamatan was a leader of the Nooksack people. He claimed a homestead in the upper Nooksack Valley, just outside the town of Lynden, Washington. Yellakanim died in April 1911 at the age of nearly 100 at the home of his granddaughter, Emily Williams.
Caption on image: "Jim, Chief of the Nooksacks"
Caption information source: "About Us," Nooksack Indian Tribe, retrieved from https://nooksacktribe.org/about/. Caption information source: "Aged Nooksack chief passes to happy hunting ground," Bellingham Herald, Apr. 27, 1911, p. 1. Caption information source: "John and Clara Tennant," Center for Pacific Northwest Studies, retrieved from https://west.wwu.edu/cpnws/centennial/people/tennant.html.

rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Nooksack are a Coast Salish people whose historic lands centered on the Nooksack River drainage basin, from the shore to around Mount Baker in the east. They have their own language, also named Nooksack. On the edges of Nooksack land and in offshore waters, resources were shared with neighboring peoples, to whom the Nooksack were linked by shared descent or marriage ties. The Nooksack were party to the Treaty of Point Elliott in 1855 and ceded their land in exchange for fishing, hunting, and gathering rights but the Nooksack did not receive a reservation. Many Nooksack refused to leave their homes and in the 1870s, they claimed homesteads on their historic land. The Nooksack tribe received a small reservation in 1970 and was federally recognized in 1973. Today, many of the 2,000 Nooksack tribal members live near their historic lands and continue to fish, both for income and to maintain cultural practices.
In this photo, taken around 1900, several Nooksack people pose with a non-Indigenous man in front of a building near Lynden, a small town in Whatcom County on historic Nooksack land.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cheholtz family in front of fishing shack, near Castle Rock, Washington, circa 1885
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hadley, U.P. (Urban Pope)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Cheholtz, Kathleen, Cheholtz, Elisha; Cheholtz, john, Cheholtz, Peter, Cheholtz, Lemmea; Cheholtz, Henry; Cowlitz Indian Tribe, Washington; Cowlitz Indian Tribe, Washington--Clothing; Fishing shanties--Washington (State)--Cowlitz County
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Cowlitz People are a Coast Salish group whose historic lands are along the Cowlitz and Lewis Rivers, in what is now southwestern Washington. Traditionally, the annual cycle of resource gathering determined where the Cowlitz People traveled and at what time of year – from river fishing in the spring, gathering roots and berries in summer and fall, and making crafts and repairing nets in the winter to prepare for the next spring. In 1855, Cowlitz leaders left negotiations with the Washington territorial government when the government required them to abandon their homeland in exchange for a reservation on the coast, to be shared with the other Indigenous peoples of southwestern Washington. The Cowlitz signed no treaty with the United States, but after the Puget Sound War of 1855-56, the Cowlitz’s land was taken by the US and sold to settlers. Many Cowlitz people remained in their historic lands and maintained their tribal ties to each other through the 20th century. The Cowlitz Indian Tribe was federally recognized in 2000 and the Cowlitz reservation was established near Ridgefield, Washington in 2010.
This image shows the Cheholtz family, from the Toutle River band of the Cowlitz people. From left to right: Kathleen Cheholtz, Elisha Cheholtz, John Cheholtz, Peter Cheholtz (seated), Lemmea Cheholtz, and Henry Cheholtz. The man wearing a hat standing behind Peter is unidentified. Henry was the chief of the Toutle River band and Kathleen and Lemmea were his wives. The Cheholtz family lived on the banks of the Cowlitz River near the town of Castle Rock and this photo was taken in front of a fishing shack as they returned home.
Caption information source: Email exchange with Clarence Koch, descendant of the Cheholtz family, November 2022 Caption information source: "Cultural Resources Department," Cowlitz Indian Tribe, retrieved from https://www.cowlitz.org/services/cultural-resources.html Caption information source: "That the People May Live: The Cowlitz Tribe’s Journey of Peace and Justice," by Eugene A. Wiggins, Journal of Pacific Rim Psychology, 1(2), page 44-53, retrieved from https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1375/prp.1.2.44 Caption information source: "Castle Rock," by Vicki Selander, Arcadia Publishing, page 10

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quileutes landing provisions at La Push, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Nowell, F.H. (Frank H.)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Quileute Indians--Transportation; Quileute Indians--Subsistence activities; Canoes--Quileute Indians; Canoes--Washington (State)--La Push; Beaches--Washington (State)--La Push
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Quileute are an Indigenous people whose historic lands are on the west side of the Olympic Peninsula, in the valleys of the Quillayute and Hoh Rivers. The Quileute are not related to either the Makah to the north or the Coast Salish peoples of western Washington, and the Quileute language is unrelated to any other in the world. Quileute land is directly exposed to the Pacific Ocean and receives about 9.5 feet of average yearly rainfall. To protect themselves, the Quileute made rainproof hats and clothing using the inner layer of cedar bark. The Quileute signed the Treaty of Olympia in 1856, in which they ceded their land and agreed to move to a reservation. In the treaty, the Quileute reserved rights for hunting, fishing, and gathering at all usual and accustomed places. However, because their land was so remote, reservations were not established until 1889 and 1893. Today, most Quileutes live on either the Quileute or the Hoh reservations.
Because Quileute land was distant from road or rail connections, the Quileute obtained supplies by loading up their large sea-going canoes. In this photo, a group unloads large sacks at First Beach, which borders the village of La Push. The canoes are of the West Coast style with an upturned prow and a vertical stern. The caption written on the image misidentifies the location as Mora, which is slightly up the Quillayute River from La Push.
Caption on image: "Indians landing provisions at Mora, Washington"
Caption information source: "History", Quileute Nation, retrieved from https://quileutenation.org/history/#. Caption information from Jay Powell and Vickie Jensen, Quileute: An Introduction to the Indians of La Push, n.p. Nearby Mora is not directly on the beach.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indigenous men, women and children working in hop field, Kent, circa 1895
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Anderson, O.P. (Oliver Phelps)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultural laborers--Indians of North America; Agricultural laborers--Washington (State)--Kent; Baskets.; Brewing industry--Washington (State)--Kent; Harvesting----Washington (State)--Kent; Hops--Washington (State)--Kent; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Kent--Employment
rdf:Description.dc:description:
From the late 1860s to the early 1890s, hop farming was an important activity in the valleys of the Puget Sound region, including Puyallup, White River, and Snoqualmie. Indigenous workers came from throughout the Pacific Northwest, Canada, and Alaska (but especially from regional tribes like the Puyallup, Snoqualmie, Muckleshoot, Duwamish, Sammamish, Lummi, and Nisqually) as a seasonal labor force to harvest these crops in late summer and early autumn. This seasonal work gave them a chance to earn the money they needed to buy things in a cash economy.
Many Native families traveled to the hop fields where they camped out during the harvest. Some returned to the same hop fields each year, and this became an important social event. Schools were closed during the harvest so that children could help in the fields. This photo, probably from the 1890s, shows Indigenous men, women, and children at work in a hop field near Kent, Washington. The dried blossoms of the hop plant, called cones, fill the large baskets in the foreground.
Caption on image: "Indian hop pickers at Kent."
Caption information source: "Indigenous Hop Pickers in Western Washington" by Hans Zeiger, HistoryLink.org Essay 21295

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chief Chits-A-Man-Han and his wife, circa 1884
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chits-A-Man-Han; Klallam Indians--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Spouses--Washington (State)--Puget Sound Region; Tribal chiefs--United States; Group portraits
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The S’Klallam (also spelled Klallam) are a Coast Salish people whose historic lands stretch across the northern Olympic Peninsula from the current location of Port Townsend to the Hoko River, near Makah lands. They also lived on Whidbey Island and on the south shore of Vancouver Island. The S’Klallam lived in permanent longhouses during the winter, but in other seasons individual families spread out and camped at traditional sites to fish, hunt, or gather resources. In 1855, the S’Klallam signed the Point No Point Treaty and ceded their land to the United States but reserved rights to hunt, fish, and gather at usual and accustomed sites. The treaty stated that the S’Klallam would move to a reservation at Skokomish, but this site was distant from their traditional lands and most S’Klallams refused to leave. Beginning in the 1870s, many S’Klallam individuals privately purchased land on their traditional territory. As a result, separate S’Klallam groups emerged, which last to this day. One of the tribes lives on Vancouver Island at Becher Bay. The other three are on the northern Olympic Peninsula – the Lower Elwha Klallam Tribe (federally recognized in 1939), the Port Gamble S’Klallam Tribe (federally recognized in 1936), and the Jamestown S’Klallam Tribe (federally recognized in 1981).
This is a portrait of Chits-A-Man-Han (nicknamed the “Duke of York” by the settlers) and his wife. He was chief of the S’Klallam in the 1850s and was one of the signers of the Point No Point Treaty. This image is a composite, created by combining separate photos of Chits-A-Man-Han and his wife.
Caption information source: “Elwha Klallam Historical Timeline,” Lower Elwha Klallam Tribe, retrieved from https://www.elwha.org/culture-history/elwha-klallam-historical-timeline/ Caption information source: “History,” by Jerry Gorsline, Port Gamble S’Klallam Tribe, retrieved from https://www.pgst.nsn.us/land-and-people-and-lifestyle/history Caption information source: “Jamestown S’Klallam Tribe Introduction and Overview,” Jamestown S’Klallam Tribe, retrieved from https://library.jamestowntribe.org/ld.php?content_id=47309688"

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chesheeahud and others in a canoe on Lake Union, Seattle, circa 1885
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chodups John; Duwamish Indians--Washington (State)--Seattle; Duwamish Indians--Transportation; Canoes--Duwamish Indians; Canoes--Coast Salish Indians; Canoes--Washington (State)--Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Chesheeahud (also spelled Cheshiahud) was a Duwamish chief and guide to the lakes and rivers around what is now Seattle, living between the mid-19th and early 20th centuries. He led a village called hehs-KWEE-kweel (meaning Skate), at the south edge of the mouth of Union Bay onto Lake Washington. hehs-KWEE-kweel was near a vital portage used by the Duwamish between Lake Union and Lake Washington. Chesheeahud and his wife Tleebuleetsa lived on a plot of land located at Edgewater Park near the point at the south edge of the mouth of Union Bay onto Lake Washington. They were the last Duwamish people to live on Lake Union as the city grew and dislocated the Indigenous residents. Because of this, the settlers often called them the "last of the Lake Union Indians." Chesheeahud was also called "Lake Union John" and the derogatory name "Chudups (also spelled Chodups) John" by the settlers, while Tleebuleetsa was called "Madeline." After Tleebuleetsa died, Chesheeahud moved to the Port Madison reservation, where many other Duwamish people had been displaced to after the Treaty of Point Elliott in 1855.
In this photo, Chesheeahud and several other people sit in a canoe on Lake Union. A mast sticks out beyond the vessel's notched prow. These canoes carried enough supplies to last for journeys lasting several months and could travel far inland on the many rivers in the region. This Coast Salish canoe design was later replaced by the West Coast style through contact with tribes from the Olympic Peninsula and Vancouver Island.
Caption information source: "Chesheeahud," Duwamish Tribe, retrieved from https://www.duwamishtribe.org/cheshiahud
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Historical Society Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indigenous woman and canoe at the Seattle waterfront, 1898
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Anderson, O.P. (Oliver Phelps)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Baskets; Canoes--Indians of North America--British Columbia; Canoes--Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Seattle; Hats; Indians of North America--British Columbia--Women; Indians of North America--British Columbia--Clothing & dress; Indians of North America--British Columbia--Arts & crafts; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Seattle--Women
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Indigenous people from many parts of the Pacific Northwest came to Seattle to trade and buy supplies. In this photo, a woman holding a basket stands by a large canoe at the Seattle waterfront. The design of the canoe and her hat suggest that she is from one of the First Nations in Vancouver Island or another part of coastal Canada. Her canoe is of the Northern style, designed for long journeys in open water. It has a high prow, flared sides, and a rounded bottom to help with speed and buoyancy. The photo was taken in Seattle, two blocks south of King Street, near First Avenue.
Caption information source: "Canoes, Lifeways, Waterways, " Simon Fraser University, retrieved from https://www.sfu.ca/archaeology/museum/exhibits/virtual-exhibits/canoes--lifeways--waterways.html

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Rutter, Thomas H.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Yakima Region--Clothing & dress; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Yakima Region--Children; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Children--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Blankets; Bags; Hats; Group photographs
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Indigenous peoples of the Columbia Plateau include many different tribal groups. The Plateau peoples’ historic lands are in what is now British Columbia, Washington, Idaho, Montana, and Oregon. In Washington, the Yakama, Nez Perce, Spokane, Colville, and other Plateau tribes live east of the Cascade Range in the Columbia River watershed.
In this image, a young man and woman dressed in European-style clothing pose for the camera in a Yakima-area photographer's studio. The woman wears a simple beaded necklace and carries a beaded bag with floral designs. The young man holds a woolen blanket and wears a dress shirt, elaborate necktie, and hat.
Caption information source: "Columbia River Indians," Columbia River Inter-Tribal Fish Commission, retrieved from https://critfc.org/for-kids-home/for-kids/indians-and-indian-tribes/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plateau group in a photography studio, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Rutter, Thomas H.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Yakima Region--Clothing & dress; Women--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Men--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Photographic studios--Washington (State)--Yakima; Group photographs
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Indigenous peoples of the Columbia Plateau include many different tribal groups. The Plateau peoples’ historic lands are in what is now British Columbia, Washington, Idaho, Montana, and Oregon. In Washington, the Yakama, Nez Perce, Spokane, Colville, and other Plateau tribes live east of the Cascade Range in the Columbia River watershed.
In this image, four Indigenous women and one man pose in the studio of a Yakima-area photographer around the turn of the 20th century. The two women on the right hold woven cornhusk bags, and one woman on the left carries a beaded bag. Also notable are their necklaces with large shell pendants, their shell earrings, and their beaded belts. The young man holds a gilded mirror and wears a woolen blanket around his waist. The large windows which provided light for the portrait would have been cropped out in the final copy.
Caption information source: "Columbia River Indians," Columbia River Inter-Tribal Fish Commission, retrieved from https://critfc.org/for-kids-home/for-kids/indians-and-indian-tribes/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Captain Billy and woman on horseback, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Rutter, Thomas H.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Captain Billy; Yakama Indians--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Yakama women--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Bags; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Horses--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Horseback riding--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Spouses--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Yakama Indians--Transportation; Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress; Wooden sidewalks--Washington (State)--Yakima Region
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Yakama (formerly spelled Yakima) people have lived in the Columbia River basin since time immemorial. During the winter, they lived in permanent villages built on the valley floor, where the climate was most temperate. Starting in spring, they traveled along the rivers and into the hills to gather food. Some gathered roots and berries, and others fished in rivers, especially the Columbia and the Yakima. In 1855, a confederation of 14 tribal groups signed the Yakama Nation Treaty with the United States and ceded most of their traditional lands, but reserved rights for hunting, gathering, and fishing at all usual and accustomed places. These groups were: Kah-miltpah, Palouse, Klickitat, See-ap-Cat, Klinquit, Sk-in-pah, Li-ay-was, Oche-Chotes, Wenatchapam, Pesquose, Yakama, Shyiks, Know-was-say-ee, and Wish-ham. All 14 groups are now part of the Confederated Tribes and Bands of the Yakama Nation and live on a reservation in central Washington.
This image taken by a Yakima-area photographer, shows a Yakama man identified as Captain Billy and a woman whose name is unknown, possibly his wife. Captain Billy wears animal skin decorations in his hair, and the woman carries a cornhusk bag on her horse's saddle. Both horses wear feathers on their bridles. Writing on the image describes the woman as a ""squaw."" This word is a sexist and racist slur used to refer to Indigenous North American women.
Caption on image: ""Captain Billy and squaw""
Caption information source: Yakama Nation, retrieved from https://www.yakama.com/about/
rdf:Description.dc:source: Dam Brothers Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plateau man with a dentalium necklace, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Rutter, Thomas H.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Men--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Yakima Region--Clothing & Dress; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Belts (Clothing); Necklaces; Blankets; Portrait photographs
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Indigenous peoples of the Columbia Plateau include many different tribal groups. The Plateau peoples’ historic lands are in what is now British Columbia, Washington, Idaho, Montana, and Oregon. In Washington, the Yakama, Nez Perce, Spokane, Colville, and other Plateau tribes live east of the Cascade Range in the Columbia River watershed.
In this portrait, part of a series taken in a Yakima-area photographer's studio, a young Indigenous man poses wearing a beaded belt, necklace, choker, armbands, and earrings. The large horn-shaped dentalium shells in his necklace came from the waters off Vancouver Island and were traded long distances to inland tribes. Traditionally, both men and women wore shell and bead ornaments. The dentalium shells were often interspersed with blue or red glass beads.
Caption information source: "Columbia River Indians," Columbia River Inter-Tribal Fish Commission, retrieved from https://critfc.org/for-kids-home/for-kids/indians-and-indian-tribes/

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Families--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Women--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Children--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Yakima Region--Women; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Yakima Region--Children; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Yakima Region--Clothing & dress; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Bags; Blankets; Group portraits
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Indigenous peoples of the Columbia Plateau include many different tribal groups. The Plateau peoples’ historic lands are in what is now British Columbia, Washington, Idaho, Montana, and Oregon. In Washington, the Yakama, Nez Perce, Spokane, Colville, and other Plateau tribes live east of the Cascade Range in the Columbia River watershed.
An Indigenous family poses for the camera of a Yakima-area photographer at the turn of the 20th century. The mother and infant wear cloth head coverings, and they carry a beaded bag with a running horse design. Floral designs were popular in the late 19th century, and designs featuring animals became more common in the early 20th century.
Caption information source: "Columbia River Indians," Columbia River Inter-Tribal Fish Commission, retrieved from https://critfc.org/for-kids-home/for-kids/indians-and-indian-tribes/
