rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Indigenous peoples of the Columbia Plateau include many different tribal groups. The Plateau peoples’ historic lands are in what is now British Columbia, Washington, Idaho, Montana, and Oregon. In Washington, the Yakama, Nez Perce, Spokane, Colville, and other Plateau tribes live east of the Cascade Range in the Columbia River watershed.
At the turn of the 20th century, this young Indigenous man posed for a Yakima-area photographer, holding a flute, in a pastoral scene with rocks and grass. The painted backdrop, with its trees and lake, contrasts with the subject's beaded shirt and leggings, woolen blanket, and feather-decorated hat.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cadina Chenoweth and an unidentified woman, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Rutter, Thomas H.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chenewith, Cadina (Yakama Indian); Women--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress; Yakama Indians--Women; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Blankets; Group portraits
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Indigenous peoples of the Columbia Plateau include many different tribal groups. The Plateau peoples’ historic lands are in what is now British Columbia, Washington, Idaho, Montana, and Oregon. In Washington, the Yakama, Nez Perce, Spokane, Colville, and other Plateau tribes live east of the Cascade Range in the Columbia River watershed.
Here, two Indigenous women pose for their portrait in a Yakima-area photographer's studio around 1900. The seated woman is identified as Cadina Chenoweth (1875-1940), daughter of Young Chief Chenoweth of the Mid-Columbia and Cascade Tribes. Her companion holds a beaded bag, which was a popular item among Indigenous people in the region at the time.
Caption information source: ""Columbia River Indians,"" Columbia River Inter-Tribal Fish Commission, retrieved from https://critfc.org/for-kids-home/for-kids/indians-and-indian-tribes/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mattie Spencer, Klikitat woman, circa 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Rutter, Thomas H.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Spencer, Mattie (Klikitat Indian); Women--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Yakama Indians--Women; Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Yakima Region; Bags; Blankets; Portrait photographs
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Klickitat (also spelled Klikitat) are an Indigenous group whose historic lands are along the Klickitat and White Salmon Rivers east of the Cascade mountains in Washington. Their language is related to the language of the Yakama, their eastern neighbors. The Klickitat fished for salmon in the rivers of their homeland and were also involved in trade among different Indigenous groups because of their convenient location near the Columbia River between Coast Salish tribes to the west and other tribes further east. In 1855, the Klickitat signed a treaty ceding their land to the United States while reserving rights to fish, hunt, and gather at all usual and accustomed places. The Klickitat were assigned to live on the Yakama reservation and today most Klickitats are part of the Confederated Tribes and Bands of the Yakama Nation.
This portrait of a young woman, identified by the subject's granddaughter as Mattie Spencer, is part of a series taken in a Yakima-area photography studio early in the 20th century. She holds a cornhusk bag with a typical geometric design and wears a patterned blanket, beaded belt, necklace and earrings.
Caption information source: "Western Oregon Klickitats," by Robert Boyd, R. Scott Byram, David Lewis, Oregon Encyclopedia, retrieved from https://www.oregonencyclopedia.org/articles/western_oregon_klickitats/#.Y2F9Z3bMKUk
rdf:Description.dc:source: Dam Brothers Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Unveiling the totem pole at Pioneer Square, Seattle, 1899
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tlingit Indians--Arts & Crafts; Crowds--Washington (State)--Seattle; Dedications--Washington (State)--Seattle; Totem poles--Alaska--Tongass; Totem poles--Washington (State)--Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:description:
This Tlingit totem was carved around 1790 to honor a tribal woman named Chief-of-All-Women and it was placed in the village of Tongass on the Alaska coast. In 1899, a group of leading Seattle businessmen on a goodwill tour of southeastern Alaska stole the totem and brought it back to Pioneer Square. The businessmen were indicted for the theft, but the case was later dismissed. The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, which sponsored the tour, eventually paid a $500 fine to the Tlingit Tribe. After rot and fire damaged the original pole in 1938, Tlingit craftsmen including several descendants of the carvers of the original pole, carved a replica and donated it to Seattle to replace the original.
In this photo, taken in October 1899, a large crowd has gathered for the dedication of the original totem pole.
Caption information source: "Seattle’s Totem Poles," by Viola Garfield, Thistle Press, 1996. Caption information source: "Stolen totem pole unveiled in Seattle's Pioneer Square on October 18, 1899," by David Wilma, HistoryLink, retrieved from https://www.historylink.org/File/2076
rdf:Description.dc:source: Wilse Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:description:
This Tlingit totem was carved around 1790 to honor a tribal woman named Chief-of-All-Women and it was placed in the village of Tongass on the Alaska coast. In 1899, a group of leading Seattle businessmen on a goodwill tour of southeastern Alaska stole the totem and brought it back to Pioneer Square. The businessmen were indicted for the theft, but the case was later dismissed. The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, which sponsored the tour, eventually paid a $500 fine to the Tlingit Tribe. After rot and fire damaged the original pole in 1938, Tlingit craftsmen including several descendants of the carvers of the original pole, carved a replica and donated it to Seattle to replace the original.
In this photo, the totem pole towers over a group of men waiting for the streetcar in Pioneer Square.

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Suquamish Indians--Washington (State)--Seattle; Couples--Washington (State)--Seattle; Aged persons--Washington (State)--Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:description: Although the photographers did not identify this couple or the location, it is possible that they are Suquamish, waiting in Seattle's federal courthouse. At approximately the same time, a group of Suquamish were photographed at Seattle's Colman Dock returning to the Port Madison Reservation, on Bainbridge Island, after trying to collect payments for land sold to the government.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hwehlchtid's house at low tide, Shilshole, circa 1903
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Salmon Bay Charlie--Homes & haunts; Duwamish Indians--Structures; Dwellings--Washington (State)--Seattle; Waterfronts--Washington (State)--Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Hwehlchtid (called Salmon Bay Charlie by the settlers) of the Shilshole people lived on the southern shore of Salmon Bay, near present-day Ballard, which was then outside of Seattle. Hwehlchtid and his wife Chilohleet'sa (Madeline) remained in their traditional homeland long after others of their tribe had moved away.
This photograph showing Hwehlchtid and Chilohleet’sa’s home, later made into a postcard, was taken at low tide looking west towards Puget Sound. In the early 20th century, Seattle boosters and businesses exploited images of Indigenous people and their culture for sale on postcards or in advertising in order to market the city.
Caption source information: "City of the Changers: Indigenous People and the Transformation of Seattle’s Watersheds," by Coll Thrush, Pacific Historical Review, (2006) Vol. 75, No. 1, pages 89–117, Accessed at http://web.mit.edu/people/spirn/Public/Granite%20Garden%20Research/Urban%20Environmental%20History/Thrush%202006%20Indigenous%20People%20Seattle.pdf
rdf:Description.dc:source: PEMCO Webster & Stevens Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Native camp on the beach, Seattle, circa 1885
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Levy, H.E.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indian encampments--Washington (State)--Seattle; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Seattle--Dwellings; Camping--Washington (State)--Seattle; Canoes--Indians of North America--Washington (State); Canoes--Washington (State)--Seattle; Beaches--Washington (State)--Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:description:
In 1865 the Board of Trustees of Seattle passed Ordinance No. 5 banning Indigenous people from living in the city unless they worked for a non-Indigenous resident and lived on their employer’s property. Despite this attempt to enforce separation between Indigenous people and the settlers, Seattle depended on Indigenous people. Settlers relied on Native people for domestic work and for trade of fish, shellfish, and baskets. Indigenous people from across the Pacific Northwest also harvested hops in agricultural areas to the south and east of Seattle.
This 1880s photo shows a Native encampment in Seattle, probably located near the western end of Bell Street. Because they were excluded from the rest of the city, many Indigenous people camped on the waterfront when visiting or passing through Seattle.
rdf:Description.dc:type: silver gelatin print; photograph; image StillImage
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Historical Society Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Jack Adams' racing canoe, Portage Bay, Seattle, 1909
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Adams, Jack (Suquamish Indian); Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition (1909 : Seattle, Wash.); Suquamish Indians--Sports; Canoes--Suquamish Indians; Canoes--Washington (State)--Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:description: In 1909, Jack Adams (1853-1931), a member of the Suquamish Tribe, built a canoe for a canoe race at Seattle's Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. Adams built the vessel from a single 48-foot log. On September 6, the canoes raced to the finish line at the foot of the fair's Pay Streak, in Portage Bay. In this photo, Adams and ten other men paddle the canoe on Portage Bay.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cayuse twin babies in cradleboards, October 2, 1898
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Moorhouse, Lee
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tax-a-Lax (Cayuse Indian); Alompum (Cayuse Indian); Cayuse Indians--Children; Cayuse Indians--Arts & crafts; Cradleboards; Children--Oregon--Pendleton Region; Twins--Oregon--Pendleton Region
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Cayuse people historically lived in the Blue Mountains of northeastern Oregon and southeastern Washington, where they fish from rivers that flow into the Columbia. They were in an advantageous position between the coast and the Great Plains, allowing them to trade between both. The Cayuse owned horses in large numbers, which led to their expansion and brought them into contact with tribes on the coast as well as further inland. In 1855, the Cayuse in confederation with the Walla Walla and the Umatilla peoples signed a treaty with the United States. The tribes ceded their land but reserved rights to hunt, fish, and gather at usual and accustomed places. They also reserved the Umatilla Indian Reservation as a permanent homeland. Today, most Cayuse live on the Umatilla Indian Reservation.
In this photo, Cayuse twins Tax-a-Lax and Alompum (Emma and Edna Jones) look out from their undecorated wood and fabric cradleboards. One source identifies the twins as grandnieces of Chief Joseph, a leader of the Nez Perce people. Various tribes in interior Washington and Oregon traditionally wrapped their infants tightly and laced them into cradleboards. Cradleboards were often made of wood, with a covering of leather or fabric. Some were quite plain while others were highly decorated with beadwork and shells. Women would carry cradleboards in their arms or on their backs, so they could care for infants while performing other tasks.
From 1889 to 1891, photographer Lee Moorhouse served as “Indian Agent” on the Umatilla Reservation, and many of his subjects were members of the Umatilla, Cayuse, and Walla Walla tribes.
Caption on image: ""Copyrighted 1898 by Lee Moorehouse"" [sic]
Caption information source: ""A Brief History of CTUIR,"" Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation, retrieved from https://ctuir.org/about/brief-history-of-ctuir/ Caption information source: ""Lee Moorhouse: Photographer of the Inland Empire,"" by Steven L. Grafe, Oregon Historical Quarterly 98, no. 4 (Winter 1997-98): 426-477. Caption information source: “Alompum and Tax-a-Iax, b. 1898. Twin grandnieces of Chief Joseph,” Library of Congress, retrieved from https://www.loc.gov/item/2018648235/
rdf:Description.dc:type: Safety film negatives; image; photograph StillImage
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Historical Society Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chief Isaac of the Hän, Yukon Territory, circa 1898
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Curtis, Asahel, 1874-1941
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Isaac, Chief; Hän Indians--Yukon Territory; Tribal chiefs--Yukon Territory; Tents--Yukon Territory
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Hän people historically lived along the Yukon River near the border of eastern Alaska and western Yukon Territory. One of their largest and most important sites was Tr’ochëk, where the Klondike and Yukon Rivers meet. It was there that the Klondike Gold Rush started in 1896 and within a few years thousands of people had come to Hän lands hoping to find gold. The prospectors drove game animals away and took over the land, which threatened the Hän people's traditional lifeways. Chief Isaac of the Hän people, shown here, saw the impacts that the Gold Rush had on his people and their culture. In response, he moved them three miles downriver to Moosehide and entrusted knowledge of many of their songs and dances to Indigenous people in Alaska for safekeeping. In the aftermath of the gold rush, the Hän strove to balance Indigenous traditions against cultural influences from the settlers. Chief Isaac continued to lead the Hän until his death in 1932. Today, most Hän people are part of the Tr’ondëk Hwëch’in First Nation in Dawson City. The Tr’ondëk Hwëch’in began negotiating their Land Claim in 1991 and it came into effect in 1998.
Curtis no. 46,136
Caption information source: Tr’ondëk Hwëch’in, FirstVoices, retrieved from https://www.firstvoices.com/explore/FV/sections/Data/Athabascan/H%C3%A4n/H%C3%A4n Caption information source: The Chiefs, Chief Isaac's People of the River, retrieved from http://chiefisaac.com/the_chiefs.html
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Historical Society Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kate Borst christening the steamer "Snoqualmie," August 11, 1919
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Nowell, F.H. (Frank H.)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Borst, Kate Kanim; Snoqualmie (Ship); Puget Sound Bridge & Dredging Company--Facilities; Snoqualmie Indians--Commemoration; Snoqualmie Indians--Women; Boat & ship industry--Washington (State)--Seattle; Launchings--Washington (State)--Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:description:
In August 1919, the Puget Sound Bridge & Dredging Company launched the steamer "Snoqualmie" at its Seattle shipyard on Harbor Island. The vessel was named for the Snoqualmie Tribe, in honor of the aid they gave the settlers against other Indigenous groups in the war of 1855-1856, now referred to as the Puget Sound War. Many tribal members traveled to Seattle and took part in the launching ceremonies. This photo, taken August 11, 1919, shows Kate Borst (1855-1938) christening the steamer "Snoqualmie" by breaking a bottle of champagne against the bow. Kate Borst was a relative of Chief Si’ahl (Chief Seattle) and the half-sister of Snoqualmie chief Jerry Kanim, who was a nephew of 19th century Snoqualmie chief Patkanim.
Caption information source: "Historic Overview: Carnation, Washington," by Christine Palmer, King County Cultural Resources Division, retrieved from: https://web.archive.org/web/20050519084000/http://www.ci.carnation.wa.us/library/carnation-historical-context.pdf. Caption information source: "Borst, Kate (1855-1938)" by Alan J. Stein, HistoryLink, retrieved from https://www.historylink.org/File/294.
rdf:Description.dc:source: McCurdy Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Snoqualmie woman and girls at the launching of the steamer "Snoqualmie," 1919

rdf:Description.dc:description:
On August 11, 1919, the Puget Sound Bridge & Dredging Company launched the steamer "Snoqualmie" at its Seattle shipyard on Harbor Island. The vessel was named for the Snoqualmie Tribe, in honor of the aid they gave the settlers against other Indigenous groups in the war of 1855-1856, now referred to as the Puget Sound War. This photo shows some of the Snoqualmie tribe members who traveled to Seattle to take part in the launching ceremonies.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indigenous group in ceremonial dress, Seattle, 1931
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Blackthunder (Skykomish chief); Dancers--Washington (State); Skykomish Indians--Clothing & dress; Drums
rdf:Description.dc:description:
This image shows a group of Indigenous people dressed in elaborate ceremonial dress in the summer of 1931. It is possibly in connection with a display of Northwest Indigenous culture at the Seattle Exposition and Outdoor Show, which included a war dance demonstration every evening. The two men on the right wear feather headgear typical of Coast Salish spirit dancers. The man on the left holding a painted drum is Frank Hillaire, a leader of the Lummi people.
Caption information source: "Indian village draws crowds," Seattle Post-Intelligencer, July 27, 1931, page 4.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Canoe race at Coupeville festival, August 9, 1936
rdf:Description.dc:subject: International Indian War Canoe Race (1936 : Coupeville, Wash.); Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Social life; Canoes--Indians of North America--Washington (State); Canoes--Washington (State)--Coupeville; Racing--Washington (State)--Coupeville
rdf:Description.dc:description:
In 1936, the Coupeville Indian Water Festival culminated in a race of traditional canoes crewed by Indigenous people from Washington and British Columbia. Eleven canoes started the three-mile race in Penn's Cove on August 9, 1936, but only eight managed to finish. High winds caused three canoes to sink; the Lone Eagle from the Lummi Reservation sank only a few feet from the finish line. Fortunately, no racers were injured and the canoes were undamaged. The winner of the race was Saanich No. 5 from the Saanich Tribe in British Columbia. About 12,000 viewers watched the competition.
Original negative envelope title: "Canoes nearing half-mile point"
Caption information from "Historic Indian race at Coupeville: eleven war canoes in colorful battle," Seattle Post-Intelligencer, Aug. 10, 1936, page 2.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Post-Intelligencer Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: siastenu at the Seattle Post-Intelligencer office, Seattle, November 16, 1940
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Shelton, Ruth Sehome (Snohomish Indian) ; Snohomish Indians--Women; Snohomish Indians--Clothing & dress; Women--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation--Clothing & dress; Clothing & dress----Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Portrait photograph
rdf:Description.dc:description:
siastenu (1857-1958), also named Ruth Sehome Shelton, was born in 1857 on Guemes Island, in one of the last remaining Samish longhouses. She was descended from the Dungeness Klallam, the Lummi, and the Samish peoples. siastenu spread the oral histories of the Coast Salish peoples and carried knowledge of that history into the 20th century. In 1889, siastenu married Wheakadim or Whah-kay-dub (also named William Shelton), who was a leader of the Snohomish people.
This image shows siastenu at the Seattle Post-Intelligencer office on November 16, 1940. She visited the newspaper to deliver a forecast of a cold and harsh winter ahead. While at the PI, siastenu had a conversation in Chinook Jargon with Ed Dalby, the newspaper’s marine editor. Chinook Jargon was a trade language derived from French, English, and several different Indigenous languages. siastenu noted that few white people at that time knew Chinook Jargon and complimented Dalby on his grasp of the language.
Caption information source: "siastenu Ruth Shelton," Tulalip Lushootseed, retrieved from https://tulaliplushootseed.com/dx%CA%B7s%C9%99hubtx%CA%B7-story-tellers/ruth-siast%C9%99nu-shelton/ Caption information source: "'Klonas mika wasa Chinook?' and chief's widow knows the answers," Seattle Post-Intelligencer, Nov. 17, 1940, page 24
rdf:Description.dc:type: Safety film negatives; image; photograph StillImage
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Post-Intelligencer Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indigenous women making baskets, Olympic Peninsula, 1926
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Basket making--Washington (State)--Quinault Indian Reservation; Quinault Indians--Arts & crafts; Quinault Indians--Women; Quinault Indians--Clothing & dress; Women--Washington (State)--Quinault Indian Reservation; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Quinault Indian Reservation; Baskets; Blankets
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The women from coastal Washington's Indigenous tribes are known for their basketry. They made twined, coiled, and plaited baskets for gathering clams and berries, storing and serving food, and many other purposes. Basketry techniques were also used for hats and other clothing. At the start of the 20th century, Indigenous artists in the Pacific Northwest were making baskets specifically for the tourist trade and were experimenting with form and design. Making baskets for sale became an import income source for many Indigenous families.
This 1926 photo shows five women making baskets on a beach, possibly at Taholah, in the Quinault Reservation on Washington's Olympic Peninsula. The Quinault are a Coast Salish people whose historic territory was the southwestern Olympic Peninsula.
Caption information source: "Northwest Coast Basketry," by Silvia Koros for the Burke Museum, retrieved from https://www.burkemuseum.org/static/baskets/Teachersguideforbasketry.htm. Caption information source: "Quinault," by Justine E. James and Leilani A. Chubby, in "Native Peoples of the Olympic Peninsula: Who We Are," by the Olympic Peninsula Intertribal Cultural Advisory Committee, University of Oklahoma Press, 2002, p. 99-106.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Post-Intelligencer Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Swinomish drummer and singer at the Treaty Day observance, January 22, 1939
rdf:Description.dc:subject: George, Patrick (Swinomish Indian); Joe, Joseph (Swinomish Indian); Treaty Day (1939 : Swinomish Indian Reservation, Wash.); Swinomish Indians--Performances ; Drums; Singers--Washington (State)--Swinomish Indian Reservation; Commemoration--Washington (State)--Swinomish Indian Reservation
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Swinomish are a Coast Salish group whose historic lands were in the Skagit and Samish River valleys as well as Whidbey, Camano, Fidalgo Islands, and the San Juan Islands. They lived in large permanent villages during the winter, then spread out in spring and summer to gather resources – salmon from the rivers, shellfish from the coastline, cedar wood and berries from inland forests. In 1855, a confederation of four major groups and their allied bands – Aboriginal Swinomish, Lower Skagit, Kikiallus, and Aboriginal Samish – signed the Treaty of Point Elliott with the United States. They ceded their land to the US while reserving rights to hunt, fish, and gather at usual and accustomed places, as well as reserving the Swinomish Reservation on southeastern Fidalgo Island for a permanent homeland. Today, most descendants of these groups live on the Swinomish Reservation.
On January 22, 1939, the tribes living at the Swinomish Reservation near La Conner, Washington, held their annual Treaty Day observance. The event marked the anniversary of the 1855 Treaty of Point Elliott. In addition to the tribes from the Swinomish Reservation, tribal members from the Saanich and Cowichan (in British Columbia) and from the Puyallup came to the celebration. Treaty Day events included feasting, singing, drumming, and dancing. The 1939 Treaty Day was the first year that Swinomish chiefs allowed the ceremonies to be photographed. In this photo, Patrick George (seated) beats on a drum while tribal elder Joseph Joe sings.
Caption information source: "Who we are," Swinomish Indian Tribal Community, retrieved from https://swinomish-nsn.gov/who-we-are.aspx Caption information from "Powwow recalls end of Indian war," by R.C. Cummings, Seattle Post-Intelligencer, Jan. 24, 1939, page 11.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Post-Intelligencer Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mr. and Mrs. George Adams standing outside their home, 1939
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Adams, George (Snoqualmie Indian); Adams, George, Mrs. (Snoqualmie Indian); Snoqualmie Indians; Houses--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Spouses--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Aged persons--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The S’Klallam (also spelled Klallam) are a Coast Salish people whose historic lands stretch across the northern Olympic Peninsula from the current location of Port Townsend to the Hoko River, near Makah lands. They also lived on Whidbey Island and on the south shore of Vancouver Island. The S’Klallam lived in permanent longhouses during the winter, but in other seasons individual families spread out and camped at traditional sites to fish, hunt, or gather resources. In 1855, the S’Klallam signed the Point No Point Treaty and ceded their land to the United States but reserved rights to hunt, fish, and gather at usual and accustomed sites. The treaty stated that the S’Klallam would move to a reservation at Skokomish, but this site was distant from their traditional lands and most S’Klallams refused to leave. Beginning in the 1870s, many S’Klallam individuals privately purchased land on their traditional territory. As a result, separate S’Klallam groups emerged, which last to this day. One of the tribes lives on Vancouver Island at Becher Bay. The other three are on the northern Olympic Peninsula – the Lower Elwha Klallam Tribe (federally recognized in 1939), the Port Gamble S’Klallam Tribe (federally recognized in 1936), and the Jamestown S’Klallam Tribe (federally recognized in 1981).
In this 1939 photo, a S’Klallam couple, Mr. and Mrs. George Adams, stand outside their home. The photo was probably taken on the Port Gamble Reservation. MOHAI had previously identified them as Snoqualmie tribe members living on the Tulalip Reservation.
Caption information source: "Elwha Klallam Historical Timeline," Lower Elwha Klallam Tribe, retrieved from https://www.elwha.org/culture-history/elwha-klallam-historical-timeline/ Caption information source: "History," by Jerry Gorsline, Port Gamble S’Klallam Tribe, retrieved from https://www.pgst.nsn.us/land-and-people-and-lifestyle/history Caption information source: "Jamestown S’Klallam Tribe Introduction and Overview," Jamestown S’Klallam Tribe, retrieved from https://library.jamestowntribe.org/ld.php?content_id=47309688
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Post-Intelligencer Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two S'Klallam boys carrying clams on an Olympic Peninsula beach, 1939
rdf:Description.dc:subject: George, Claude (Klallam Indian); Anderson, Benny (Klallam); Klallam Indians--Children; Boys--Washington (State)--Olympic Peninsula; Clams--Washington (State)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The S’Klallam (also spelled Klallam) are a Coast Salish people whose historic lands stretch across the northern Olympic Peninsula from the current location of Port Townsend to the Hoko River, near Makah lands. They also lived on Whidbey Island and on the south shore of Vancouver Island. The S’Klallam lived in permanent longhouses during the winter, but in other seasons individual families spread out and camped at traditional sites to fish, hunt, or gather resources. In 1855, the S’Klallam signed the Point No Point Treaty and ceded their land to the United States but reserved rights to hunt, fish, and gather at usual and accustomed sites. The treaty stated that the S’Klallam would move to a reservation at Skokomish, but this site was distant from their traditional lands and most S’Klallams refused to leave. Beginning in the 1870s, many S’Klallam individuals privately purchased land on their traditional territory. As a result, separate S’Klallam groups emerged, which last to this day. One of the tribes lives on Vancouver Island at Becher Bay. The other three are on the northern Olympic Peninsula – the Lower Elwha Klallam Tribe (federally recognized in 1939), the Port Gamble S’Klallam Tribe (federally recognized in 1936), and the Jamestown S’Klallam Tribe (federally recognized in 1981).
In February 1939, a Seattle Post-Intelligencer photographer took this photo of two Port Gamble S'Klallam boys carrying a bucket of clams at Point Julia. The boy on the left is Claude "Skip" George and on the right is Benny Anderson, Claude's uncle. The dog is George's dog Skipper. Skip George (1930-2011) was raised at Point Julia by grandparents and great-grandparents who spoke the S’Klallam language and passed on memories of S’Klallam culture from the mid-19th century. George went on to become a historian who preserved and passed on knowledge of S'Klallam history and culture.
Written on negative: Claude George, Benny Anderson
Caption information source: "Elwha Klallam Historical Timeline," Lower Elwha Klallam Tribe, retrieved from https://www.elwha.org/culture-history/elwha-klallam-historical-timeline/ Caption information source: "History," by Jerry Gorsline, Port Gamble S’Klallam Tribe, retrieved from https://www.pgst.nsn.us/land-and-people-and-lifestyle/history Caption information source: "Jamestown S’Klallam Tribe Introduction and Overview," Jamestown S’Klallam Tribe, retrieved from https://library.jamestowntribe.org/ld.php?content_id'47309688 Caption information source: "Skip George, S'Klallam historian and spiritual leader, Passages," by Richard Walker, Kitsap Daily News, November 30, 2011, retrieved from https://www.kitsapdailynews.com/news/skip-george-sklallam-historian-and-spiritual-leader-passages/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Husky crew and Indigenous canoe race, La Conner, November 29, 1941
rdf:Description.dc:subject: University of Washington--Sports; Rowing races--Washington (State)--La Conner; Canoes--Washington (State)--La Conner; Canoes--Coast Salish Indians; Coast Salish Indians--Washington (State)--La Conner
rdf:Description.dc:description:
In 1941, Swinomish leader Tandy Wilbur arranged a competition between two Indigenous racing canoes and two shells crewed by the University of Washington Huskies. Wilbur had recently become chairman of the Swinomish Tribal Community, and he intended the race to help form bonds among the several different tribal groups living together on the Swinomish reservation. He also wanted to use publicity from the race to build economic ties to the settler communities around the reservation. The two canoes participating in the race were named 'Lone Eagle' and 'Susie Q.' The four crews made a series of 100-yard sprints down Swinomish Slough, from the Swinomish Reservation to the town of La Conner. When interviewed in the 1990s, members from both sides remembered winning the race.
This image shows three of the racing craft. In the center is a UW shell, with eight rowers, with a Native canoe behind it, with ten rowers. The second UW shell is behind and to the left of the canoe.
Written on negative: Huskies & Indians 1942 [date incorrect]
Caption information source: "The Great Race of 1941: A Coast Salish Public Relations Coup," by Bruce G. Miller, Pacific Northwest Quarterly 89, No. 3 (Summer 1998): 127-135.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Post-Intelligencer Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indigenous berry pickers on Vashon Island, June 1943
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--British Columbia--Employment; Agricultural laborers--Washington (State)--Vashon Island; Strawberries--Washington (State)--Vashon Island; Croplands--Washington (State)--Vashon Island; World War, 1939-1945--Economic & industrial aspects
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The United States' entry into World War II in December 1941 created labor shortages as many men left civilian jobs to join the military. On the West Coast, the shortage was exacerbated by the forced removal of Japanese Americans, many of whom were farmers. In the summer of 1943, the Vashon Island Packing Company hired 80 First Nations people from British Columbia to weed and harvest strawberries, loganberries, and currants. The Indigenous workers replaced Filipino workers who were now growing vegetables and working in war industries. The First Nations farmworkers earned 50 to 60 cents an hour, reportedly two to three times what they might have made at home. Those who stayed the whole summer had their transportation to and from Canada paid for as well. Under the 18th century Jay Treaty between Britain and the United States, Indigenous people could freely cross the US-Canada border by proving their tribal status. First Nations people had begun working on Bainbridge and Vashon Islands as fruit pickers in the early 1900s. Most of them were women, because men from their tribes stayed closer to home to work as loggers or dockworkers.
This June 1943 photo shows a group of Indigenous workers, mostly women, in a Vashon Island strawberry field.
Caption information source: "Tribesmen weed berries," by Anne Stewart, Seattle Post-Intelligencer, June 7, 1943, page 11. Caption information source: Seattle from the Margins, by Megan Asaka, University of Washington Press, pages 153-156.
rdf:Description.dc:type: Safety film negatives; image; photograph StillImage

rdf:Description.dc:title: Charlie Swan, Makah cultural leader, Neah Bay, August 1945
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Swan, Charlie (Makah Indian); Makah Days (1945 : Makah Indian Reservation, Wash.) ; Makah Indians; Dancers--Washington (State)--Makah Indian Reservation; Drums; Masks; Blankets
rdf:Description.dc:description:
"The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to ""the people who live by the rocks and seagulls."" The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
In August of each year the Makah people hold the annual Makah Days celebration at Neah Bay, which celebrates the Makah people gaining full US citizenship in 1924. In their 1945 festival, the Makah also celebrated the end of World War II, the imminent return of 45 tribal members serving in the military, and the dedication of a new housing project on the reservation. Tribal leader Charlie Swan, whose son served in the Pacific, led the dancing. In this August photo, Swan wears a button blanket and wooden mask, and he holds a painted drum. Swan, who was well known for his dancing, had a dance troupe which gave performances throughout the Pacific Northwest.
Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com Caption information from ""Neah Bay Indians hold celebration,"" by Anne Stewart, Seattle Post-Intelligencer, Aug. 28, 1945, p. 11."
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Post-Intelligencer Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Slahal game at the Swinomish smokehouse, January 22, 1946
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Joe, Abel D. (Swinomish Indian); Treaty Day (1946 : Swinomish Indian Reservation, Wash.); Swinomish Indians--Social life; Gambling--Washington (State)--Swinomish Indian Reservation; Commemoration--Washington (State)--Swinomish Indian Reservation; Drums
rdf:Description.dc:description: The January 22, 1946 Treaty Day celebration at the Swinomish Reservation at La Conner featured the gambling game known as slahal or the bone game. Two teams of players sat in lines facing one another, with one player holding the pair of bones and the others singing and beating time with sticks and a drum. This photograph shows one line of players. Abel D. Joe of Swinomish sits to the left of a group of tall scoring sticks placed in the ground. He chants while holding one of the game bones in his open hand. Two drummers sit to the left; other players sing and drum the floor with sticks.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indigenous dancers fancy dancing at the Ellensburg Rodeo, September 1945
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Rodeo (1945 : Ellensburg, Wash.); Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Dance; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Children; Boys--Washington (State)--Ellensburg; Dancers--Washington (State)--Ellensburg; Rodeos--Washington (State)--Ellensburg
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The first rodeo at Ellensburg, Washington, opened in September 1923. For many years, the "Indian Village" was one of the more popular attractions at the rodeo. There, Indigenous people from many tribes camped in teepees and put on dancing and riding performances. In 1945, 100 Yakama Natives camped and performed at the rodeo and rode in its parades.
In this 1945 photo, young dancers from an unidentified tribe demonstrate fancy dancing at the rodeo. The fancy dance, also called the Oklahoma Feather Dance, was invented in the early 20th century by Gus McDonald, a member of the Ponca tribe in Oklahoma. It evolved from earlier Indigenous dance traditions and has been performed by people from many different Indigenous tribes at celebrations and competitions.
Caption information from John Ludtka, The Tradition Lives: a 75 year history of the Ellensburg Rodeo (1998 : Ellensburg, Wash.). Caption information source: "The Native American Fancy Dance," National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum, retrieved from https://nationalcowboymuseum.org/explore/the-native-american-fancy-dance/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indigenous people on the beach at Port Townsend, September 2, 1899
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilcox, William Holmes
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Port Townsend--Women; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Port Townsend--Structures; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Dwellings--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Beaches--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Tents--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Canoes--Indians of North America; Canoes--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Women--Washington (State)--Port Townsend
rdf:Description.dc:description: Port Townsend, site of a S’Klallam village prior to the arrival of settlers in the mid-1800s, became an important trading center by the end of the 19th century. Indigenous peoples from Canada and the tribes of Puget Sound and the Olympic Peninsula gathered along the shores of Port Townsend Bay to trade and socialize. Many also stopped here on their way to or from Puget Sound, including for seasonal work in the hop fields south and east of Seattle. In this photograph, canoes line the beach and tents are pitched above the high tide line.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Wilcox Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indigenous group launching their canoe at Port Townsend, August 30, 1899
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilcox, William Holmes
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Port Townsend--Transportation; Beaches--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Fishing--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Canoes--Indians of North America--Washington (State); Canoes--Washington (State)--Port Townsend
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Many Indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest traditionally carve canoes from cedar. The canoes are made in several styles and sizes, and the larger ocean-going canoes required multiple people to launch. This image taken in late August 1899 shows a group of Indigenous people dragging a cedar dugout canoe towards the waters of Port Townsend Bay. In the late 19th century, many Indigenous people traveled to Port Townsend to conduct trade on the beach. Canoes were often landed backwards, with the prow facing the water, in order to facilitate the next launching. In areas of frequent launchings and landings, the people cleared the beach rocks away, leaving open "canoe runs," some of which can still be seen on certain Olympic Peninsula beaches.
This canoe is of the West Coast style, as seen by its upturned prow made to resemble a wolf head. West Coast style canoes were first created by the Nuu-chah-nulth peoples of Vancouver Island, but they were adopted by many Indigenous groups across the Pacific Northwest because they were more suited to traveling in rougher waters and open ocean.
Caption information source: "Canoes, Lifeways, Waterways, "Simon Fraser University, retrieved from https://www.sfu.ca/archaeology/museum/exhibits/virtual-exhibits/canoes--lifeways--waterways.html
rdf:Description.dc:source: Wilcox Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:description:

In areas of frequent launchings and landings, the people cleared the beach rocks away, leaving open "canoe runs," some of which can still be seen on certain Olympic Peninsula beaches.
This canoe is of the West Coast style, as seen by its upturned prow made to resemble a wolf head. West Coast style canoes were first created by the Nuu-chah-nulth peoples of Vancouver Island, but they were adopted by many Indigenous groups across the Pacific Northwest because they were more suited to traveling in rougher waters and open ocean.

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilcox, William Holmes

rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
This photograph shows two Makah people from Neah Bay camped on the beach at Port Townsend in September 1899. In the late 19th century, many Indigenous people traveled to Port Townsend to conduct trade on the beach. The young Makah woman wears a dress of cloth which was probably bought or traded for. Her earrings are probably Native-made.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Group of Makah people under a fly tent at Port Townsend, August 30, 1899
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilcox, William Holmes
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Makah Indians--Domestic activities; Makah Indians--Structures; Dwellings--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Families--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Tents--Washington (State)--Port Townsend
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
Port Townsend, site of a S’Klallam village prior to the arrival of settlers in the mid-1800s, became an important trading center by the end of the 19th century. Indigenous peoples from Canada and the tribes of Puget Sound and the Olympic Peninsula gathered along the shores of Port Townsend Bay to trade and socialize. Many also stopped here on their way to or from Puget Sound, including for seasonal work in the hop fields south and east of Seattle. This candid photograph shows a Makah group, likely a family, resting on the beach. Their tent appears to be commercially manufactured. The man on the right seems to be splitting firewood.
Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilcox, William Holmes
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Port Townsend--Structures; Indians of North America--Washington (State)--Port Townsend--Women; Dwellings--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Clothing & dress--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Families--Washington (State)--Port Townsend; Tents--Washington (State)--Port Townsend
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Port Townsend, site of a S’Klallam village prior to the arrival of settlers in the mid-1800s, became an important trading center by the end of the 19th century. Indigenous peoples from Canada and the tribes of Puget Sound and the Olympic Peninsula gathered along the shores of Port Townsend Bay to trade and socialize. Many also stopped here on their way to or from Puget Sound, including for seasonal work in the hop fields south and east of Seattle.
In this scene, a woman weaves a basket amid the hustle and bustle of a crowded camp. In the background, a white man examines a small box, perhaps intending to buy or trade. Baskets were among the top trade items for the Makah and other Indigenous peoples of the Olympic Peninsula region.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Makah dancing at Colman Dock, Seattle, March 22, 1941
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Swan family (Makah Indians); Green, Alexander (Makah Indian); Dancers----Washington (State)--Seattle; Makah Indians--Dance; Makah Indians--Clothing & dress; Spectators--Washington (State)--Seattle; Sailors--American--Washington (State)--Seattle; United States. Navy
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Makah people of the northwest tip of the Olympic Peninsula refer to themselves as Kwih-dich-chuh-ahtx, which translates roughly to "the people who live by the rocks and seagulls." The early Makah were skilled mariners, using several types of canoes which they carved from western red cedar for various purposes—war, whaling, fishing, sealing, carrying cargo, and long voyages. Today, roughly 1400 Makah live in and around their traditional lands near Neah Bay on the Makah Indian Reservation. The carving of their skilled woodworkers can range in size from tiny masks to totems and giant, oceangoing canoes. Whaling and fishing have been central to Makah culture for thousands of years. The Makah are the only tribe to be granted whaling rights by treaty with the US government, in the Treaty of Neah Bay signed in 1855. While the Makah voluntarily suspended whale hunting in the 1920s due to the near extinction of whales from commercial whaling, they exercised their treaty right to hunt whales once in 1999 before court decisions blocked further legal hunting.
Here five members of the Makah tribe gave a preview of their upcoming dance performance upon arriving at Colman Dock on March 22, 1941. Charlie Swan (at right, with mask), his wife, and his daughter Delores are shown with Alexander Green (playing the drum) and his wife. The group came to Seattle to attend a Chamber of Commerce luncheon promoting tourism to the Olympic Peninsula. Charlie (also spelled Charley) Swan was a chief of the Makah. He was well known for his dancing, and had a dance troupe which gave performances throughout the Pacific Northwest.
Written on negative: Neah Bay Indians
Caption information source: "Indians DO give a whoop for Seattle," by Doug Welch, Seattle Post-Intelligencer, Mar. 28, 1941, part 2, page 1. Caption information source: Makah Tribe website at https://makah.com

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chief Jerry Kanim and his family, Snoqualmie, February 21, 1948
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Kanim family (Snoqualmie Indians); Group portraits
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Snoqualmie people are a Coast Salish group who have lived in the Snoqualmie River Valley since time immemorial. They made dugout canoes which they used to navigate the river and reach Puget Sound. Traditionally the Snoqualmie burned off the bottom lands of the Snoqualmie Valley to create open areas that ensured an abundance of edible plants for foraging as well as supplied space for game animals to feed. In the early 19th century, the Snoqualmie were among the most powerful tribes around Puget Sound. They exerted economic influence over neighboring groups from Whidbey Island to Snoqualmie Pass. Snoqualmie chief Patkanim (also spelled Pat Kanim) signed the Treaty of Point Elliott in 1855, ceding the Snoqualmie people’s land to the United States. They were temporarily assigned to live on the Tulalip reservation and were promised a reservation of their own. However, the US government reneged on its promise and no land was allocated for the Snoqualmie, most of whom moved back to their historic lands or stayed on the Tulalip reservation. The Snoqualmie finally received a reservation on their historic land in 1999.
This image shows Snoqualmie chief Jerry Kanim (the nephew of Patkanim) with some of his family members. On February 21, 1948, Jerry Kanim and representatives of several other tribes met at Eagles Hall in Carnation, Washington, on historic Snoqualmie land to discuss ways of pressing their claims to the reservation land that had been promised to them.
[SHS 15,662]
Caption information source: "Indians still awaiting '80 acres per family'", Seattle Post-Intelligencer, February 22, 1948, page 7
rdf:Description.dc:type: Safety film negatives; image; photograph StillImage

rdf:Description.dc:title: Women cooking salmon, Muckleshoot Reservation, circa 1950
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Muckleshoot Indians--Women; Outdoor cookery--Washington (State)--Muckleshoot Indian Reservation; Cooks--Washington (State)--Muckleshoot Indian Reservation; Salmon--Washington (State)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Muckleshoot Indian Tribe is made up of descendants of the Duwamish and Upper Puyallup peoples who lived near Puget Sound and its associated waterways since time immemorial. Muckleshoot ancestors lived in villages that were tied together by marriage bonds, trade, shared ceremonies, and use of the same land. This network of interconnected villages extended far beyond the Upper Puyallup and Duwamish tribes, which allowed Muckleshoot ancestors to fish, hunt, and gather across a large area, from the west side of Puget Sound to the Cascade Mountains. The Upper Puyallup and Duwamish tribes signed treaties in 1854 and 1855 respectively, which ceded their land to the United States in exchange for reserving rights to hunt, fish, and gather at usual and accustomed places. The tribes were also promised reservations as permanent homelands. A conflict between the settlers and several Indigenous groups, now called the Puget Sound War, occurred from 1855-56 and in its aftermath a reservation was established on a plain called Muckleshoot at the junction of the White and Green Rivers. After the Muckleshoot Reservation was established, its people gradually came to be known as the Muckleshoot Tribe, instead of by their historical tribal affiliations. Since the early 20th century, the Muckleshoot people have defended their treaty rights, especially fishing rights.
Salmon was historically a mainstay food for the Indigenous tribes of the Pacific Northwest and has remained an important part of their diet. The catching, preparing, and cooking of salmon also remain significant parts of the culture of many Indigenous peoples in Washington. In this photo, several women on the Muckleshoot Reservation help prepare salmon, which has been cut and strung onto sticks and then suspended over an open fire to grill. The wood is probably alder, which gives a distinctive flavor to fresh-cooked salmon and was the preferred fuel.
Caption information source: "History of the Muckleshoot Indian Tribe and its Reservation," Muckleshoot Indian Tribe, retrieved from http://www.muckleshoot.nsn.us/about-us/overview.aspx.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Post-Intelligencer Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Native Alaskan woman working on a canoe by a river, circa 1909
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Johnson.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--Alaska; Indians of North America--Transportation; Canoes--Indians of North America--Alaska; Boat & ship industry--Alaska
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Canoes need upkeep and repair in order to stay watertight. In this photo, an Native Alaskan woman works on the edge of her flat-bottomed craft by the side of a river. Two other canoes rest nearby on the beach. The wooden poles are probably used for drying fish. The location of the photograph is unknown, but it was most likely taken in southeastern Alaska or the Yukon region. Its date is also unknown, but is likely between 1898 and 1920.
Caption on image: "Boat Builder"
rdf:Description.dc:type: Safety film negatives; image; photograph StillImage

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tlingit boy wearing a woven hat, Sitka, circa 1915
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Merrill, E.W. (Elbridge Warren)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Boys--Alaska--Sitka; Tlingit Indians--Children; Tlingit Indians--Arts & Crafts; Hats
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tlingit people have lived on the coast and islands of what is now southeastern Alaska since time immemorial. Tlingit society is organized into clans, which follow maternal descent. Fishing, gathering, and hunting were central to historic Tlingit lifeways. They used salmon, shellfish, seals, berries, deer, and other food sources, making sure to use every part for different purposes, not wasting anything. The Tlingit also had many uses for cedar trees, from houses, to totems and baskets. Cedar was also used for canoes, which were one of the main modes of transport for the Tlingit and enabled them to travel and trade not only amongst each other but also with neighboring peoples north and south along the Pacific coast.
This young Tlingit boy is photographed in a photographer's studio wearing a blanket and a woven spruce root hat typical of the northern Northwest Coast Indigenous peoples. The spruce root is twined so tightly that it sheds water, and the hat's rim is decorated with a geometric pattern.
Caption information source: "Our History," Central Council Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska, retrieved from http://www.ccthita.org/about/history/index.html

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tal Tan Billy, Alaska, circa 1898 - 1920
rdf:Description.dc:creator: J.E.W.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tal Tan Billy; Tahltan Indian--British Columbia; Ceremonial dancers--British Columbia; Tahltan Indians--Clothing & dress; Tahltan Indians--Arts & crafts; Men--British Columbia; Blankets
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tlingit are a group of Indigenous peoples whose traditional home is on the coast of southeastern Alaska. The Tlingit, as well as neighboring groups, weave elaborate ceremonial blankets with abstracted images of animals. The blankets are called Chilkat blankets after one of the Tlingit tribes, and are traditionally worn during important events.
The man in this photograph wears a woven Chilkat blanket and a wooden headdress carved with the image of a bear. His name, written on the photograph as Tal Tan Billy, implies that he was connected with the Tahltan people who lived inland from the British Columbia coast, along the Stikine River. The subject's ceremonial clothing is typical of the Tlingit; Tahltan artwork was influenced by Tlingit styles. The Tahltan and Tlingit peoples had a complex relationship that involved trade networks, intermarriage, and some overlapping territories.
Caption on image: "Tal Tan Billy" ; "J.E.W."
Caption information from Bill Holm, "Art", in Wayne Suttles, ed. Handbook of the North American Indians, Vol. 7: Northwest Coast, p. 606. Caption information source: "Unpacking a phrase: The Chilkat blanket," by Christy Christodoulides, Burke Museum, retrieved from https://www.burkemuseum.org/news/unpacking-phrase-chilkat-blanket

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chief Anotklosh of the Taku, Alaska, circa 1913
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Case, W.H. (William Howard)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anotklosk (Tlingit Indian); Tlingit Indians--Clothing & dress; Aged persons--Alaska--Juneau Region; Men--Alaska--Juneau Region; Tribal chiefs--United States; Blankets
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tlingit people have lived on the coast and islands of what is now southeastern Alaska since time immemorial. Tlingit society is organized into clans, which follow maternal descent. Fishing, gathering, and hunting were central to historic Tlingit lifeways – they used salmon, shellfish, seals, berries, deer, and other food sources. They used every part for different purposes, not wasting anything. The Tlingit also had many uses for cedar trees, from houses to totems, canoes, and baskets. Canoes were one of the main modes of transport for the Tlingit and enabled them to travel and trade not only amongst each other but also with neighboring peoples north and south along the Pacific coast.
The Taku are a tribe of northern Tlingit whose traditional lands extended along the Taku River and included the area northeast of Juneau, Alaska. The northern Tlingit traded heavily with merchant vessels and bartered for large numbers of imported goods. In this image, Chief Anotklosh (also spelled 'Ano-Thlosh' or 'Ano-Tlosh'), chief of the Taku, wears a woven Chilkat blanket made from cedar bark and mountain goat wool which had been dyed yellow, black and blue-green. He holds a carved wooden bird rattle and wears a European military-style cap. Chilkat blankets, named after one of the Tlingit tribes, are elaborate ceremonial blankets made by the Tlingit as well as neighboring peoples. They feature abstracted images of animals and are traditionally worn during important events.
Caption on image: ""Chief Anotklosk Chief of the Taku Tribe, Juneau, Alaska.""
Caption information source: “Our History,” Central Council Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska, retrieved from http://www.ccthita.org/about/history/index.html Caption information source: ""Unpacking a phrase: The Chilkat blanket,"" by Christy Christodoulides, Burke Museum, retrieved from https://www.burkemuseum.org/news/unpacking-phrase-chilkat-blanket"

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tlingit man and woman in full potlatch costumes, Alaska, 1906
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Nowell, F.H. (Frank H.) Case & Draper
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Kaw-claa (Tlingit Indian); Tlingit Indians--Clothing & dress; Tlingit Indians--Women; Ceremonial dancers--Alaska--Juneau Region; Women--Alaska--Juneau Region; Men--Alaska--Juneau Region; Hats; Couples--Alaska--Juneau Region
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tlingit people have lived on the coast and islands of what is now southeastern Alaska since time immemorial. Tlingit society is organized into clans, which follow maternal descent. Fishing, gathering, and hunting were central to historic Tlingit lifeways – they used salmon, shellfish, seals, berries, deer, and other food sources. They used every part for different purposes, not wasting anything. The Tlingit also had many uses for cedar trees, from houses, to totems, canoes, and baskets. Canoes were one of the main modes of transport for the Tlingit and enabled them to travel and trade not only amongst each other but also with neighboring peoples north and south along the Pacific coast.
The two Tlingit people in this photograph wear elaborate painted and beaded tunics. The man (left) wears a tall hat topped with rings which signify the number of potlatches he has given. He holds a painted paddle with a fringe of deer hoof rattles. The woman (right) wears a nose ring and a bear claw headdress. She carries a crescent-shaped object painted with a raven design. Both individuals wear face paint. The woman is identified as Kaw-claa in another photograph in the museum's collection. Potlatches are traditional feasts involving extensive gift-giving as a show of power and wealth. Potlatches are a traditional part of many Northwest Coast Indigenous cultures.
Caption on image: "Natives in full potlatch dancing custome [sic]. Copyright 1906 by Case & Draper."
The name of photographer Frank Nowell is embossed on the lower right corner of the image. Nowell likely copied the original Case & Draper photograph.
Caption information source: "Our History," Central Council Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska, retrieved from http://www.ccthita.org/about/history/index.html

rdf:Description.dc:title: Three brothers, headmen of the Chilkat, Alaska, 1907
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ka-sh-ak (Tlingit Indian); Skan-doo (Tlingit Indian); Ind-a-yanek (Tlingit Indian); Families--Alaska; Tlingit Indians--Clothing & dress; Men--Alaska--Juneau Region; Blankets; Rattles
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Chilkat are a Tlingit tribe who have lived in and around their village of Klukwan on the Chilkat River, in southeastern Alaska since time immemorial. They lived on foods available on their lands as well as trading with other tribes on the Pacific coast and inland. Settlers came to Chilkat lands in large numbers in the early 20th century, and they dispossessed the Chilkat of most of their land. US authorities attempted to suppress Chilkat culture by prohibiting potlatches and other traditional customs. However, their efforts failed and the Chilkat people maintained many of their traditions. Today most Chilkat people live in Klukwan.
This image shows three brothers and leaders of the Kak-Von-Tons, a part of the Chilkat tribe. They are identified as Ka-sh-ak (also spelled Kaalgéi), Skan-doo (Skundoo or Sx'andu.oo), and Ind-a-yanek (Swatka or Yindayáank') and they pose together wearing their ceremonial clothing. Two of the brothers have elaborately patterned Chilkat blankets, and the third wears a shirt decorated with deer hoofs. The man in the center also displays a carved wooden bird helmet with feathers attached. Each man holds a carved and painted bird-shaped rattle.
Caption on image: "Three brothers, old head-men of the Kak-von-tons of the Chilkat Tribe. Ka-Sh-Ak, the Monkey-Man; Skan-Doo, notorious old medicene [sic] man; Ind-A-Yanek (Swatka) the famous Indian guide" ; "Copyright 1907 by Case & Draper."
Caption information source: "History," Chilkat Indian Village, retrieved from https://chilkat-nsn.gov/history/ Caption information source: "Ka-Sh-Ak, the Monkeyman. Skan-Doo [Skundoo], notorious old medicene [medicine] man. Ind-A-Yanek (Swatka), the famous Indian guide." Alaska State Library, retrieved from https://vilda.alaska.edu/digital/collection/cdmg21/id/6749/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Camp of Auke Natives, Alaska, circa 1896
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tlingit Indians--Subsistence activities; Tlingit Indians--Structures; Indian encampments--Alaska--Juneau Region
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tlingit people have lived on the coast and islands of what is now southeastern Alaska since time immemorial. Tlingit society is organized into clans, which follow maternal descent. Fishing, gathering, and hunting were central to historic Tlingit lifeways – they used salmon, shellfish, seals, berries, deer, and other food sources. They used every part for different purposes, not wasting anything. The Tlingit also had many uses for cedar trees, from houses to totems, canoes, and baskets. Canoes were one of the main modes of transport for the Tlingit and enabled them to travel and trade not only amongst each other but also with neighboring peoples north and south along the Pacific coast.
The Auke are a tribe of the Tlingit. Their historic lands are near the current location of Juneau, Alaska. The Auke, like other southeast Alaska groups, traveled to fishing camps during the summer months. This photograph of an Auke fishing camp on the beach shows filleted halibut drying in front of the leftmost tent, and a mixture of Indigenous-made and commercially purchased items scattered around the campsite. In front of the rightmost tent, a seated woman prepares food near a large pot while a man and child stand nearby.
Caption on image: ""Camp of Auk Indians, Alaska""
Caption information source: “Our History,” Central Council Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska, retrieved from http://www.ccthita.org/about/history/index.html

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chilkat people in dance costumes, Klukwan, Alaska, circa 1895
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ceremonial dancers--Alaska--Klukwan; Tlingit Indians--Clothing & dress; Tlingit Indians--Children; Men--Alaska--Klukwan; Children--Alaska --Klukwan; Hats
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Chilkat are a Tlingit tribe who have lived in and around their village of Klukwan on the Chilkat River, in southeastern Alaska since time immemorial. They lived on foods available on their lands as well as trading with other tribes on the Pacific coast and inland. Settlers came to Chilkat lands in large numbers in the early 20th century, and they dispossessed the Chilkat of most of their land. US authorities attempted to suppress Chilkat culture by prohibiting potlatches and other traditional customs. However, their efforts failed and the Chilkat people maintained many of their traditions. Today most Chilkat people live in Klukwan.
The costumes worn by these Chilkat dancers at Klukwan include button-design and beaded tunics, with elaborately-beaded aprons and fringed leather shirts. The boy in the darker costume wears a wig and headdress of mountain goat horn normally reserved for the ixt, or spiritual leader. All five of the men have nose rings, a traditional adornment, but the boys do not wear them.
Caption on image: "Chilkat Indians in dancing costumes, Alaska" ; "Copyright by Winter & Pond."
Caption information source: "History," Chilkat Indian Village, retrieved from https://chilkat-nsn.gov/history/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tlingit women weaving baskets, Alaska, circa 1897
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Basket making--Alaska--Sitka; Baskets; Tlingit Indians--Arts & crafts; Tlingit Indians--Women; Tlingit Indians--Children; Infants--Alaska--Sitka; Children sleeping--Alaska--Sitka; Cradleboards--Alaska--Sitka; Women--Alaska--Sitka
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tlingit people have lived on the coast and islands of what is now southeastern Alaska since time immemorial. Tlingit society is organized into clans, which follow maternal descent. Fishing, gathering, and hunting were central to historic Tlingit lifeways – they used salmon, shellfish, seals, berries, deer, and other food sources. They used every part for different purposes, not wasting anything. The Tlingit also had many uses for cedar trees, from houses to totems, canoes, and baskets. Canoes were one of the main modes of transport for the Tlingit and enabled them to travel and trade not only amongst each other but also with neighboring peoples north and south along the Pacific coast.
Tlingit women made finely-woven baskets for the tourist trade and marketed them in towns served by steamship lines. In this photo, three weavers work on baskets using spruce root and grasses, and decorated in a technique known as "false embroidery." False embroidery involves using dyed grass stems wrapped around the weft so the pattern shows only on the outside of the basket. Beaded pouches, a basketry-covered flask, and a few other items are laid out on the grass in front of the women. A baby sleeps beside its mother, wrapped tightly in its cradleboard, and a glass baby bottle with a long-necked nipple sits at the cradleboard's foot.
Caption on image: "Native women weaving baskets, Alaska. Copyright by Winter & Pond."
Caption information source: "Our History," Central Council Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska, retrieved from http://www.ccthita.org/about/history/index.html

rdf:Description.dc:title: Infant asleep in a sling, Alaska, circa 1905
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Infants--Alaska--Juneau Region; Children sleeping--Alaska--Juneau Region; Indians of North America--Alaska--Juneau Region
rdf:Description.dc:description:
In this image, an infant wearing a cap covered with buttons sleeps in a birchbark sling rigged with a rocking mechanism. The style of the cap appears Tlingit, but the infant's moccasins and the sling are probably of Alaskan Athabaskan origin. Around the beginning of the 20th century, white photographers used photographs of Indigenous babies on commercial products, and this image was produced on a Christmas card.
Caption on cardboard photo mount: "Alaska slumberland."
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Historical Society Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Group of Chilkat people in traditional dance costumes, Klukwan, Alaska, circa 1895
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Yeilgooxu (Tlingit Indian); Ceremonial dancers--Alaska--Klukwan; Tlingit Indians--Clothing & dress; Tlingit Indians--Children; Tlingit Indians--Structures; Men--Alaska--Klukwan; Children--Alaska--Klukwan; Hats; Masks; Dwellings--Alaska--Klukwan
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Chilkat are a Tlingit tribe who have lived in and around their village of Klukwan on the Chilkat River, in southeastern Alaska since time immemorial. They lived on foods available on their lands as well as trading with other tribes on the Pacific coast and inland. Settlers came to Chilkat lands in large numbers in the early 20th century, and they dispossessed the Chilkat of most of their land. US authorities attempted to suppress Chilkat culture by prohibiting potlatches and other traditional customs. However, their efforts failed and the Chilkat people maintained many of their traditions. Today most Chilkat people live in Klukwan.
Here, men and boys dressed in dance regalia pose in front of the house of Chief Klart-Reech at Klukwan, Alaska. The man in the center, wearing the highly-patterned Chilkat tunic, is Yielgooxu, a hereditary chief of the Klukwan Whale House. The man next to him wears a fur-trimmed shirt with a beaver design. Several of the masks and spruce root hats appear in photos of the interior of the Whale House taken by the same photographer. The mixture of native and European clothing is typical of this time period.
Caption on image: "Ixterior [sic] of chief's house. Chilkat Indians in old dancing costumes, Alaska. Copyright Winter & Pond."
Caption information source: "History," Chilkat Indian Village, retrieved from https://chilkat-nsn.gov/history/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Woman weaving a Chilkat blanket, Alaska, circa 1904
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Weaving--Alaska--Juneau Region; Tlingit Indians--Women; Tlingit Indians--Arts & crafts; Tlingit Indians--Clothing & dress; Women--Alaska--Juneau Region; Looms; Blankets
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Chilkat are a Tlingit tribe who have lived in and around their village of Klukwan on the Chilkat River, in southeastern Alaska since time immemorial. They lived on foods available on their lands as well as trading with other tribes on the Pacific coast and inland. Settlers came to Chilkat lands in large numbers in the early 20th century, and they dispossessed the Chilkat of most of their land. US authorities attempted to suppress Chilkat culture by prohibiting potlatches and other traditional customs. However, their efforts failed and the Chilkat people maintained many of their traditions. Today most Chilkat people live in Klukwan.
In this photograph, a woman works on a Chilkat ceremonial dance blanket using a frame loom. Chilkat blankets are elaborate ceremonial blankets made by the Tlingit as well as neighboring peoples. They feature abstracted images of animals and are traditionally worn during important events. The warp threads, made from cedar bark covered with mountain goat wool, hang in bundles from the top bar. The weaver has completed the border on three sides and is beginning to weave the design in the center. She has carefully placed newspapers over the edges of her blanket to protect the finished portion. A closer look at the image reveals that the newspapers originated in California and are dated January 12, 1904. Traditionally, men created the designs and painted them on boards which the women used as patterns for their weaving.
Caption information source: "History," Chilkat Indian Village, retrieved from https://chilkat-nsn.gov/history/ Caption information source: "Unpacking a phrase: The Chilkat blanket," by Christy Christodoulides, Burke Museum, retrieved from https://www.burkemuseum.org/news/unpacking-phrase-chilkat-blanket

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indigenous women merchants at Treadwell Mines on Douglas Island, Alaska, circa 1898 - 1912
rdf:Description.dc:creator: La Roche, Frank
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Treadwell Mines; Tlingit Indians--Alaska--Douglas Island--Commerce; Tlingit Indians--Alaska--Douglas Island--Women; Tlingit Indians--Alaska--Douglas Island--Clothing & dress; Tlingit Indians--Alaska--Douglas Island--Arts & crafts; Baskets; Women--Alaska--Douglas Island; Clothing & dress--Alaska--Douglas Island
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Tlingit people have lived on the coast and islands of what is now southeastern Alaska since time immemorial. Tlingit society is organized into clans, which follow maternal descent. Fishing, gathering, and hunting were central to historic Tlingit lifeways – they used salmon, shellfish, seals, berries, deer, and other food sources. They used every part for different purposes, not wasting anything. The Tlingit also had many uses for cedar trees, from houses, to totems, canoes, and baskets. Canoes were one of the main modes of transport for the Tlingit and enabled them to travel and trade not only amongst each other but also with neighboring peoples north and south along the Pacific coast.
This image shows a group of Indigenous women selling baskets, beaded clothing, and other goods near the Treadwell gold mines. The Treadwell mines were located on Douglas Island, across the channel from Juneau. The land around Juneau is the traditional home of the Auke and Taku tribes of the Tlingit people. In 1881, settlers and gold miners displaced the Auke and Taku people in order to establish the Treadwell gold mines. After the mines opened, Indigenous women came from nearby villages to sell wares to the gold miners and tourists. The baskets for sale in this photograph are Tlingit in style.
Caption on image: "Indian merchants at Treadwell Mines"
Caption information source: "Our History," Central Council Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska, retrieved from http://www.ccthita.org/about/history/index.html
rdf:Description.dc:source: Seattle Historical Society Collection Museum of History and Industry, Seattle

Susan Michel's mother (Spokane Mary is what whites called her) Tschimtah, Spokane above Indian Canyon." "Hec psesi-- she is packing wood, a grandmothers job, per Pauline Flett, 7/97" "Tchim Tom Burden Bearer. Colfax Tribe.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Spokanes in ceremonial dress pose under banner, "Indian War Dance
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Washington (State); Spokane Indians--Clothing & dress; Spokane Indians--Exhibitions; Spokane Indians--Dance
rdf:Description.dc:description: Men and children stand under banner; behind them is large marquee tent, a wagon, a tepee and some onlookers. Men wear a variety of headdresses & hats, necklaces, beaded shirts, vests, leggings & moccasins. Small boy sits on drum in front, small girl stands next to young woman in white with large beaded panel. Note from unidentified source: Indian War Dance.
