rdf:Description.dc:title: Skitswish & Spokane mothers and babies at the Indian Baby Clinic and Contest, Second National Indian Congress, July 1926
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Washington (State); Mother & children--Washington (State); Spokane Indians--Infants; Spokane Indians--Women; Spokane Indians--Clothing & dress; Skitswish Indians--Infants; Skitswish Indians--Women; Skitswish Indians--Clothing & dress; National Indian Congress (2nd : 1926 : Spokane, Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Three women watch while their babies are examined by a pair of doctors; the women wear beaded & fringed ceremonial dresses.
Note from unidentified source: "Indian Baby Prizewinner - Second National Indian Congress, Spokane, Wa. July 21-27, 1926. One of the interesting highlights of the Second National Indian Congress was the Indian Baby Clinic and Contest held under the auspices of the Spokane Child Health Association, David Friedlander, 7 month old Coeur d'Alene Indian baby was awarded the $10.00 prize for the most perfect type of Indian baby at the clinic, in comparison with the weekly clinic the Child Health Association holds the Indian babies scored much higher on the average than the Whites.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Skitswish Mission of the Sacred Heart, Cataldo, Idaho, ca. 1920
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sacred Heart Mission (Cataldo, Idaho); Skitswish Indians--Spiritual life; Missions--Idaho
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Mission building; six pillars hold up the arched roof-front with sunburst circular window.
Note from unidentified source: Old Mission State Park features the oldest standing building in Idaho, The Mission of the Sacred Heart built between 1848 and 1853. Mission walls stand a foot thick, without the benefit of nails. The structure was woven carefully of straw, mud and wooden pegs. Inside, there are no pews because the Indians preferred to worship in an open room. Over 300 members of the tribe labored over the construction. It transferred in 1877 to Desmet where it stands today.
Photo from Don. B. Scott, former editor of Coeur d'Alene Press - his father had this photo taken about 1920.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Collins Anderson / Don B. Scott Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cayuse/Nez Perce man known as Tauitau or Tu Ah Tway poses with headdress and other beaded objects
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tauitau; Joseph, Nez Perce Chief, 1840-1904--Family; Portraits--Oregon; Cayuse Indians--Clothing & dress; Cayuse Indians--Arts & crafts
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Studio portrait of seated man with feathers in his hair, spotted shirt with armbands, blanket across lap & fur around neck. Set next to him are a beaded, feathered headdress, a widebrimmed hat with beaded band, a pipe, a wide-beaded collar and other objects. Painted backdrop of tree is behind him.
Note from unidentified source: Tau-I-Tau (Tu-ah-Tway), also called Young Chief, grandson of the spokesman for the Cayuse and Umatilla Tribes at the 1855 Walla Walla Council, who was also called Young Chief.

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Portrait of seated woman with small child standing beside her. Beaded and fringed items are hung up behind her, blankets lay on ground beneath chair, and a few other beaded pieces are set upon the blankets. She is wearing a dark top over a white blouse, and beaded moccasins; the small girl is in a beaded dress. Both wear necklaces.
Note from unidentified source: Ida (Howlish - Te-Mow-E-Ne) She is of mixed Chinook and Cayuse blood.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sinkiuse-Columbia chief Moses, his nephew Chil-Lee-Leet-Sah and two other delegates sent to petition President Hayes, Washington, ca. 1879
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Moses, Chief, ca. 1829-1899; Chil-Lee-Leet-Sah; Group portraits--Washington (State); Sinkiuse-Columbia Indians; Umatilla Indians; Cayuse Indians; Walla Walla Indians; Delegations--Washington (D.C.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Four men pose for portrait in suits; two seated, two standing.
Caption on mount: This is a deputation of Indian Chiefs that General [Oliver Otis] Howard sent back to Washington D.C. in about 1879 or 1880. The clothes they are wearing was the idea of the Army Officers that conducted them on the trip. The man at the extreme left (sitting) is Chief Moses. The tall man standing next with his right hand on the shoulder of Chief Moses is Chil-lee-leet-sah, a nephew of Chief Moses and at the time the picture was taken had been designated to be the successor of Chief Moses. The large man sitting next is an Umatilla chief named Peo-peo-mox-mox which appears to mean Flying Yellow Geese. The small man standing at the extreme right is an Umatilla or Cayuse chief named as follows: Kah-lees-quot-quo-lot. Chief Moses died late in March 1899 and Chil-lee-leet-sah was drowned in the Coulmbia river near the mouth of the Spokane river about a year before Chief Moses died. We have no record of the other two chiefs.
Note from Center for Columbia River History: 1879 delegation to Washington D.C. Left to Right, Chief Moses (Sulktalthscosum), Moses' nephew, Chillileetsah, Hiachenie of the Cayuse, and Chief Homily of the Walla Wallas.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Washington (State); Colville Indians--Political activity--Washington (State); Colville Indians--Organizations--Washington (State); Government officials--Washington (State); Colville Indian Reservation (Wash.)

Caption on image: Tribal Business Council - 1941. Standing left to right: Dick Armstrong, Alex Covington, Henry Covington, Pete Moses, Barney Rickard, Fred A. Gross, Superintendent, Henry Nelson, Grace Coil and Louie Smitkin. Front row: George LaVatta, area placement officer, Florence Quill, Leo Runnels,Pete Gunn, Albert Orr, Marcel Arcasa, and Steve Cleveland
Note from unidentified source: The Confederated Tribes of the Colville Reservation is a sovereign nation governed by a 14-person board of adult Colville tribal members officially titled the Colville Business Council and informally called the tribal council.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Colville missionary Fr. Pat Savage, St. Michael's Mission, Inchelium, Washington, 1936
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Savage, Pat.; Portraits--Washington (State); Colville Indians--Spiritual life; Missionaries--Washington (State); Priests---Washington (State); St. Michael's Mission (Inchelium, Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Priest poses beneath tree.
Note from unidentified source: "1936 Inchelium, WA. Father Pat Savage, S.J., on my two day visit to Inchelium, Pater told me to cook what I wanted. Later I learned that in my two-day visit I had consumed one month's supply of food. Fr. Savage wore roman collar, a dickey, cuffs and white tennis shoes. But he always wore a coat because he never wore a shirt.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Edgar Dowd Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture

rdf:Description.dc:description: Two women, one standing and one sitting, pose before a studio backdrop, ca. 1900-1930. The woman standing is Carrie Nesbitt. The seated woman is Agnes Craig, who sits with a blanket around her shoulder and also wears a pendant necklace. The date of the photograph is unknown.

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Four women, four men, and three children pose outside with tepee and horse in background. The women have head scarves, blankets around shoulders, necklaces and hold decorated handbags. The standing men wear feathered headdresses, decorated vests, and hold various items.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nez Perce woman named Tolah, Camas Prairie, Idaho, ca. 1899
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tolah; Portraits--Idaho; Nez Perce Indians--Women; Nez Perce Indians--Wars, 1877--Women; Nez Perce--Clothing & dress; Camas Prairie (Idaho)
rdf:Description.dc:description: Studio portrait of woman seated with hands folded. She is bare headed, wears a loose blouse and blanket. Tolah is the friendly Nez Perce woman who warned the whites in 1877. She is the sister of Chief Mox Mox, leader of the active field Indians, Camas Prairie in Idaho. Lake Tolo is named after her. She is also Emma Broncheau's grandmother.
rdf:Description.dc:source: F. Young Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Salish group in ceremonial dress ride horses in elaborate tack, Montana
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Montana; Salish Indians--Clothing & dress; Salish Indians--Arts & crafts; Salish Indians--Transportation; Horses--Montana
rdf:Description.dc:description: Two boys and a young woman on horseback in front of several tents and automobiles (ca. late 20s-early 30s). Young man at far right wears a feather headdress, beaded vest, leggings and moccasins; his horse has a small beaded breast collar. Boy in middle wears a beaded vest and necklaces, and his horse has an elaborate beaded breast collar, as well as saddle decorations. The young woman wears a scarf on her head, a beaded & fringed dress & her horse also has an elaborate beaded breast collar, as well as saddle decorations.

Mourning Dove was the first female Indian to write a novel.

rdf:Description.dc:title: San Poil woman named Clara Moore, Washington
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Moore, Clara, d. 1972; Portraits--Washington (State); Sanpoil Indians--Women
rdf:Description.dc:description: Color portrait of elderly woman seated outside. She wears a scarf around her head, a red and white dress with a black sweater. Wife of Thaddeus Moore, she was born down near the mouth of the old San Poil where it flowed into the Columbia, before the dam was ever thought of. She died in the spring of 1972 at the age of 92 or 93 and was buried at Keller, Washington.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Richard T. Lewis / Chalk Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

Note from unidentified source: L-R. ?, David Isaac (Nez Perce), Jeannette Whitford (Cd'A), Sam Tilton (Nez Perce), at the dedication of Cabinet Gorge Dam, ca. 1950s. Sam Tilton is Chief Joseph's nephew. Sam's mother was Chief Joseph's sister.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nez Perce Chief White Bird
rdf:Description.dc:subject: White Bird, Nez Perce Chief; Portraits--Idaho; Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; Nez Perce Indians--Structures; Nez Perce Indians--Wars, 1877.
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Man in full length feather headdress, beaded & decorated tunic, breechcloth, leggings and moccasins stands holding decorated stick aloft, in front of tepee.
Caption on mount: Chief White Bird of the Nez Perces. Photograph courtesy of Burns' Photo Co.
Note from unidentifed source: Chief White Bird and a small band of Nez Perce fled for Canada after their capture with Chief Joseph in 1877
rdf:Description.dc:source: Roy Berk Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Williams, Beverly; Ellwood, Nathan; Halfmoon, Dorothy; Group portraits--Washington (State); Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; Nez Perce Indians--Children
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Two small girls in fringed and decorated dresses with beaded belts stand on either side of a small boy in a roach headdress, necklaces, beaded belt & armbands, decorated top & breechcloth, plain leggings and moccasins decorated with bells. In the background are men & women in decorated clothing
Note from unidentifed source: L-R: Mary Sturgis, ?, Katherine Lott (daughter of Sam Lott), Beverly Williams, Nathan Ellwood (from the Red Bear family), Princess Dorothy Halfmoon, Mabert Moore (Dorothy Halfmoon's uncle), Levi McCormack, ?, July 1937

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nez Perce rodeo champion Jackson Sundown poses with horse
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sundown, Jackson; Portraits--Idaho; Cowboys--Idaho; Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; Nez Perce Indians--Transportation
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Man wearing a wide-brimmed hat, beaded gauntlets, shirt, jeans & spurred boots stands holding horse by its bridle. In background can be seen people moving about and a concession stand.
Note from unidentifed source: Jackson Sundown [1863 - 1923], model for Charles Russell. [His family joined Chief Joseph in his flight of 1877. They crossed into Canada after the defeat at Bear Paw, Mont. Eventually, about 1910, Sundown and his wife returned to Nez Perce country. He won the titles of world champion saddle bronc rider and rodeo performer of the year at the 1916 Pendleton, Ore., Roundup - at the age of 53]
rdf:Description.dc:source: Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kalispel schoolhouse, later used as a community hall, Kalispel Indian Reservation, Washington
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Dellwo, Robert D.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Kalispel Indians--Structures; Kalispel Indians--Education; Schools--Washington (State)--Kalispel Indian Reservation; Kalispel Indian Reservation (Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Group of people moving about on steps of a dilapidated single-story building
Note from unidentified source: The Kalispel schoolhouse, classroom and living quarters for the teacher and family. After Kalispel students started to attend Cusick [WA.] schools, the old building served as community hall until, dilapidated and crumblingm it was burned to make room for a new community hall. [see L87-410.44] Used as illustration in John Fahey's book, The Kalispel Indians, c1986.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Robert D. Dellwo Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kalispel home, Kalispel Indian Reservation, Washington, 1985
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Fahey, John
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Kalispel Indians--Structures; Dwellings--Washington (State)--Kalispel Indian Reservation; Kalispel Indian Reservation (Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Single-story home set under trees; tepee visible beyond parked car. Small child sits on the doorstep.
Note from unidentified source: Under provisions of the 'Family Plan' for use of judgement fund, many Kalispel built modern homes on and off the reservation. Most of the homes, like this one beside LeClerc road, are in forest settings or overlook the Pend O'reille River. Photo taken in 1985. Used as illustration in John Fahey's book, The Kalispel Indians, c1986.
rdf:Description.dc:source: John Fahey Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kalispel tribal community center, Kalispel Indian Reservation, Washington, 1985
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Fahey, John
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Kalispel Indians--Structures; Community centers--Washington (State)--Kalispel Indian Reservation; Kalispel Indian Reservation (Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Rambling brick buildings, with wooden stairs leading to a parking lot.
Note from unidentified source: The Kalispel tribal community center, on the site of the old Kalispel schoolhouse, was built with tribal funds. Important tribal meetings, youth activities, and similar functions convene here. [see L87-410.15] Used as illustration in John Fahey's book, The Kalispel Indians, c1986.
rdf:Description.dc:source: John Fahey Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:description: Bird's eye view of farm on the Spokane River where Spokane House is located. About half a dozen buildings can be seen including a barn. Site is located northwest of Spokane just north of Nine Mile Falls.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kalispel Metal Products, near Cusick, Kalispel Indian Reservation, Washington, 1985
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Fahey, John
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Kalispel Metal Products; Kalispel Indians--Industries; Kalispel Indians--Structures; Industry--Washington (State)--Kalispel Indian Reservation; Kalispel Indian Reservation (Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Man drives a forklift outside a factory
Note from unidentified source: Kalispel Metal Products, the tribe's fabricating business near Cusick (WA), manufactures steel and aluminum components to close tolerance. The structures beside the building are among 68 dock sections for Lake Chelan, WA. Photo taken in 1985. Used as illustration in John Fahey's book, The Kalispel Indians, c1986.
rdf:Description.dc:source: John Fahey Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kalispel tribal office building & Our Lady of Sorrows Church, Kalispel Indian Reservation, Washington, 1985
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Fahey, John
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Kalispel Indians--Structures; Government facilities--Washington (State)--Kalispel Indian Reservation; Churches--Washington (State)--Kalispel Indian Reservation; Kalispel Indian Reservation (Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Long, single story building & parking lot next to small brick church.
Note from unidentified source: The Tribal office building, constructed with donated materials and Kalispel labor, stands beside the restored Our Lady of Sorrows Church. The white structure, center, is part of playground equipment. Behind it, dots in a field, is the buffalo herd. Photo taken in 1985. Used as illustration in John Fahey's book, The Kalispel Indians, c1986.
rdf:Description.dc:source: John Fahey Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kalispel tribal business committee meeting, Kalispel Indian Reservation, Washington, 1984

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Kalispel Indians--Indians--Political activity--Washington (State); Kalispel Indians--Organizations--Washington (State); Government officials--Washington (State); Kalispel Indian Reservation (Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Long, single story building & parking lot next to small brick church.
Note from unidentified source: The Kalispel business committee meets in the tribal office building. From left to right: tribal counsel Robert D. Dellwo (back to camera), Darlene Auld, secretary, Glen Nenema, chairman: Francis Cullooyah and Edo Pierre. One member, Stanley Bluff, was absent from this 1984 meeting. Used as illustration in John Fahey's book, The Kalispel Indians, c1986.
rdf:Description.dc:source: John Fahey Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture

rdf:Description.dc:title: Grand Coulee Region exploratory group, ca. 1920s
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Guilbert, Frank W., d. 1940
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bretz, J. Harlen, 1882-1981; Columbia Plateau; Grand Coulee Region
rdf:Description.dc:description: Eleven men from Princeton University and University of Chicago are seen studying the Grand Coulee Region in the area of Adrian, west of Soap Lake. Dr. Harlen Bretz, of University of Chicago, brought a student group from Princeton and the Uchicago to study Grand Coulee. These studies over many years led to the "Bretz Flood" explanation of the Columbia River and Channeled Scablands.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Frank W. Guilbert Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:description: Studio portrait of seven men. In the back row stand four, John McBain (far left), Cayuse chief Showaway, Palouse chief Wolf Necklace, and far right, Lee Moorhouse, Umatilla Indian Agent. rdf:Description.dc:title: Spectators at a football game during the National Indian Congress, Spokane, Washington, 1925
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Guilbert, Frank W., d. 1940 Guilbert, David C.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--Northwest, Pacific--Clothing & dress; Football--Washington (State)--Spokane; Gonzaga University--Football; Haskell Institute--Football; National Indian Congress (1st : 1925 : Spokane, Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Spectators at th Gonzaga/Haskell football game include three men from an unidentified tribe. They wear full ceremonial clothing including feathered headdress and pelts. One man carries a long pole covered in feathers. In the foreground two women can be seen wearing coats and hats.
"Old Album #MA 9, pg. 78 / Duplicate in Old Album #MA 18, pg. 6
rdf:Description.dc:source: Frank W. Guilbert / David Guilbert Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Spectators at a football game during the National Indian Congress, Spokane, Washington, 1925
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Guilbert, Frank W., d. 1940 Guilbert, David C.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--Northwest, Pacific--Clothing & dress; Football--Washington (State)--Spokane; Gonzaga University--Football; Haskell Institute--Football; National Indian Congress (1st : 1925 : Spokane, Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description: Spectators stand in front of the stands at th Gonzaga/Haskell football game. Four people stand in front and are most visible. They are from an unidentified tribe. Two of the women wear scarves around their heads. One wears a beaded headband and carries a baby in a cradleboard. The man wears a feathered headdress and carries a bag. Behind them many other spectators in the stands can be seen.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Frank W. Guilbert / David Guilbert Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tipis--Northwest, Pacific; Indian encampments--Washington (State)--Spokane; Indians of North America--Northwest, Pacific--Structures; National Indian Congress (1st : 1925 : Spokane, Wash.); Indian councils--Washington (State)--Spokane; Glover Stadium (Spokane, Wash.); Stadiums--Washington (State)--Spokane; Bridges--Washington (States)--Spokane
rdf:Description.dc:description: Three tepees can be seen in entirety erected in Glover Stadium along the Spokane River on Main Ave., west of Monroe. One has large circles around the bottom. A child stands in front of this tepee. An unidentified source indicates that the child may be a Coeur d'Alene Indian. In the background a bridge can be seen.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Frank W. Guilbert / David Guilbert Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture

rdf:Description.dc:title: Umatillas on their way to the general parade, National Indian Congress, Spokane, Washington, 1926

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Umatilla Indians--Transportation; National Indian Congress (2nd : 1926 : Spokane, Wash.); Parades & processions--Washington (State)--Spokane
rdf:Description.dc:description: A line of horses and carts at Monaghan Triangle on Riverside Ave. carry people to the general parade at the National Indian Congress of 1926. On the left side of the street tepees, cars and people can be seen. On the right hand side is more people and a building housing the Winship & Sons Music House. On the side of that building is a large advertisement for Goodrich Silvertowns tires.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Frank W. Guilbert Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Umatillas marching in the parade, National Indian Congress, Spokane, Washington, 1925 or 1926
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Guilbert, Frank W., d. 1940
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Umatilla Indians--Transportation; National Indian Congress; Parades & processions--Washington (State)--Spokane; Streets--Washington (State)--Spokane; Davenport Hotel (Spokane, Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description: Bird's eye view of parade at the National Indian Congress in Spokane. There is some disagreement of source concerning whether this particular parade happened in 1925 or 1926. At both Congresses they had colorful parades with Indians in full regalia from 28 different tribes of the Pacific Northwest. This picture is of the Umatilla Tribe, taken in front of the Davenport Hotel, Sprague Ave. Flags are hung over the street.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Frank W. Guilbert Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Crowning of Jessie Jim, the second Princess America, Masonic Temple, Spokane, Washington, 1926
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Guilbert, Frank W., d. 1940
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Jim, Jessie; Beauty contests--Washington (State)--Spokane; National Indian Congress (2nd : 1926 : Spokane, Wash.); Buildings--Washington (State)--Spokane
rdf:Description.dc:description:
A large crowd has gathered in front of the Masonic Temple on Riverside Ave. to see the crowning of Jessie Jim, the second Princess America. Her tribe is not know, although sources from this photograph indicate she is a Okanagon. Other sources have indicated she is either Colville, Wenatchi or Spokane. The front steps of the Temple are lined with the princesses the officials and spectators. Flags hang between the columns of the Temple.
"Old Album #MA 19, pg. 27
rdf:Description.dc:source: Frank W. Guilbert Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:description: Three people are shown being interviewed by Mr. Crewsdon. The woman on the left is Thunder. She wears a cape with fringes and a necklace. Next to her is No Shirt. rdf:Description.dc:description:
Older woman poses next to wooden chair wearing a fringed and decorated dress with a woven top and a wide leather belt. She holds a bag with a star pattern.
Note from unidentified source: (Mrs. Red Rock?) a (Nez Perce?) Indian. Tailoring of the skirt is typical of Nez Perce. Star design on bag is more common among Nez Perce than among northern neighbors, including Yakama.

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Portraits--Washington (State); Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress; Meninock, George
rdf:Description.dc:description:
A man stands on a sidewalk in a city in full ceremonial clothing. He wears a large feathered headdress, a beaded shirt, banner, breachcloth and moccasins. He holds something in his hand and a long pelt hangs from his arm. In the background is buildings and parked cars. Name is spelled either Meninock or Meninick.
The correct form of the name Meninock, kindly provided by Virginia Beavert, Yakama elder.

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Whitehall, Jack
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Saluskin, Ellen; Saluskin, Oscar; Yakima Indians--Transportation; Yakima Indians--Clothing & dress; Horses
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Two women and two children can be seen riding two of the three visible horses. Possibly the people are Johnson Meninick and his mother and grandmother. Both women wear scarves on their heads tied under their chins. The first horse is covered with a decorated blanket on which the woman sits.
The woman and child have been identified by Virginia Beavert, Yakama elder, as her mother Ellen Saluskin and her older brother Oscar.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Siksika encampment on Riverside Ave. during the National Indian Congress, Spokane, Washington, 1925
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Guilbert, Frank W., d. 1940
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tipis--Washington (State); Indian encampments--Washington (State)--Spokane; Siksika Indians--Structures; National Indian Congress (1st : 1925 : Spokane, Wash.); Indian councils--Washington (State)--Spokane; Streets--Washington (State)--Spokane
rdf:Description.dc:description: Four tepees are seen in the median of the Riverside Ave. looking west from Monroe Street. They were erected to house part of the delegation from the Blackfeet Tribe (Siksika) from Glacier National Park during the National Indian Congress. The tepees are colorful. Many cars can be seen parked and traveling along either side of the tepees. Large buildings are also visible on both sides of the street as well as a statue on the far left.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Frank W. Guilbert Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Spokane woman named Alice Garry, the first Princess America, presents an Indian hunting jacket to Herbert Hoover at the National Indian Congress, Spokane, Washington, August 19, 1926
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Libby, Charles A., Sr., 1879-1966 Libby, Charles A., Jr., 1907-1982
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Garry, Alice; National Indian Congress (2nd : 1926 : Spokane, Wash.); Spokane Indians--Clothing & dress; Hoover, Herbert, 1874-1964; Coats; Gifts
rdf:Description.dc:description: Alice Garry and Herbert Hoover pose in the corner of a room after an Indian hunting jacket has been presented to him. Alice wears beaded headband with a feather in the back, a long fringed dress, neclaces and decorated shawl. He wear a normal business suit and tie and holds the jacket. To the right can be a large planter.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Carolyn Geary Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Princess America contestants at the National Indian Congress in the Davenport Hotel, Spokane, Washington, 1925
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Libby, Charles A., Sr., 1879-1966 Libby, Charles A., Jr., 1907-1982
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Washington (State); National Indian Congress (1st : 1925 : Spokane, Wash.); Beauty contestants
rdf:Description.dc:description: Nine contestants for the Princess America title pose in the Davenport Hotel. Five sit in the front with the other four standing behind them. The first Princess America is Alice Garry standing in the back row on the right. They all wear similar clothing, headband (some with feathers, some without) and long dresses with fringe. All but one have earrings.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Charles A. Libby & Son Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Yakama family named Yallup at the National Indian Congress, Spokane, Washington, 1925
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Guilbert, Frank W., d. 1940
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Yallup family; Group portraits--Washington (State); Yakama Indians--Arts & crafts; Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress; National Indian Congress (1st : 1925 : Spokane, Wash.); McCoy, Alex
rdf:Description.dc:description:
The Yallup family, Chief William Yallup, Mrs. William Yallup, and Tom Yallup (son of Chief William Yallup), stand on a street in Spokane by a pillar. They wear mostly Western style clothing with wide rimmed hats and scarves around their necks. Mrs. Yallup wears a scarf around her head, a blanket around her shoulders and carries two bags. Behind them three men are visible
The man standing behind the Yallup family to their left is Alex McCoy. (Identified by Virginia Beavert, Yakama elder)
rdf:Description.dc:source: Frank W. Guilbert Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chemawa Indian Training School, Salem, Oregon
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemawa Indians--Children; Indian Training School
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Large group of young boys pose in the front gate and white picket fence of the Indian Training School. They all wear uniforms consisting of hat with brim, jacket, knickers, and boots. In the background the school building can be seen with trees on either side.
Caption on image: 1583 - Entrance to Indian Training School, Chemawa near Salem, Oregon.
Filed in Postcards-Oregon

rdf:Description.dc:description: Two studio portraits of a young woman; on left she poses with her hair down, in a beaded & fringed dress, necklace, and beaded moccasins. rdf:Description.dc:title: Cayuse man and woman inside tepee, Oregon
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Moorhouse, Lee
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Cayuse Indians--Clothing & dress; Cayuse Indians--Arts & crafts; Drums
rdf:Description.dc:description:
An unidentified man and woman sit on a blanket in a tepee. The woman is seated on the blanket with decored bag beside her. She is wearing a print dress, blanket around her shoulders, and a necklace. Her hands are folded in her lap and a ring can be seen on her left hand. The man sits higher on a seat beside a drum with a star on it. He wears moccasins, necklaces, and arm bands. He holds a feather in his left hand.
The tepee in the background is striped.
rdf:Description.dc:source: CCM / Mrs. W.H. Cowles Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Black Eagle, Chief; Lawyer, Chief, 1796-1876--Associated objects; Portraits--Montana; Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; Nez Perce Indians--Structures; Tipis--Northwest, Pacific
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Older man in suit sits in chair holding a wide-brimmed hat in front of tepee
Caption on image: Chief Black Eagle of the Nez Perces. He fought with Joseph throughout the war and was banished to Oklahoma with the rest of the warriors. He has traveled the Lolo Trail many times. The tepee in the picture is more than a hundred years old; it was made by some of the relatives of old Chief Lawyer. Photograph courtesy of J. F. Anderson.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Fisherman at Celilo Falls, Oregon/Washington, ca. 1956-1957
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Colby, Clarence, 1894-
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Fishing--Oregon; Umatilla Indians--Subsistence activities; Celilo Falls (Or.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
One fisherman sits on a seat suspended over the water from a rope. Another sits at the end of a pier built out over the water. Several other men stand on the shore or at the beginning of the pier. All the men wear Western style clothing.
The tribe of the fishermen is not known for certain but may be Umatilla. The photo was taken in 1956 or 1957 before the Dalles Dam was built.

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hops--Washington (State); Harvesting--Washington (State); Yakama Indians--Employment
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Twenty hop pickers and two children (one a babe in arms) pose with their crop. The hops are in a large wooden crate and a large woven basket. A dog can also be seen on the lap of one of the younger pickers. All wear Western style clothing.
Back of photo states: Charley Slatkin.

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Studio portrait of two chiefs with the Indian agent named J. T. Erwin. The chiefs are seated with Erwin standing behind them with his hands on their shoulders. On the left is Chief Moses and on the right Chief White Swan (Joe Stwire). They all wear Western style clothing.
"Compliments of Indian Agency."
Same Moses as in L85-124: "Moses, Indian Chief, died March 1900. [1899]
Note from unidentified source: Possibly from the Reisner Collection.

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Northwest, Pacific; Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Two men pose in studio in front of a painted backdrop. The seated man on left wears necklaces, plain shirt with decorations, breechcloth, beaded leggings & moccasins and holds a decorated object in his hands.. Man on right has braid decorations and wears necklaces, a striped shirt, breechcloth, beaded vest, leggings & moccasins.
Note from unidentified source: L-R. Albert Moore (seated), unidentified. ca. 1905.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture

rdf:Description.dc:title: Yakama and Wyam men in the motion picture Canyon Passage, Oregon, 1946
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress; Yakama Indians; Wyam Indians; Westerns; Canyon passage (Motion picture)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Eight men who participated in the motion picture, Canyon Passage in 1946. They are shown here in full ceremonial clothing. They are: Jobe Charley, Jim Looney, Charlie Telleish, Tommy Thompson son Henry, William Yallup (Thomas Yallup's father), Thomas Yallup, Wheeler Miller, David Miller.
Canyon Passage was a western film based on a book by Ernest Haycox, screenplay by Ernest Pascal, produced by Universal Pictures.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:description:

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cayuse/Nez Perce man known as Tauitau or Tu Ah Tway poses with headdress and other beaded objects
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tauitau; Joseph, Nez Perce Chief, 1840-1904--Family; Portraits--Oregon; Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; Cayuse Indians--Clothing & dress; Nez Perce Indians--Arts & crafts; Cayuse Indians--Arts & crafts
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Studio portrait of seated man with feathers in his hair, spotted shirt with armbands, blanket across lap & fur around neck. Set next to him are a beaded, feathered headdress, a widebrimmed hat with beaded band, a pipe, a wide-beaded collar and other objects. Painted backdrop of tree is behind him.
Note from unidentified source: Tu-Ah-Tway or 'Young Chief' as he was also known. He was a son of Allicot [Ollokot], the brother of Chief Joseph. His mother was a descendent of the famous Cayuse chief Tauitowe (as the name appears in the old histories) also called Young Chief, who was prominent in Dr. Whitman's day, also during the Cayuse War and at Gov. Stevens Walla Walla council. This man died about 1920. On account of his lineage and his personality his memory is much revered among the Umatillas and Nez Perces of the Chief Joseph strain.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nez Perce woman named Jane Silcott in formal portrait, Idaho, ca. 1890
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Silcott, Jane; Portraits--Idaho; Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; Nez Perce Indians--Women
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Studio portrait of a woman in a hat and dress with lace collar and ribbon.
Note from unidentified source: Jane Silcott, Nez Perce wife of John Silcott, shortly before her death on January 17, 1895. Silcott had come to the Lewiston country in 1860 to erect the government buildings at Fort Lapwai.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Chappie Dunning Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Spokane Indians--Clothing & dress; Portraits--Washington (State); Horses--Washington (State); National Indian Congress (1st : 1925 : Spokane, Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Jim Elisha stands in a large open plain holding the reins of his horse. He wears a feathered headdress, beaded vest, leather cuffs, and a breechcloth.
The photo was possibly taken on the Spokane Indian Reservation during the time the National Indian Congress was going on in Spokane, 1925.
Old Album #MA 9, pg. 43

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pablo, John; Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; National Indian Congress (1st : 1925 : Spokane, Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
John Pablo or Chief Three Feathers stands outside the door of a tourist service in Spokane while attending the National Indian Congress in Spokane, 1925. He wears a feathered headdress, beaded vest and cuffs and breechcloth.
The printing on the door says: Good Roads, Spokane County Good Roads Assn, Inland Automobile Assn, Eastern Washington Highway Assn, Tourist Service.
"Old Album #MA 9, pg. 62 / duplicate in Old Album #MA 18, pg. 42 (close-up)

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kutenai man named Osey Joseph & his son Moses look at historical marker, Bonner's Ferry, Idaho
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Joseph, Osey; Joseph, Moses; Group portraits--Idaho; Kutenai Indians--Clothing & dress; Historical markers--Idaho--Bonner's Ferry; Bonner's Ferry (Idaho)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Older man in fringed jacket and leggings stands with small boy in feather headdress, beaded belt & leggings. He points to large stone marker; behind them can be seen a large crowd of people, and a building with the sign "Bonner's Ferry"
Inscription on marker: Down the Kootenai thence to the Pend O'reille and Spokane the railroad followed the way taken by explorer, trader and missionary. A route which from time immemorial had been the highway of the Indian.
Note from unidentified source: Osey Joseph, medicine man and Moses Joseph his son. Possibly opening of the railway line that follows old traders and missionary route

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kutenai group, 1892
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Kutenai Indians--Clothing & dress; Kutenai Indians--Structures; Abraham family; Jerome family; David family
rdf:Description.dc:description:
A group of sixteen Kutenai people posed in front of a tepee. In the back row, left to right are: Louie Abraham (Chief's father), Nicala Jerome, Abraham Raymond, Mrs. Mary Abraham, Annie Spotted Coyote, Catherine (daughter), Christine Abraham (Catherine's grandmother), Camille Abraham (Catherine's father), Mrs. Inez Jerome (wife of Nicala), Jerome Turquay. In the front row, left to right is: Simon David, Andrew Jerome, John David, Stanislau David, Aeneas, Charlie David, Ann Jerome, ?, ?, Mary Louise Abraham, Luke Sam.
Note from unidentified source: The David's are blood brothers.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Arthur B. Dunning Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture

rdf:Description.dc:title: Celilo ( Yakama) group pose in ceremonial dress at Celilo Falls, Oregon
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Oregon; Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress; Fishing--Oregon--Celilo Falls; Celilo Falls (Or.); Thompson, Henry; Thompson, Henry, Mrs.; Thompson, Tommy
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Group of men women & children pose in front of the falls, wearing fringed and beaded clothing. Several of the men and boys wear feather headdresses, and the women wear beaded headbands. Taken before the Falls were inundated by the Dalles Dam in 1957.
Caption on image: Indians in costume at Celilo Falls, Oregon. #54.
Virginia Beavert a Yakama elder, kindly provided the following identifications: the men on the right are, from right to left, Henry Thompson, to his left Tommy Thompson, main chief at Celilo. To the left of Tommy Thompson was his first wife. The woman holding the child on the far left is Mrs. Henry Thompson. The woman to the right of her, was from White Swan, but her name is unknown.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

Two older women pose with two small girls in front of a striped tepee. The girls are in sweaters & slacks, the woman on the right wears a scarf on her head, a tunic and skirt, necklaces and plain moccasins. The woman on the left wears an apron over a print dress and plain moccasins.
Note from unidentified source: L-R. Sophie Red Duck, ?, ?, Sophie Broncheau

rdf:Description.dc:title: Covada post office and general store, Covada, Washington, ca. 1908
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Palmer, Frank, 1864-1920
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Covada (Wash.); Colville Indian Reservation (Wash.); Streets--Washington (State)--Covada; General stores--Washington (State)--Covada; Post offices--Washington (State)--Covada; Automobiles--American--Washington (State)--Covada; Nickens, A. B.
rdf:Description.dc:description:
View of the a street in Covada looking at the front of the post office and the A B Nicken General Merchandise. A sign also indicates that A B Nickens is a notary public. A car is parked in front, various men stand on the porch in front of the store, and a horse rides up the "street." To the right in the distance is a barn and further away a house. Sign on store says "telephone exchange".
Covada is located in the Colville Indian Reservation in Ferry County just east of Kewa on the Silver Springs Road.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Jerome Peltier Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Colville writing by teenager named Fannie Wynecoop writing, Fort Spokane, Washington
rdf:Description.dc:subject: First aid in illness and injury; Colville Indians--Health & welfare; Health education--Washington (State)--Fort Spokane
rdf:Description.dc:description:
This may have been some kind of test. It was written by a 17 year old Colville girl.
List compiled by Fannie Wynecoop entitled: What to do in case of accidents. The text reads: 1. For nose bleeds put ice or anything as cold as you can get just back of the neck. Roll a small piece of paper up and place under the upper lip. Hold the arms as high above the head as possible and make the patient hold his head up. 2. For frost bite rub snow on the injured part and do not go near a fire or in a warm room. 3. For sprained ankles or any other joints keep hot cloths on the injured part and if you can't get a doctor try to get it in place as soon as possible. 4. For sun stroke keep the head cool the same as in nose bleeds and do not give anything cold to drink but give something warm. 5. In case of fainting give the patient plenty of fresh air and loosen all tight clothing, sprinkle a little cold water on face. 6. In case of apoplexy keep the head up. 7. In case of a hemmorage of any kind to keep quiet is the main thing. 8. For cuts of any kind keep everything clean to avoid puss gathering. For a bad cut on the arm for instance bind tight with a stout string or cloth above the cut.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Estelle Reel Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

At the top of the page it says: "Original problem, Walter McClung, Age 16 years, Tribe Colville, Spokane Wash, June 12, 1902. Walter McClung bought of The Crescent Co Spokane" It then lists ten items bought and what each costs. The total of all the good purchased is $47.50.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Estelle Reel Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Colville student, Willie Warren's original math problem, Fort Spokane, Washington
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Warren, Willie; Colville Indians--Education; Mathematics
rdf:Description.dc:description: An original math problem, probably done as a school assignment. At the top of the page it says: "Original problem, Willie Warren, Age 12 years, Tribe Colville". The math problem entails selling some land and investing the proceeds to determine the interest earned after 5 years, 6 months. 16 acres sold and proceeds saved for 5 years, 6 months equaled $6020.13.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Estelle Reel Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kutenai people that attended a land sale meeting, Bonners Ferry, Idaho, 1927
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Idaho; Kutenai Indians--Government relations; Land use--Idaho--Bonner's Ferry; Chiquiet, Pierre Eneas; Adams, Francis; David, John; Adams, Lucy; Isadore, Narcisse; Sam, Mary; Francis, Simon
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Seven Kutenai people pose for a group photo after a meeting in which they were told their lands were to be sold. Most Indian participants left but these seven stayed until the meeting was over. Left to right they are: Pierre Eneas Chiquiet (or Chiqui), Francis Adams, John David, Lucy Adams, Chief Narcisse Isadore, Mary Sam and Simon Francis.
They all wear Western style clothing.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Arthur B. Dunning Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kutenai people that attended conference with Capt. John Webster, Bonner's Ferry, Idaho, May 31, 1911
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Idaho; Kutenai Indians--Government relations; Kutenai Indians--Education; Webster, John McAdam, 1849-1921; Chiquiet, Isadore
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Thirtyeight people who attended a meeting between the Kootenai and Capt. John Webster, U.S. Indian Agent, pose in front of a building. The meeting was held at Bonner's Ferry in the A.J. Kents Real Estate Office. Mr. kent was acting on behald of the Kootenais so the government could build a school for them. The chief of the Kootenais from 1900-1916, Isidore Chiquiet held the meeting with Capt. Webster, an agent of the Colville Indian Agency, Colville Indian Reservation. In order to have the school built, Chiquiet agreed to have his tribe enrolled under the Colville Agency.
The people picture are: (left to right, front to back) Chief Isadore Chiquiet, Saul Chiquiet (nephew of Isadore), Osay Joseph (son of Chief Chiquiet), John David, Simon David, Tamia Abraham, Moyse (or Moses) Paul, Terry Isadore (son of Chief), Kalile Baptiste, Osnay Ironpaddle (Cutsack), Sophie David, Alice David, Charlotte Alexander, Baptiste Cutsack, Rosalie Alexander, Takla Adams, Charlie David, Michelle Temo, Stanislaus David (known also as John Mosquito), Phillip Cutsak, Abel Alexander, Alexander Kanaka, Paul (only has one name), Moise (or Moses) Chiquiet, Pierre Neo Alexander, Captain Webster, Mary David, Ann Temo, Atha David, Simon Francis, Narcisse Isadore (son of Chief), Pierre Adams, Terry Chiquiet (know as Joseph), Pierre Chiquiet, Stanish Adam, David (no other name), Stanislaus Pierrson.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Arthur B. Dunning / Kaye Hale Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Annie's Katie, a basket weaver, seated on a mat in front of a fishing net hanging on a hut; she wears a scarf on her head, a blanket around her shoulders, and basket making materials sit before her. Same woman in NA858.
Notes from unknown source: "The basketweaver. Here is Annie's Katie, a basket weaver in front of her wikiup on the beach near Everett. Katie's daughter Susie will be known as Katie's Susie. When Susie in course of time has a little daughter and her name happens to be Mary, then she'll be known as Susie's Mary, and so right down the line. A real old Indian custom.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Yakama/Umatilla Chief Shet-a-mo-on-e, Washington, ca. 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Rutter, Thomas H.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Shet-a-mo-on-e--Associated objects; Portraits--Washington (State); Umatilla Indians--Clothing & dress; Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress; Yakama Indians--Structures; Tipis--Washington (State)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Shet-a-mo-on-e, a noted Yakama chief stands holding pipe, wearing horned headdress, decorated tunic & leggings, beaded moccasins; photographed standing in front of buffalo-skin tepee. Same man in NA611
Caption on image: 'Shet-a-mo-on-e'. A noted chief of Yakimas. Copyrighted by Rutter. 1900. The Tepee is buffalo skins.
Note on verso of photograph: Shut-a-mo-ne, Sheep Cross Horns. This Indian is half Yakima and half Umatilla. His uncle was an Umatilla Chief. He served with U.S. Troops during the Bannock war of 1878, and killed the Bannock chief, and brought his head back to the camp of General Howard. He prevented the Umatillas from joining the hostiles and Bannocks in war against the whites. He dies several years ago, and at the big potlatch his war horse and nearly all his belongings were given to Shut-a-mo-ne, his nephew, he being the nearest living relative. It is the Umatilla Chief's dress that is now worn by Shut-a-mo-ne as shown in this picture.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Thomas H. Rutter Collection no. 287 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Tlingit healer and female patient pose in a reenactment of a healing ceremony. He wears a beaded shirt, a horned headdress & a nose ring; he holds rattle and painted bone. The patient is covered by, and lying on fur blankets, an ax by her side. In background are a Chilkat blanket and two small totems. Copy print by Frank H. Nowell of a photograph by W. H. Case and H. H. Draper.
Caption on image: Indian witch doctor (or Sha-man) healing a sick woman. Copyright 1906 by Case & Draper

rdf:Description.dc:title: Salmon drying on racks in Anvik, Alaska, 1913
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Curtis, Asahel, 1874-1941
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Athapascan Indians--Subsistence activities; Fish drying--Alaska--Anvik; Salmon--Alaska--Anvik; Fishing--A aska--Anvik; Anvik (Alaska); Salmon--Drying
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Salmon drying on racks in Anvik Alaska, 1913.
Caption on image: Curtis. Seattle, Wash. 29219.
On verso of image: Drying salmon on the lower Yukon. The coming of the salmon is the harvest time of the Indians of the Yukon. Salmon furnishes food for them and their dogs. Without dried salmon they could not maintain their dog teams and without dog teams winter travel would be impossible. Anvik, 1913.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Asahel Curtis Photo Company Collection no. 482 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bradford, John; Portraits--Oregon; Siletz Indians--Clothing & dress; Siletz Indians--Arts & crafts; Siletz Indian Reservation (Or.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Older Siletz man poses outdoors with two large obsidian blades, ca. 1890-1904. He has a woven neck ornament, and wears a feathered headdress, while holding another.
Note from p. 90 of Stephen Beckham's The Indians of Western Oregon: John Bradford of Siletz Reservation holding two obsidian blades and wearing headress decorated with woodpecker scalps.

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Older Siletz woman poses outdoors while weaving a basket, ca. 1890-1904. She has several necklaces on, and wears a close fitting woven cap.
Note from unidentified source: Woman on Siletz Reservation with twined basket she is weaving, wearing twined basketry hat, Yurok style?

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Older Siletz pose outdoors, ca. 1890-1904. Woman on far left holds basket, and wears a fur cloak. The man and women in center wear plain western-style clothing and woman on right has several necklaces on, wears a close fitting woven cap, and holds a half-finished basket. Woman in cap also in NA1510b
Notes from unidentified sources: Man and three women on Siletz Reservation; women on right and left holding baskets and one wears basketry hat; fish smoking over fire in background

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nez Perce family in camp at the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Nowell, Frank H., 1864-1950
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Washington (State); Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition (1909 : Seattle, Wash.)--People
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Nez Perce family in camp at the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition, Seattle Wash., 1909. In foreground are two men, two childen and a woman. The men wear beaded clothing and necklaces; one, with beaded arm bands, holds his rifle. The small boy wears a feathered headdress and beaded robe and belt. Others can be seen in background.
Stamped on image: E.H. Nowell, Official fotografer Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition
rdf:Description.dc:source: Alaska Yukon Pacific collection University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nez Perce children wearing dancing costumes, in front of a tepee at the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Nowell, Frank H., 1864-1950
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Washington (State); Nez Perce Indians--Children; Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; Nez Perce Indians--Dance; Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition (1909 : Seattle, Wash.)--People; Tipis
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Three Nez Perce children in dancing costumes pose in front of a tepee at the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition, Seattle Wash., 1909. All three are wearing necklaces, headdresses, and fur decorations; the small boy in front wears bells on a belt, and the small girl wears bells on her ankles and beaded moccasins.
Stamped on image: E.H. Nowell, Official fotografer Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition
On verso of photograph: Meeker's Indians
rdf:Description.dc:source: Alaska Yukon Pacific collection University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nez Perce family in dance costumes pose at the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Nowell, Frank H., 1864-1950
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Washington (State); Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; Nez Perce Indians--Dance; Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition (1909 : Seattle, Wash.)--People
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Nez Perce family (man, woman, child) in dancing costumes pose at the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition, Seattle Wash., 1909. The woman is seated next to a large drum, and wears a beaded top and necklace, and a scarf on her head. The child wears a headdress, beaded and decorated vest, moccasins and bells around the ankles. The man has a feathered headdress, necklaces and beaded armbands, bels at his knees, and beaded moccasins.
Stamped on image: E.H. Nowell, Official fotografer Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition
Note from unidentified source: Ezra Meeker's Indians
Additional information: Nez Perce couple and child on exhibit, Alaska Yukon Pacific Exposition, Seattle
rdf:Description.dc:source: Alaska Yukon Pacific collection University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tlingit Indians--Commerce; Tlingit Indians--Arts & crafts; Tlingit Indians--Women; City and town life--Alaska--Sitka
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Tlingit women selling baskets and other goods along the roadside in Sitka Alaska, ca. 1904-1908. They have set up shelters under trees, and have their wares displayed on blankets. In the middle ground, several [white] people are looking at the market; in the immediate background is a very large building, in far background are other buildings and a church. Copy print by Frank H. Nowell of a photograph by W. H. Case and H. H. Draper.

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Angeline, daughter of Chief Seattle, Seattle Washington, ca. 1891-1895. Full face head shot, subject wears a head scarf, and plaid shawl pinned around her shoulders.
On verso of image: Queen Angeline, Chief Seattle's daughter
Note from unidentified source: Kick-is-on-lo Cud was the eldest daughter of Chief Seattle. By the time this photo was taken, in the 1890s, her Suquamish and Duwamish people had been exiled to the Port Madison Reservation. White settlers renamed her Princess Angeline or Queen Angeline.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indian women, probably Tlingit, selling baskets and other crafts on beach, Treadwell, Alaska, probably between 1890 and 1897

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tlingit Indians--Commerce; Tlingit Indians--Arts & crafts; Tlingit Indians--Women; Baskets; Blankets; Treadwell (Alaska)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
After the Treadwell Mines opened in 1881, women came from nearby villages to sell baskets, beaded clothing, and other wares to the gold miners and tourists. The baskets for sale in this photograph are Tlingit in style. The Treadwell Mines were located on Douglas Island, across the channel from Juneau.
Caption on image: Indian merchants at Treadwell Mines. LaRoche Photo, Seattle, Wash.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Studio portrait of three Yakama men posed in ceremonial clothing, Washington, probably between 1894 and 1899
rdf:Description.dc:creator: La Roche, Frank
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Portraits-Washington (State); Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Studio portrait of three Yakama men, Washington, ca. 1894-1899. Two of the men are seated in wicker chairs, blankets around their waists. Man on left holds wide-brimmed hat trimmed with fur and feather, wears necklaces and earrings, fur at shoulder, with beaded bag at waist. Man on right holds plain hat, and wears necklaces. The man standing behind wears beaded vest and earrings. They are posed on a fur blanket, in front of a painted backdrop of an arbor.
Caption on image: Yakima warriors. La Roche. Seattle.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Yakama women and a Nez Perce man pose in ceremonial clothing, Washington, probably between 1894 and 1899
rdf:Description.dc:creator: La Roche, Frank
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Portraits--Washington (State); Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress; Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Studio portrait of three Yakama women and a Nez Perce man, ca. 1894-1899. Two of the women are seated in wicker chairs; the other woman and the man stand behind. The women wear blankets around their shoulders, earrings and necklaces, bracelets and rings. Beaded bags are displayed near the feet of the seated women. The man wears a decorated wide-brimmed hat, earrings, necklaces and beaded trousers and moccasins. They are posed on a fur blanket, in front of a painted backdrop of an arbor.
Caption on image: Yakima squaws & Nez Perces brave/La Roche. Seattle

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two Yakama women pose in ceremonial clothing, Washington, probably between 1894 and 1899
rdf:Description.dc:creator: La Roche, Frank
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Portraits-Washington (State); Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress; Yakama Indians--Women
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Studio portrait of two Yakama women, ca. 1894-1899. Both women wear earrings and necklaces, rings and bracelets, and have blankets around their shoulders. One woman holds a bag, and displayed on the floor in front of them is another bag and several beaded belts. They are posed in front of a painted backdrop of an arbor.
Caption on image: 430. Yakima squaws. La Roche. Seattle.

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Portraits--British Columbia; Salishan Indians--Arts & crafts; Salishan Indians--Women; Basket making--British Columbia--Vancouver Island
rdf:Description.dc:description:

rdf:Description.dc:title: Salishan basketmakers pose with baskets and carvings, Washington, probably between 1890 and 1895
rdf:Description.dc:creator: La Roche, Frank
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Washington (State); Salishan Indians--Arts & crafts; Baskets; Wood carvings--Indians of North America--Northwest Coast of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Nine Salishan basketmakers (7 women, 2 men) ca. 1890-1895. The group is seated on a woven mat, with a variety of baskets displayed in front and beside them. Several also hold baskets, including a half-finished one. Some wood carvings (possible Tlingit) including a totem, are also displayed. The group all have blankets around their shoulders, the women wear kerchiefs and the older man in front has a woven hat. They are posed in front of a painted backdrop of an arbor.
Caption on image: Siwash Indian basketmakers

rdf:Description.dc:title: Yakama couples posed in ceremonial dress, Washington, ca.1905
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Curtis, Asahel, 1874-1941
rdf:Description.dc:subject: White Swan, Chief; Water, George; Group portraits--Washington (State); Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Studio portrait of two older Yakama couples, ca. 1900-1910. One couple identified as Chief White Swan and his wife Martha. The other man identified as George Water, a regular ordained minister in the Columbia River conference and his wife.
The minister wears western style dress. The other man and two women are in ceremonial dress. The man wears a fur and feather headdress & jacket with fur decorations over western style dress; the two women wear the basket-style hats, beaded bags, necklaces and blankets over their shoulders. They are posed in front of a painted backdrop.
On verso of image: Chief White Swan and his wife, Martha (Geo. Water) a regular ordained minister in the Columbia River conference and his wife.

Note from unidentified source: Front row, right to left: Ta-lo-ah, Chi-poo, Edwin Haijut's mother-in-law, John Markishtum's grandmother, Edwin Haijut's mother, Cla-ko-kuk, Jennie Howe, unknown; Back, right to left: Nora Barker's father's aunt, unknown, Queen Annie, Mrs. James Guy or Yarlado, Lida Colfax's great-grandmother, Ush-la-baht, three unknowns.

rdf:Description.dc:description:

Caption on image: Copyrighted 1900. No.520. 'Dal Tim Shaw Yakima Indian Chief'
Note on verso of image: Dal-Tim-Shaw, Yakima Indian Chief. This head-dress is made of eagle feathers and is very expensive. The bonnet was made by Cheyenne Sioux for this Indian. His dress is velvet and beads.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indian camp with canoes on the Seattle waterfront, Washington, ca. 1898.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--Puget Sound Region--Structures; Indians of North America--Puget Sound Region--Transportation; Indian encampments--Washington (State)--Seattle; Waterfronts--Seattle (Wash.); Canoes
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Indian encampment on beach of Puget Sound at Seattle, ca. 1897-1900. Canoes are pulled up onto beach; tents on beach, small structures and houses can be seen in background. Men women and children move about the camp.
Caption on image: 1010
Notes from unidentified source: Arrival of Indians for hop-picking. A large part of the harvesting labor was by the Indians of the Sound, and British Columbia coast. These Indians came in great canoe brigades and camped on the waterfront. This Indian camp was on the Seattle waterfront below Vine, Cedar and Broad streets. This is now the location of the Bell Street Terminals of Port of Seattle.
PH Coll 285.40
Also in Prosch Album, v. 2, no. 22
rdf:Description.dc:source: Anders Beer Wilse Collection. PH Coll 285 Prosch Indian Albums. PH Coll 18 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Makah couple haul canoe ashore after fishing, Neah Bay, Washington, 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Neah Bay (Wash.); Makah Indians--Transportation; Makah Indians--Clothing & dress; Makah Indians--Subsistence activities; Canoes; Neah Bay (Wash.); Salmon fishing
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Man and woman on beach at Neah Bay, 1900. He is pulling a canoe with folded sail, and fishing gear onto beach; she holds fish, with blanket wrapped around her body, and scarf on her head. Island visible in background.
Caption on image: Copyrighted 1900
Note from unidentified source: The Makah people of the Olympic Peninsula built small canoes for fishing. In this photo, taken around 1900 by Anders Wilse, a Makah fisherman has just brought his canoe in to the beach at Neah Bay. The woman has unloaded two large salmon. She will clean the fish and smoke or dry it to eat later.
PH Coll 285.39
Also in Prosch Album
rdf:Description.dc:source: Anders Beer Wilse Photographs. PH Coll 285 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tlingit totem pole is unveiled at Pioneer Square, Seattle, Washington, October 18, 1899
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilse, Anders B.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Totem poles--Washington (State)--Seattle ; Tlingit Indians--Arts & crafts; Pioneer Square (Seattle, Wash.); Seattle (Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
A large crowd waits in Pioneer Square for the dedication of the totem pole, 1899. The pole stands beside an intersection, and is surrounded by people and stands for a fireworks display. Wagons, trolley car and buildings of Pioneer Square visible in background. Viewed from east.
Caption on image: Unveiling the totem pole on Pioneer Square, Seattle, Oct 18, '99
Note from Museum of History and Industry: The totem pole at Pioneer Square has been a Seattle landmark since 1899. That year, a group of Seattle businessmen visited a Tlingit village in Alaska. They thought the village was deserted and removed a 50-foot tall totem pole as a souvenir. The men brought the pole back to Seattle and had it set up in Pioneer Square. They were later fined for the theft of the pole. After being damaged by fire in 1938, it was replaced by a duplicate pole carved by Tlingit craftsmen.
PH Coll 285.64
rdf:Description.dc:source: Anders Beer Wilse Photographs. PH Coll 285 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gitksan totem pole featuring a canoe in front of house, Kispiox, British Columbia, 1909
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Emmons, George Thornton
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Totem poles--British Columbia--Kispiox; Gitksan Indians--Arts & crafts; Gitksan Indians--Structures; Kispiox (B.C.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
House with totem pole in grass in front of house
Pole of Naegt (Haray) at Kispiox, called Attached-Within. Figures: Eagle-prince at top; Thunderbird; Haida Chief Bull-Head, father of Naegt, who was murdered by his Gitksan wife; Lutraiscek's canoe, a miniature Haida dug-out transversal to pole and resting on two pegs. Carved by Larhilemhot Wolf phratry
More information about this location available in: Totem poles of the Gitksan / Marius Barbeau (p. 117-118)

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gitksan totem pole in front of house, beside an orca carving, Kispiox, British Columbia, 1909
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Emmons, George Thornton
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Totem poles--British Columbia--Kispiox; Gitksan Indians--Arts & crafts; Gitksan Indians--Structures; Kispiox (B.C.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Pole in front of house, next to dilapidated platform; orca figure (also in NA3383) can be seen next to it.
Pole belonging to Qael at Kispiox; Leading-in, a being with a human face and what is described as a very large mouth. The crest Leading-in is repeated three times on the pole, twice in lower part, once at top; second figure is Grizzly Bear woman; next is Dzaraurhlaw, mythological person with a long beak-like nose. Pole carved by Wawsemlarhee of the same phratry, Kispayaks.
More information about this location available in: Totem poles of the Gitksan / Marius Barbeau (p. 117-118)
rdf:Description.dc:source: George Thornton Emmons Collection no. 131 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gitksan totem pole featuring frogs, in front of house, Kispiox, British Columbia, 1909
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Emmons, George Thornton
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Totem poles--British Columbia--Kispiox; Gitksan Indians--Arts & crafts; Gitksan Indians--Structures; Kispiox (B.C.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Pole in front of house, with several frog carvings at base.
Pole belonging to Ma'us at Kispiox, called Frog-pole. Figures: Raven (which formerly sat on top), 7-8 foot uncarved section, Person-of-the-smoke-hole or Man-looking-down-the-smoke-hole, Frog or Tadpole (head downwards), Woodpecker or Real-Woodpecker, Man-of-the-smoke-hole, Frogs-jammed-up or squeezed. Carved by Wawsemlarhae, Fireweed phratry.
More information about this location available in: Totem poles of the Gitksan / Marius Barbeau (p. 117-118)

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gitksan totem poles in front of house, people passing behind it, Kitsegukla, British Columbia, 1910
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Emmons, George Thornton
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Totem poles--British Columbia--Kitsegukla; Gitksan Indians--Arts & crafts; Gitksan Indians--Structures; Kitsegukla (B.C.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Totem pole with bird at top stands in front of small house. A man and woman packing items on their backs can be seen passing behind it.
Pole of Harhpegwawtu at Kitsegukla called Decayed-corpse. Figures: at top, Bird-on-high; the three rows of small figures are dead people caled many-small-people or many-skulls at the bottom is Decayed-corpse, the bill or projecting nose has broken off.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gitksan boy poses with dog in front of totem pole, Kitsegukla, British Columbia, 1910
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Emmons, George Thornton
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Totem poles--British Columbia--Kitsegukla; Gitksan Indians--Arts & crafts; Gitksan Indians--Structures; Gitksan Indians--Children; Kitsegukla (B.C.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Totem pole with bird and brood in center; a small boy holding dog on leash poses in front of it, houses seen behind it.
Pole belonging to Ksraromlarhae at Kitsegukla. Figures: Kuksdedalreh, head of a subdivision of this family, in whose commemoration the pole was erected; on his head, the ceremonial hat of Tsagyem-hanak (not visible in this photograph); Winged-person, twice repeated, the lower holding a small human in his claws; in center is Grouse with its brood.
More information about this location available in: Totem poles of the Gitksan / Marius Barbeau (p. 117-118)

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gitksan totem pole topped by cylindrical hat, Kitsegukla, British Columbia, 1910
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Emmons, George Thornton
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Totem poles--British Columbia--Kitsegukla; Gitksan Indians--Arts & crafts; Gitksan Indians--Structures; Kitsegukla (B.C.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Totem pole with figure in tall cylindrical hat at top; stands by several houses
Pole at Gitksan village of Kitsegukla belonging to Hanamuk, called Person-of-the-rainbow. Figures: hat with three cylinders, man represents Ramarhtseraet in whose memory pole was erected or Person-of-the-hills; Hanging-across or Half-a-man, body cut in two with head down; small circles representing the stars; the Rainbow; Rainbow-Person. Carved by Kwawzabark, Kitwanga.
More information about this location available in: Totem poles of the Gitksan / Marius Barbeau (p. 117-118)
rdf:Description.dc:source: George Thornton Emmons Collection no. 131 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division

rdf:Description.dc:description:

Pole at Kitanmox (Hazelton) belonging to Gitemraldo, possibly named Nose-like-cohoe. rdf:Description.dc:title: Gitksan totem of a cougar or mountain lion, Kitwanga, British Columbia, 1910
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Emmons, George Thornton
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Wood carvings--British Columbia--Kitwanga; Gitksan Indians--Arts & crafts; Kitwanga (B.C.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Wood carving of a large cat; possibly cougar or mountain lion. Displayed on wooden platform in clearing; man sits on platform next to pedestal. Totem pole in background. Totem also seen in NA3446
Note from unidentified source: Figure how-how of a mythical animal which is believed to have been a mountain lion or cougar that wandered north to the Skeena country and killed people; later it was killed and taken by the clan [at Kitwanga] as a crest. Here it stands as a family totem.
rdf:Description.dc:source: George Thornton Emmons Collection no. 131 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Makah Indians--Arts & crafts; Whaling; Rattles
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Hand holds carved rattle in front of cheesecloth backdrop.
Note from unidentified source: A whaler's rattle, very old, made of the jelly-bone of a whale, the rattle was employed by Makah whalers to turn a harpooned whale towards the shore should it run outward with the whaling canoe. A song was sung by the whalers in conjuction with the rattling. Property of Charles Swan, Neah Bay Indian.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Ernest B. Bertelson Collection no. 477 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Older woman sits on woven rug on grass knitting with 4 needles; several balls of yarn sit in front of her. She wears a scarf wrapped headband-style around her forehead.
Note from unidentified source: Chief William Shelton's mother, Magdaline Whea-kadim, Tulalip Washington, 1906

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tulalip family in ceremonial dress pose in Volunteer Park, Seattle, Washington, 1938
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Edson, Norman, d. 1968.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Shelton, William; Shelton, William--Family; Group portraits--Washington (State); Tulalip Indians--Clothing & dress; Tulalip Indians--Arts & crafts
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Two men, three women and boy stand in park. Older women on left both have beaded necklaces and bag, with blankets over shoulder, over dresses. One on left has beaded headband as well. Men & boy wear feathered headdresses; the men wear beaded vests, belts, moccasins and pants (younger man also has beaded arm bands). The young woman at the right has a beaded & fringed dress, beaded headband and necklaces, beaded bag and carries a blanket over her arm.
Note from unidentified source: Chief Shelton and family, from the Tulalip Reservation, before appearing on a visual-radio programme in Seattle's Volunteer Park. Left to right: Mrs. Annie Frederick, Mrs. Shelton, Chief Shelton, Wayne Williams (grandson), Silas George (drowned), Harriete Shelton Dover.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Norman Edson Collection no. 475 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
