rdf:Description.dc:description: Notes from other sources: William We-ah-lup, an ancient Siwash Indian, smoking salmon and salmon eggs on a beach on Puget Sound. At the time this picture was taken William was estimated as being close to a hundred years of age.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Snohomish couple in temporary summer house, Puget Sound, Washington, 1905
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Edson, Norman, d. 1968.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Washington (State); Snohomish Indians--Subsistence activities; Snohomish Indians--Structures; Indian encampments--Washington (State); Salmon--Drying
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Man and woman sit in their beach hut, by fire, under fish smoking rack. She is knitting, with yarn in woven basket.
Note from unidentified source: Snohomish Indians on Puget Sound, during the summer in 1905--before and after--erected temporary dwellings on the shore composed of rush mats and pieces of canvas, and hung their salmon catch on beams above a camp fire to be smoked and cured for the winter months.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Norman Edson Collection no. 475 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Older man and woman on beach next to painted canoe. She sits on a log, next to a large a salmon on woven mat. Man stands looking down at fish. Canoes in background.
Note from unidentified source: The fish story. Tulalip Indians. Two Indians of the Snohomish tribe at Tulalip Reservation and their dugout canoes. Snohomish couple at Tulalip Reservation with canoes and freshly caught fish; probably William We-ah-lup. [NA709]

rdf:Description.dc:description:

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Angeline, daughter of Chief Seattle, Seattle Washington, ca. 1885-1896. She is seated on porch of very small wooden home. She wears a head scarf, and shawl pinned around her shoulders, over plaid skirt. A small dog sits up next to her.
Caption on image: Princess Angeline, daughter of Chief Seattle
Notes from other source: Princess Angeline daughter of Chief Seattle, at her cottage, foot of Pike Street. [Kick-is-on-lo Cud was the eldest daughter of Chief Seattle]

rdf:Description.dc:description:

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nez Perces Chief Joseph's tombstone, Colville Indian Reservation, Washington, 1905
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Curtis, Edward S., 1868-1952
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Joseph, Nez Perce Chief, 1840-1904--Tomb; Group portraits--Washington (State); Nez Perce Indians--Monuments; Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; Tombs & sepulchral monuments--Washington (State); Colville Indian Reservation (Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Three men in full ceremonial dress and a man in military uniform stand on a small wooden platform before the new tombstone. Two of the men have full feathered headdresses, the 3rd wears a fur & horns headdress. Their clothing is decorated and beaded, and man nearest camera holds a pipe. (Same man in NA617) A blanket lays beside them on the platform. Wooden fence is visible in the background. Tombstone inscription facing the camera reads: He led his people in the Nez Perce War of 1877. Died Sept. 21, 1904. Aged about 60 years..

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Man in full ceremonial dress (full-length feathered headdress, decorated and beaded clothing, holding a pipe). Same man in NA614. Men & women in western-style dress visible in background. Tombstone inscription facing the camera reads: He led his people in the Nez Perce War of 1877. Died Sept. 21, 1904. Aged about 60 years.
Note from With One Sky Above Us by M. Gidley, plate 44: Yellow Bull standing with bowed head at reburial of Chief Joseph..

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Two women with scarves on their heads, and shawls pinned over their shoulders sit on small porch. Woman on right sits at spinning wheel, spinning the wool; woman on left is carding wool with two carders. Basket holds uncarded wool and several half-finished socks, on floor are bundled knitted socks.
Caption on image: Curtis. 895. Copyrighted 1898.
Note from unidentified source: Two women carding & spinning wool at Tulalip, with knitted socks and coiled basket in foreground; woman on right may be William Shelton's mother.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tulalip man named William Shelton carving a totem pole, Tulalip Indian Reservation, Washington, ca. 1910
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Brady, Ferdinand
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Shelton, William; Portraits--Washington (State); Tulalip Indians--Arts & crafts; Totem poles--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Wood carving--Washington (State)--Tulalip Indian Reservation; Tulalip Indian Reservation (Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
In workshop, man in overalls and cap carves figure on reclining totem pole. Man in flannel shirt and hat watches. [The totem pole that Shelton is carving was for the Tulalip Indian School. It was raised in 1912, but broke in two. It now stands in two pieces in front of Tulalip Elementary School on the Tulalip Reservation. In the
photo you can see the figures identified by Shelton as "Indian Chief Yay-bah-dad," the Bear, and the Snake. Per: David Cort]
Caption on image: William Shelton carving a totem pole - Tulalip Wash.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two Nez Perce women, identified as sisters, Colville Indian Reservation, Washington, ca. 1900-1910.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Latham, Edward H.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Washington (State); Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; Nez Perce Indians--Women; Blankets; Bags; Beadwork
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Two young women sit on chairs dressed with earrings, necklaces, moccasins. They each hold cornhusk bags.
Caption on negative sleeve: Two squaws with beadwork.
Note from unidentified source: Two sisters holding cornhusk bags, probably Nez Perce.
Note from researcher: These are the daughters of Jim Billy and his wife Yumatwy (Eyomotwy). They are Alpiato Billy (Billie) aka Alpiato or Alice Waters aka Wash-e-tone-my and Annie Billy (Billie) aka Yupchasin or Upchasin aka Wa-hem-pum. They are my paternal grand-aunts - sisters to my grandfather, Tom Billy. There is at least one other picture of them together. Alpiato is the mother of Art Circle (Art's father was Charlie Wilpocken), who is also in some of the pictures in your collection.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Edward H. Latham Collection no. 409 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division

According to a short biography entitled, Chief George Allan Charley : a brief biographical sketch with anecdotes, by the Heritage Committee, Shoalwater Bay Indian Tribe, he had his head flattened as a baby following an ancient custom for those of inherited royal lineage.

rdf:Description.dc:description:
5 men, two women & 4 children pose inside a very large, one room house. Dressers line the back wall, stove, tables, chairs, household items & beds are in center of the room. Chilkat blankets can be seen in back of room, and a button blanket is hung along other back wall. One man is standing, wearing a wide hat, and a button-decorated tunic.
Caption on image: Interior Cheif [sic] Lot's house. Wrangle, Alaska. A C Pillsbury.
Copy print made from original at Seattle Public Library

rdf:Description.dc:title: Women cleaning fish on beach, possibly Tlingit, southeastern Alaska, ca. 1906
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America--Alaska--Subsistence activities; Indians of North America--Alaska--Women; Indians of North America--Alaska--Clothing & dress; Fishing--Alaska
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Women cleaning fish on rocky beach, ca. 1904-1910. They squat on beach next to several canoes (one with fish slung over side), watched by three small girls. Women have shawls tied over heads & around shoulders (over dresses); the girls stand next to boats wearing dresses, two have blankets drawn over shoulders. Toddler in wool coat & bonnet stands by woman on the left. Small wooden building and other figures on cliff in background.
Caption on image: 520-a W&S
rdf:Description.dc:source: Alaska Collection University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tlingit totem poles, canoes and a Chilkat blanket on display at Sheldon Jackson Museum, Sitka, Alaska, n.d.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Shaw, William T.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tlingit Indians--Arts & crafts; Wood carvings--Alaska--Sitka; Canoes; Weaving--Alaska--Sitka; Sheldon Jackson Museum
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Chilkat blanket, totem poles, canoes, tools, baskets & nets on display. The Chilkat robe is said to be from Killisnoo from the gravesite of a man who had adopted to Christianity and vowed to give up old customs. The robe with "Diving Whale Pattern", was donated to the museum by his family. Also pictured are two totem poles from Metlakatla that were brought to the museum in 1888 when a group of young men from Father Duncan's Christian community came to the Sitka Industrial Training School. They were about to burn the poles when Sheldon Jackson arrived to bring the young men to Sitka and asked them to spare the poles and bring them to the museum.
Note from unidentified source: In Sheldon Jackson Museum
PH Coll 587.7
rdf:Description.dc:source: Ph Coll 587. William T. Shaw Photographs University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Old Toby; Nancy; Group portraits--Washington (State) ; Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress
rdf:Description.dc:description:

Note from unidentified source: Nancy and Toby. This Indian is another Seattle. Because of his friendliness to the whites he was ostracized from his tribe. He saved the settlement here from massacre and now is a familiar figure in Ellensburg.

rdf:Description.dc:description:

Note from parish website: In 1840 Chief Sealth (Seattle) invited Fathers Blanchet and Demers to establish a mission at Suquamish. It became the second mission in the Puget Sound area. In 1855 a church was erected, and in 1904 the present St. Peter's Mission was built on the site next to the native American cemetery where Chief Sealth, a Baptized Catholic, rest.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Skokomish woman known as Big Ann or Satsop Ann, basket maker near South Bend, Washington, ca. 1903
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Skokomish Indians--Arts & crafts; Skokomish Indians--Women; Baskets--Washington (State)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Older woman sits among a variety of baskets, wearing a head scarf and a wool cloak, ca. 1900-1905
Caption on image: Big Ann, Skokomish Indian Basket Weaver. 1084 D.M.Averill & Co., Publishers, Portland Or.
Note on postcard: Sept. 4, 1906. South Bend Washington. This lady lives not far from here and today I saw some five specimens of her work in a store downtown -- but the prices were too high -- for me. My train is due in Seattle a little after 4-- I'll probably not reach U. Heights til six though. Hope to find you there and alive.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Haida totem poles and wooden structure, village of Howkan, Long Island, Alaska, ca. 1923.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Thwaites, John E.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Haida Indians--Structures; Totem poles--Alaska--Howkan
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Two Kaijani totem poles sit in front of a wooden structure. The Kaijani are a subtribe of the Haida Indians. Caption on image: Thwaites 5859. Indian totems at a deserted village, Alaska
Note from unidentified source: Commemorative poles from Howkan. On left, pole symbolizing a long tale of a man (sitting between the ears of the bear at the base of the pole) who turned into a sea monster (above him) and who was betrayed by his mother-in-law (the small figure with headdress and ring rattles). On right, a mortuary pole with blackfish on top and bear at the base. These poles belonged to the same lineage. They were copied for the Hydaburg totem park.
In Garfield Volume 1, leaf 35

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nisqually man named Yelm Jim, Washington, ca.1890
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Yelm Jim; Portraits--Washington (State); Nisqually Indians--Clothing & dress; Pacific Coast Indians, Wars with, 1847-1865
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Survivor of the Puget Sound Indian War, Yelm Jim [Wa-he-lut or Wahoolit] poses for portrait, ca. 1880-1900. Seated in wooden chair, on fur skin, in front of a hung blanket; there is a skull set on the table beside him, he holds a rifle and wears a pouch around neck over shirt, patched pants and moccasins.
Caption in album: "Wahoolit", or "Yelm Jim" a Nisqually Indian. He fought with Leschi in 1855-56. He killed Sluggia, Leschi's betrayer [and nephew]. Sentenced to be hung, he was pardoned on the day set for execution
In Prosch Indian Album, v. 2, no. 30
rdf:Description.dc:source: Prosch Indian Albums. PH Coll 18 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Varous sized cedar houses along beach; canoes and boats drawn up on beach along with cut logs
Caption on image: 1081 Wilse. Street in Indian village
Caption in album: Indian village on west coast of Washington in 1897. The only commercial resource of these people seems to be fish. To any but the people born and raised in them these villages are dirty...malodorous and altogether unlovely. The inhabitants, however, are more comfortable in them than they would be in Seattle or Paris.

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Man in feathered headress, decorated braids, knit shirt, plaid breechcloth, decorated leggings & beaded moccasins stands before three tepees. Nearby are several wagons and horses.
Caption on mount: Chief Joseph and his tepee, in fall of 1903. By Dr. Latham

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nez Perce medicine dance, Washington, 1903
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Latham, Edward H.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Washington (State); Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; Nez Perce Indians--Spiritual life; Nez Perce Indians--Dance; Shamans--Washington (State)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Small group of men and women sit in circle with man in ceremonial dress dancing off to the right, ca. 1900-1905. The small circle is surrounded by a much larger circle of men & women, standing & seated, some on horseback. In background are nine tepees and a low wooden building.
Caption on mount: Medicine dance of the Nez Perce Indians. The great Doctor Two Moons is pictured as dancing on right of group
Prosch Indian Album, v. 1, no. 11

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nez Perces Walla-qua-mit and Jim White stand with Umatilla man named Chu-ya, 1903
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Latham, Edward H.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Group portraits--Northwest, Pacific; Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; Nez Perce Indians--Structures; Umatilla--Clothing & dress; Tipis--Northwest, Pacific
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Three men in ceremonial dress pose on Pendelton rug near a tepee, ca. 1900-1910. Each man holds a blanket over his left arm, and wears braid decorations, leggings and beaded moccasins. Man in center wears a decorated jacket, the men on either side of him wear plain shirts, necklaces and arm bands. In background are a number of other tepees in semi circle.
Note from unidentified source: left to right: Walla-qua-mit, Nez Perce; Chu-ya, Umatilla; Jim White, Nez Perce, younger brother of White Bird
Caption on mount: Three Nez Perce bucks

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Kneeling man in front of five women standing together by tepee flap, ca. 1900-1905. He has a wide-brimmed hat, vest over plain shirt and jeans, the women wear dresses, skirts & blouses; the two on the left have scarves covering their hair. A horse and wagons are visible in background.
Caption in album: A group of Snake Rivers
Note from unidentified source: possibly Bannocks or a mixed group of Colvilles and Nez Perces. Colville Reservation

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Three photographs on album page, ca. 1900-1910. Top left: Woman with child in blanket on back poses with small boy & girl near lake. Bottom left: Infant in cradleboard attached to side of saddle on horse, tethered in street in Chelan. Right: Men, woman & children pose looking off to right beside tent in cleared area. Man standing in front of group has a blanket wrapped around his waist.
Captions in album: Photo on top left: Chelan Indians on the lake shore. Photo on bottom left: Cradled on the side of a horse on Woodin Avenue, town of Chelan. Photo on right: Chelan Indians camping in woods near lake.

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Wapato John; Wapato John, Mrs.; Bob, Julia; Group portraits--Washington (State); Chelan Indians--Clothing & dress; Chelan Indians--Transportation
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Two photographs on album page, ca. 1900-1910. Left: Older man and woman in wooden chairs on porch; he is in a long overcoat, she has a scarf on her head and a ruffled dress. Right: Young woman in plaid dress (with blanket over knees) sits on horseback with man in wide-brimmed hat, vest & neckerchief.
Captions in album: Photo on left: Wapato John and wife, at home near Chelan. The Wapato family is one of much local distinction. John is very old, blind and religious. He preaches every Sunday, usually twice or thrice. Photo on right: Julia Bob, member of a well-known Chelan family

Right: studio portrait of man in wide-brimmed hat, jacket and black silk neckerchief
Caption in album: There are other first family people, tho, and here are some of them

rdf:Description.dc:description:

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Thwaites, John E.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Totem poles--Alaska--Kasaan; Haida Indians--Structures
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Totem poles and houses in wooded area, ca. 1910-1915.
Note from unidentified source: Old Kasaan. Three tall poles on right taken to New Kasaan and repaired for Totem Pole Park. Note entrance through base of lef-hand pole, once the doorway of the house. Second pole from right has the figure of a white man on the top. His Haida wife dedicated the pole to him.
In Garfield Volume 3, leaf 21
rdf:Description.dc:source: Viola Garfield Collection no.130 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Haida totem pole owned by Chief Scowl, Kasaan, Alaska, ca. 1923.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Thwaites, John E.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Totem poles--Alaska--Kasaan; Haida Indians--Structures
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Totem pole leans against wooden structure in wooded area, ca. 1923.
Note from unidentified source: Chief Scowl pole, Kasaan, removed to Ketchikan in 1938. On it is carved the god of the white man on top, an angel, a priest, a Russian eagle and a priest at the base, a depiction of Chief Scowl's conception of, and contempt for, the white man's gods. Note charred remains of houseposts and beam burned in 1915.
In Garfield Volume 3, leaf 83a
rdf:Description.dc:source: Viola Garfield Collection no.130 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nez Perce named Pio Pio Ta'likt or Peo-peo Thalekt, Washington, ca. 1898
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Thalekt, Peo Peo; Portraits--Washington (State); Nez Perce Indians--Clothing & dress; ; ; Colville Indian Reservation (Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
On verso of image: Peo-peo-ta-lik, Nez perce warrior of 1877
Man poses in front of sheet, standing on a blanket, ca. 1890-1905. He is wearing a choker-style necklace, white tunic shirt, decorated leggings, and a feathered and be-furred pelt around his waist. He holds a carved pipe, and beside his are displayed a carved stick and a beaded bag. A wide-brimmed hat lays on blanket, the beaded band on hat appears to say "...Peo T[ha]l'ke". Same man in L93-72.111, L97-6.3, N949
Reference number for image in collection no. 564: Aa-18

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tlingit village along the waterfront, Angoon, Alaska, October 1945.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Garfield, Viola Edmundson, 1899-
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tlingit Indians--Structures; Totem poles--Alaska--Angoon; Villages--Alaska--Angoon
rdf:Description.dc:description: On verso of image: Angoon, Alaska. View of houses along shore. House with small covered porch showing between two others is one on which a painting similar to that illustrated in Emmons, Art of the Northwest Coast, p. 291, occurs. It was a double whale painted over and barely visible when I was in Angoon in 1945. It was John Nelson's house.

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Shakes, Chief Charles Jones; Shakes family--Homes & haunts; Canoes--Tlingit Indians--Alaska--Wrangell; Totem poles--Alaska--Wrangell
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Canoe in water with people and American flag; smaller canoe is beside it. House and totem poles are in the background, 1916.
Caption on image: Chief Shake's house, totems and war canoe, Wrangell, Alaska
Note from Garfield Volume: The Wrangell Sentinell, May 31, 1940 states "Chief Shakes, 5th from bow; taken shortly before his death in 1916. Rev. S. Hall Young, 3rd from bow; he established Presbyterian mission in Wrangell, 1878. This photo found among Shake's possessions.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tlingit totem pole top, Wrangell, Alaska, 1940.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Garfield, Viola Edmundson, 1899-
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tlingit Indians; Totem poles--Alaska--Wrangell
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Note from Garfield Volume: Top figure on the pole in front of Chief Shake's house, Wrangell. The chief's ancestor with the double blackfish hat obtained from the Nass Tsimshian in the famed battle of the Stikine. Below the top figure is the groundhog. Note the openings in the back of the pole. These were originally used as repositories for the ashes of the deceased and the pole was a mortuary or memorial pole. Axel Ramussen says the natives always identify this as Gonaqadate.
In Garfield Volume 10, leaf 17
rdf:Description.dc:source: Viola Garfield Collection no. 130 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division

rdf:Description.dc:title: Yakama/Umatilla Chief Shet-a-mo-on-e, Spokane, Washington, ca. 1900
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Rutter, Thomas H.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Shet-a-mo-on-e; Portraits--Washington (State); Umatilla Indians--Clothing & dress; Yakama Indians--Clothing & dress; ; Tipis--Washington (State)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Man in ceremonial dress poses in studio, in front of painted backdrop, ca. 1900. He is holding pipe & bag, and wearing horned headdress, plain shirt, decorated leggings, plain breechcloth. Same man in NA628
Note on verso of NA628: Shut-a-mo-ne, Sheep Cross Horns. This Indian is half Yakima and half Umatilla. His uncle was an Umatilla Chief. He served with U.S. Troops during the Bannock war of 1878, and killed the Bannock chief, and brought his head back to the camp of General Howard. He prevented the Umatillas from joining the hostiles and Bannocks in war against the whites. He died several years ago, and at the big potlatch his war horse and nearly all his belongings were given to Shut-a-mo-ne, his nephew, he being the nearest living relative.
PH Coll 287.15
rdf:Description.dc:source: Thomas H. Rutter Photograph Collection. PH Coll 287 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tlingit totem pole in front of wooden structure, Wrangell, Alaska
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Totem poles--Alaska--Wrangell; Tlingit Indians--Structures
rdf:Description.dc:description: On verso of image: Totem at Wrangell. Picture given to Viola E. Garfield by Mrs. J.W. Young, Ketchikan 8/12/40. This pole was owned by A. Rasmussen, Skagway. See Niblack, Coast Indians, Plate LXV, fig. 347. The top figure is beaver and not the bear. Rasmussen says the three figures below the beaver were carved separately and nailed to the pole at a later time. It may be that there were two poles though. This is not likely. Niblack says: "Grave of Chief Shustocks on Shustock's Point, opposite Wrangell. Pole is surmounted by black bear." It is in front of a square house with a high platformed square under the roof. Pole bought by Terr. Museum, Juneau from Rasmussen's estate - Oct. 1945.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Viola Garfield Collection no. 130 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

Notes from unidentifed sources: Canoes, Coupeville. These Indians came to solve a knotty question -- i.e. allow white men to remove their ceremony? Whidbey Island beach.
PH Coll 376.125
rdf:Description.dc:source: Oliver S. Van Olinda Photograph Collection. PH Coll 376 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tlingit totem pole and wooden structures, Saxman, Alaska, ca. 1922.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Thwaites, John E.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Totem poles--Alaska--Saxman; Tlingit Indians--Structures
rdf:Description.dc:description: On verso of image: Modern short pole, obviously posed for this photograph. The whale at the top and Raven at the base diving under the ocean are the only certainly identifiable figures. The cross grooves in the ears of the figures suggests a Haida carver, but the whole style is degenerate. The mountain in the background appears to be Deer, a mountain back of Ketchikan. If so, the pole was photographed in Saxman.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Viola Garfield Collection no. 130 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Two men wearing boots and overalls stand on either side of wooden figure. Mountain, logs, house, and telephone pole show in the background. Figure on tope of pole being raised in NA3807.Taken at same time as NA 3807. Brown also in NA3836
Note from unidentified source: Abraham Lincoln, copied by Forest Service craftsmen at Saxman in 1940; original from Tongass village. This pole is called Proud Raven by the natives after the figure at the bottom of the pole. James Starrish and Charles Brown, two of the carvers, stand beside the figure.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quinault graveyard across the Quinault River from Taholah, Washington, probably 1885
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Willoughby, Sarah, 1841-1913
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Drawings; Quinault Indians--Spiritual life; Tombs & sepulchral monuments--Washington (State)--Quinault Reservation; Cemeteries--Washington (State)--Quinault Reservation; Quinault Reservation (Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
From unidentified material: Indian graveyard across the river from the village of Quinault (now renamed Taholah). In the large ocean-going canoe are the remains of eight brothers and sisters out of one family. When an Indian died and before the corpse was cold a rope was put under the knees and around the back of the neck by which means the body was drawn up and tied in as small a bundle as possible. All belongings of the deceased were placed in and on the grave to be used in the happy hunting grounds.
PH Coll 568.9
rdf:Description.dc:source: Sarah Cheney Willoughby Drawings. PH Coll 568 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Eskimo and Aleut implements and baskets from Alaska, in engraving made 1807
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Langsdorff, G. H. von (Georg Heinrich), 1774-1852
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Engravings; Aleuts--Arts & crafts; Eskimos--Arts & crafts; Baskets--Alaska; Unalaska (Alaska)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Photograph of engraving of tools, jewelry, baskets. Caption says tools of Alaska and Unalaska.
Note from unidentified source: 1) a pouch of fishskins from Alaska 2) a finger-guard of leather, usid in place of a thimble by Alaskan women for sewing 3) a rattle from Kodiak, used in the dance and which consists of the bills of puffins 4) and 5) ear ornament made from walrus tusk, and from mussel shells 6) a lip ornament of the Aleuts, in actual size, which consists of a small piece of bone and glass beads, and is inserted in an ingeneously [sic] made opening beneath the lower lip 7) an example of embroidery on leather done with reindeer hair, from Unalaska 8) a cap of squirrel skins from Alaska 9) a small basket woven from straw from Unalaska 10) and 11) two pocket books woven from strw from Unalaska 12) a cap with a great deal of embroidery, used only in the dance festivals of the Aleuts. The stray goat hairs were sewn and woven as ornament.
Image from G. H. von Langsdorff's Bemerkungen auf einer Reise um die Welt in den Jahren 1803 bis 1807, 1812. V.2, pl.11
Caption on image: Gerathschaften von Alaska und Unalaska
rdf:Description.dc:source: University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Aleut bidara (a skin covered boat) design plan, Alaska Peninsula, Alaska, in engraving made 1807
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Langsdorff, G. H. von (Georg Heinrich), 1774-1852
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Engravings; Aleuts--Arts & crafts; Aleuts--Transportation; Skin boats--Alaska
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Photograph of engraving showing the top, side & end views of the wooden frame of a multi-seat, skin covered boat
Note from unidentified source: a) the keel b) the rear piece, which is fastened together with the keel c) the board, which rests on the keel d) cross laths which lie on the keel e) poles, which lie at the ends of the cross laths f) the ribs, over which the stretched skin is pulled, and which are fastened to the lower cross laths g) the upper edge laths, which are fastened to the streched skin h) laths on the inner portion of the sides, on which the benches lie I) the sitting benches k) thong twined together, which are placed in 3 or 4 places under the benches, so that the baidar cannot break asunder in the waves. No rails are used the fastening, instead the pieces are made fast with baleen or sinew. The entire skeleton, or framework, is finally covered with sewn together seal pelts m) the steering paddle.
Image from G. H. von Langsdorff's Bemerkungen auf einer Reise um die Welt in den Jahren 1803 bis 1807, 1812. V.2, pl.12
rdf:Description.dc:source: University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kwakiutl village at Fort Rupert, British Columbia, 1914
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Curtis, Edward S., 1868-1952
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Kwakiutl Indians--Structures; Kwakiutl Indians--Arts & crafts; Totem poles--British Columbia--Fort Rupert
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Houses and totem poles. This village of Tsahi was founded in 1840 when the tribe abandoned Kalokwis on Turnour Island in order to be near the Hudson's Bay Company post which was being established at Fort Rupert on Vancouver Island. The totem pole in the foreground commemorates the legendary history of a Tsimshian family. Its presence in this Kwakiutl settlement is due to the following circumstances. A party of Seattle men, cruising in Alaska, innocently removed a totem pole from what they supposed was an abandoned village, and placed it in a public square of their city. In reality the inhabitants of the Alaskan village were only temporarily absent, and when they returned and learned of the spoliation, there was a protest. The news finally reached Fort Rupert where there lived a prominent member of the wronged family, the aged Tsimshian widow of a former employee of the Hudson's Bay Company. In order to wipe out the stain on the family name, she had a local carver produce a totem pole according to her description of the lost one. She had it erected at the house of her eldest son's eldest son. According to Viola Garfield, the original pole was stolen from Tongass, Alaska and placed in Pioneer Square in 1899, making it of Tlingit manufacture.
Caption on mount: Qagyuhl village at Fort Rupert
Image from: Edward Curtis' Native American Indian, Folio. v.10, pl. 353
rdf:Description.dc:source: University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:description:

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tlingit housepost of tired wolf (originally from Tongass), Saxman, Alaska, July 1939
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Schallerer, Otto
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tlingit Indians--Arts & crafts; Totem poles--Alaska--Saxman; Wood carvings--Alaska--Saxman; Totem poles--Alaska--Tongass; Wood carvings--Alaska--Tongass
rdf:Description.dc:description:
House post of wolf seen from the side, with tongue hanging out. In background can be seen a white bear post, and a house.
Note from unidentified source: One of a pair of houseposts from Tongass called the Tired Wolf; this post has a face carved in wolf's eye. Repaired and set up at Saxman National Monument [Saxman Totem Park]
In Garfield Collection, 130/4/5

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tlingit totem pole in Pioneer Square seen from Yesler Street, Seattle, Washington
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Warner, Arthur Churchill, 1864-1943
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Totem poles--Washington (State)--Seattle ; Tlingit Indians--Arts & crafts; Pioneer Square (Seattle, Wash.); Seattle (Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Totem pole set in triangular median; small wrought iron fence around pole and shrubs. Olympic Hotel (with Northern Pacific ticket office) visible behind it. Horse drawn buggy and truck seen along 1st Avenue South behind pole. Taken pre-1906, as the Pioneer Square Pergola has not been built. Also in NA1509, cur3963, cur47020, UW8571
Caption on image: The totem pole. 204.
Note from Museum of History and Industry: The totem pole at Pioneer Square has been a Seattle landmark since 1899. That year, a group of Seattle businessmen visited a Tlingit village in Alaska. They thought the village was deserted and removed a 50-foot tall totem pole as a souvenir. The men brought the pole back to Seattle and had it set up in Pioneer Square. They were later fined for the theft of the pole. After being damaged by fire in 1938, it was replaced by a duplicate pole carved by Tlingit craftsmen.
rdf:Description.dc:source: Arthur Churchill Warner Collection no. 273 University of Washington Libraries. Special Collections Division
rdf:Description.dc:relation: American Indians of the Pacific Northwest Images http://content.lib.washington.edu/aipnw/

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tlingit totem pole and iron pergola in Pioneer Square, Seattle, Washington
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Curtis, Asahel, 1874-1941
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Totem poles--Washington (State)--Seattle ; Tlingit Indians--Arts & crafts; Pioneer Square (Seattle, Wash.); Seattle (Wash.)
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Totem pole set in concrete triangular median; behind it is an iron & glass pergola trolley stop. Olympic Hotel, Hotel Seattle & Merchants Cafe visible behind it, as well the corner of the Pioneer Building on the left. Taken after 1906 when the Pioneer Square Pergola has been built. Also in NA1509, war3017, cur3963, UW8571

They thought the village was deserted and removed a 50-foot tall totem pole as a souvenir. The men brought the pole back to Seattle and had it set up in Pioneer Square. They were later fined for the theft of the pole. After being damaged by fire in 1938, it was replaced by a duplicate pole carved by Tlingit craftsmen.
